column2: Scenario
column4: Question
column7: Options
column12: Correct Answer
column23: Rationale
column47: Description of Topic (OCR Audited Focus)

column2: Scenario: Treatment and Clinical Safeguards: Dr. Chen, a hospitalist, is treating Mr. Davies, a patient recovering from a stroke. Dr. Chen requests Mr. Davies’s entire medical history from an outpatient clinic. Nurse Rita is using a mobile workstation near the patient’s bedside.
column4: Dr. Chen is requesting Mr. Davies’s complete medical history from the clinic for treatment purposes. Which rule governs the degree of information Dr. Chen is entitled to receive?
column7: A. The disclosure must be limited to the minimum necessary amount.B. The minimum necessary requirement does not apply to disclosures for treatment.C. The minimum necessary requirement applies only if authorization is obtained.D. The disclosure must be limited only to information created within the last year.
column12: B. The minimum necessary requirement does not apply to disclosures for treatment.
column23: Disclosures to, or requests by, a health care provider for treatment are explicitly exempt from the Minimum Necessary standard.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define role based access.

column2: Scenario: Treatment and Clinical Safeguards: Dr. Chen, a hospitalist, is treating Mr. Davies, a patient recovering from a stroke. Dr. Chen requests Mr. Davies’s entire medical history from an outpatient clinic. Nurse Rita is using a mobile workstation near the patient’s bedside.
column4: Nurse Rita temporarily steps away from the mobile workstation while Mr. Davies’s chart is visible. She must implement safeguards to protect the PHI, primarily to limit:
column7: A. Incidental uses or disclosures made pursuant to a permitted use.B. Unintentional alteration of ePHI.C. Patient’s right to access.D. The volume of the designated record set.
column12: A. Incidental uses or disclosures made pursuant to a permitted use.
column23: Covered entities must reasonably safeguard protected health information to limit incidental uses or disclosures made pursuant to an otherwise permitted or required use.
column47: Administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect PHI and limit incidental uses/disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Treatment and Clinical Safeguards: Dr. Chen, a hospitalist, is treating Mr. Davies, a patient recovering from a stroke. Dr. Chen requests Mr. Davies’s entire medical history from an outpatient clinic. Nurse Rita is using a mobile workstation near the patient’s bedside.
column4: The policies requiring Nurse Rita to log into the workstation using a unique user ID and password are an example of fulfilling which required Security Rule implementation specification?
column7: A. Unique User Identification (Required).B. Access Authorization (Addressable).C. Automatic Logoff (Addressable).D. Encryption and Decryption (Addressable).
column12: A. Unique User Identification (Required).
column23: The standard requires assigning a unique name and/or number for identifying and tracking user identity to ensure activity is traceable.
column47: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column2: Scenario: Treatment and Clinical Safeguards: Dr. Chen, a hospitalist, is treating Mr. Davies, a patient recovering from a stroke. Dr. Chen requests Mr. Davies’s entire medical history from an outpatient clinic. Nurse Rita is using a mobile workstation near the patient’s bedside.
column4: If Dr. Chen uses the PHI for the hospital’s internal quality assessment activities, this activity falls under which category?
column7: A. Treatment.B. Health care operations.C. Payment.D. Disclosure to the individual.
column12: B. Health care operations.
column23: Conducting quality assessment and improvement activities, including outcomes evaluation, constitutes health care operations under the Privacy Rule.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Treatment and Clinical Safeguards: Dr. Chen, a hospitalist, is treating Mr. Davies, a patient recovering from a stroke. Dr. Chen requests Mr. Davies’s entire medical history from an outpatient clinic. Nurse Rita is using a mobile workstation near the patient’s bedside.
column4: If the hospital contracts with an external consulting firm to analyze recovery data for a study, the hospital must ensure the firm will not use or disclose PHI in a manner that would violate the Privacy Rule if done by the hospital. This is a requirement for:
column7: A. Healthcare clearinghouses.B. Health insurance issuers.C. Business associates.D. Affiliated covered entities.
column12: C. Business associates.
column23: A business associate may not use or disclose PHI in a manner that would violate HIPAA if done by the covered entity.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Admin Operations and Reimbursement: Sarah, an administrative clerk, is preparing to submit a claim for physical therapy services provided to Ms. Allen. She accesses Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing.
column4: Sarah’s primary job function involves submitting claims, which is defined under HIPAA as which category of permissible use or disclosure?
column7: A. Treatment.B. Health care operations.C. Payment.D. Marketing.
column12: C. Payment.
column23: Activities undertaken by a health care provider or plan to obtain or provide reimbursement for health care provision are defined as Payment activities.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Admin Operations and Reimbursement: Sarah, an administrative clerk, is preparing to submit a claim for physical therapy services provided to Ms. Allen. She accesses Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing.
column4: By accessing Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing, Sarah is violating which core privacy principle?
column7: A. The Authorization Standard.B. The Treatment Exception.C. The De-identification Requirement.D. The Minimum Necessary Standard.
column12: D. The Minimum Necessary Standard.
column23: When using or disclosing PHI for purposes like Payment or Operations, reasonable efforts must be made to limit information to the minimum necessary amount to accomplish the purpose.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Admin Operations and Reimbursement: Sarah, an administrative clerk, is preparing to submit a claim for physical therapy services provided to Ms. Allen. She accesses Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing.
column4: Under which circumstance is the Minimum Necessary Standard explicitly stated NOT to apply, making it a critical exception for staff to recognize?
column7: A. Disclosures made for health care operations.B. Uses disclosed pursuant to an authorization.C. Disclosures required by law.D. Disclosures to consumer reporting agencies.
column12: B. Uses disclosed pursuant to an authorization.
column23: The Minimum Necessary requirement does not apply to disclosures made pursuant to a valid authorization signed by the individual.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Admin Operations and Reimbursement: Sarah, an administrative clerk, is preparing to submit a claim for physical therapy services provided to Ms. Allen. She accesses Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing.
column4: To ensure minimum necessary compliance when determining Sarah’s access rights, the organization must identify which specific factor regarding her job role?
column7: A. Whether Sarah has received a patient authorization form.B. The maximum defined data set.C. Category of PHI access needed and any conditions appropriate to that access.D. The likelihood of re-identification of the PHI.
column12: C. Category of PHI access needed and any conditions appropriate to that access.
column23: The organization must identify those persons in its workforce who need access to PHI and the category of PHI access needed and any appropriate conditions.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Admin Operations and Reimbursement: Sarah, an administrative clerk, is preparing to submit a claim for physical therapy services provided to Ms. Allen. She accesses Ms. Allen’s entire medical chart, including mental health notes unnecessary for claims processing.
column4: If Sarah requests specific billing info from another covered entity (CE), the organization may rely on the other CE's representation that the info is the minimum necessary, provided the reliance is:
column7: A. Documented.B. Reasonable under the circumstances.C. Limited to the past six years.D. Approved by the Privacy Official.
column12: B. Reasonable under the circumstances.
column23: A covered entity may rely, if such reliance is reasonable under the circumstances, on a requested disclosure as the minimum necessary when the info is requested by another CE.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary: reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Patient Rights: Access and Denial: Mr. Brown submits a written request for a complete copy of his medical and billing records (the Designated Record Set, or DRS). He asks for the records to be sent to him as an encrypted PDF via email.
column4: Which of the following information sets about Mr. Brown is explicitly included in the definition of a Designated Record Set (DRS) and is thus subject to the Right of Access?
column7: A. DRS includes only medical records.B. DRS includes medical records and billing records.C. DRS includes only records used to make decisions about the individual.D. DRS excludes information maintained by a health plan.
column12: B. DRS includes medical records and billing records.
column23: The DRS includes medical records and billing records about individuals maintained by or for a covered health care provider.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Patient Rights: Access and Denial: Mr. Brown submits a written request for a complete copy of his medical and billing records (the Designated Record Set, or DRS). He asks for the records to be sent to him as an encrypted PDF via email.
column4: Assuming no reviewable grounds for denial exist, the organization must act on Mr. Brown’s request to obtain his records no later than how many days after receiving the request?
column7: A. 15 calendar days.B. 30 calendar days.C. 60 calendar days.D. 90 calendar days.
column12: B. 30 calendar days.
column23: The covered entity must act on a request for access no later than 30 days after receipt of the request.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical Staff, All Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Patient Rights: Access and Denial: Mr. Brown submits a written request for a complete copy of his medical and billing records (the Designated Record Set, or DRS). He asks for the records to be sent to him as an encrypted PDF via email.
column4: If the organization needs more time to process Mr. Brown’s request, it may extend the time period by up to an additional 30 days, provided it takes which required action?
column7: A. Provide him a written statement of reasons for the delay before the original 30-day limit expires.B. Obtain his oral agreement for the delay.C. Obtain approval from HHS for the extension.D. Waive all fees associated with the record copying.
column12: A. Provide him a written statement of reasons for the delay before the original 30-day limit expires.
column23: An entity may extend the time by no more than 30 days, provided that it informs the individual in writing of the reasons for the delay and completion date.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Patient Rights: Access and Denial: Mr. Brown submits a written request for a complete copy of his medical and billing records (the Designated Record Set, or DRS). He asks for the records to be sent to him as an encrypted PDF via email.
column4: Since Mr. Brown requested an electronic copy of his electronically maintained records, the organization must provide the PHI in that requested electronic form/format unless:
column7: A. The individual agrees to pay a higher fee.B. The organization chooses to provide a summary instead.C. The organization determines the requested electronic format is not readily producible.D. The disclosure is made to a health plan.
column12: C. The organization determines the requested electronic format is not readily producible.
column23: If the PHI is maintained electronically and the individual requests an electronic copy, the CE must provide it in the requested form and format if readily producible.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Patient Rights: Access and Denial: Mr. Brown submits a written request for a complete copy of his medical and billing records (the Designated Record Set, or DRS). He asks for the records to be sent to him as an encrypted PDF via email.
column4: If the organization does not maintain Mr. Brown’s requested PHI but knows where the information is held, the organization must fulfill which responsibility?
column7: A. Immediately forward the request to the correct entity.B. Inform the individual where to direct the request for access.C. Provide him a denial based on unreviewable grounds.D. Wait for Mr. Brown to renew his request after 60 days.
column12: B. Inform the individual where to direct the request for access.
column23: If the covered entity does not maintain the PHI and knows where it is maintained, the covered entity must inform the individual where to direct the request.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Disposal and Workstation Security: Billing specialist Tom prints a large stack of Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents containing PHI. He leaves the printouts unsecured on his desk overnight and forgets to shred obsolete billing reports.
column4: Tom leaving printed PHI unsecured on his desk overnight primarily violates the requirement to implement:
column7: A. Facility Access Controls.B. Minimum necessary policies.C. Physical Safeguards.D. Technical Safeguards.
column12: C. Physical Safeguards.
column23: The organization must implement physical measures (Physical Safeguards) to protect electronic information systems and related buildings.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect PHI and limit incidental uses/disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Disposal and Workstation Security: Billing specialist Tom prints a large stack of Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents containing PHI. He leaves the printouts unsecured on his desk overnight and forgets to shred obsolete billing reports.
column4: If Tom had stored the PHI on a flash drive, and the organization decides to reuse the drive for non-PHI operational data, the required procedure is:
column7: A. Encrypting the PHI before reuse.B. Removing the ePHI from the media before reuse.C. Logging the reuse in the Security Incident Log.D. Performing a risk analysis on the drive before reuse.
column12: B. Removing the ePHI from the media before reuse.
column23: The Media Re-use specification requires implementing procedures for the removal of ePHI from electronic media before the media are made available for re-use.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, All Staff
column47: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Disposal and Workstation Security: Billing specialist Tom prints a large stack of Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents containing PHI. He leaves the printouts unsecured on his desk overnight and forgets to shred obsolete billing reports.
column4: The policies governing the final destruction of electronic media or hardware containing PHI must comply with which required implementation specification under the Physical Safeguards?
column7: A. Accountability.B. Maintenance Records.C. Media Re-use.D. Disposal.
column12: D. Disposal.
column23: The Disposal specification is a required safeguard mandating policies for the final disposition of ePHI and the hardware/electronic media it occupies.
column47: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Disposal and Workstation Security: Billing specialist Tom prints a large stack of Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents containing PHI. He leaves the printouts unsecured on his desk overnight and forgets to shred obsolete billing reports.
column4: If Tom uses a laptop (Workstation) to input data and the organization implements physical safeguards for that device, the primary objective of these safeguards is to:
column7: A. Encrypt the data at rest.B. Restrict access to authorized users.C. Automate audit log review.D. Ensure the workforce uses unique IDs.
column12: B. Restrict access to authorized users.
column23: Workstation Security requires implementing physical safeguards for all workstations that access ePHI, to restrict access to authorized users.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, Clinical
column47: Physical safeguards for workstations to restrict access to authorized users.

column2: Scenario: Disposal and Workstation Security: Billing specialist Tom prints a large stack of Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents containing PHI. He leaves the printouts unsecured on his desk overnight and forgets to shred obsolete billing reports.
column4: The policies and procedures that define the proper functions Tom is permitted to perform on his workstation are required under which specific standard?
column7: A. Workstation Security.B. Workstation Use.C. Device and Media Controls.D. Facility Access Controls.
column12: B. Workstation Use.
column23: Workstation Use requires implementing policies that specify proper functions to be performed and physical attributes of workstation surroundings.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, All Staff
column47: Rules for appropriate functions, manner of use, and physical attributes of workstations accessing ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Standards and Identifiers: The Accounts Receivable department attempts to submit a batch of electronic claims to a health plan.
column4: The required standard unique identifier used to identify the organization (as a healthcare provider) in the electronic claim transaction is the:
column7: A. Social Security Number (SSN).B. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).C. National Provider Identifier (NPI).D. Employer Identification Number (EIN).
column12: C. National Provider Identifier (NPI).
column23: The standard unique health identifier for health care providers is the NPI, which must be used on all standard transactions requiring a provider ID.
column38: Standard Unique Health Identifier for Health Care Providers
column47: Compliance dates and standards for implementing the NPI for providers.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Standards and Identifiers: The Accounts Receivable department attempts to submit a batch of electronic claims to a health plan.
column4: If the claim also involves the transmission of info regarding the plan sponsor (employer) responsible for the health plan, the standard unique identifier for the employer is the:
column7: A. National Provider Identifier (NPI).B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).C. Social Security Number (SSN).D. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).
column12: B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).
column23: The Employer Identification Number (EIN), assigned by the IRS, is the standard unique employer identifier for standard transactions.
column47: Standards and compliance for implementing the EIN as the employer identifier.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Standards and Identifiers: The Accounts Receivable department attempts to submit a batch of electronic claims to a health plan.
column4: When an organization sends an electronic health care claim to a health plan following federal data standards, what is the required format for this exchange?
column7: A. Standard format.B. A nonstandard format.C. Direct data entry.D. A trading partner agreement format.
column12: A. Standard format.
column23: If a covered entity uses electronic media to communicate with another entity required to follow these rules, they must conduct the activity as a standard exchange.
column47: Requirements for covered entities to conduct transactions in standard format.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Standards and Identifiers: The Accounts Receivable department attempts to submit a batch of electronic claims to a health plan.
column4: A health plan generally may not reject a standard transaction (e.g., the claim submission) solely because it contains:
column7: A. PHI that exceeds the minimum necessary amount.B. Invalid medical code sets.C. Data elements not needed or used by the health plan.D. An improper NPI.
column12: C. Data elements not needed or used by the health plan.
column23: A health plan may not delay or reject a standard transaction on the basis that it contains data elements not needed or used by the health plan.
column47: Additional requirements for health plans regarding standard transaction rejection.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Standards and Identifiers: The Accounts Receivable department attempts to submit a batch of electronic claims to a health plan.
column4: If the claim submission process requires the use of medical data code sets (e.g., ICD:10), the organization must use codes that are valid at the time the:
column7: A. Claim is paid.B. Health care is furnished.C. Transaction is initiated.D. Authorization is approved.
column12: B. Health care is furnished.
column23: When conducting a covered transaction, a covered entity must use medical data code sets that are valid at the time the health care is furnished.
column47: General requirements for the use of valid medical data code sets.

column2: Scenario: Data Record Set (DRS) Components and Penalty Factors: A request is received for PHI contained in the Designated Record Set (DRS). The Privacy Official is auditing the effectiveness of the minimum necessary policy for billing.
column4: In the context of a health care provider, the Designated Record Set (DRS) specifically includes which component?
column7: A. Psychotherapy notes.B. Billing records.C. Info compiled solely for use in a lawsuit.D. Employment records held by the provider in its role as employer.
column12: B. Billing records.
column23: The DRS includes medical records and billing records about individuals maintained by or for a covered health care provider.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Data Record Set (DRS) Components and Penalty Factors: A request is received for PHI contained in the Designated Record Set (DRS). The Privacy Official is auditing the effectiveness of the minimum necessary policy for billing.
column4: Which uses or disclosures of PHI are NOT subject to the Minimum Necessary rule?
column7: A. Uses for payment activities.B. Uses disclosed to the individual.C. Disclosures for health care operations.D. Disclosures to consumer reporting agencies.
column12: B. Uses disclosed to the individual.
column23: The Minimum Necessary requirement does not apply to uses or disclosures made to the individual, as permitted under § 164.502(a)(1)(i).
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff, Clinical
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Data Record Set (DRS) Components and Penalty Factors: A request is received for PHI contained in the Designated Record Set (DRS). The Privacy Official is auditing the effectiveness of the minimum necessary policy for billing.
column4: For disclosures made on a routine and recurring basis (such as standard claims submissions), the organization must implement policies that limit the PHI disclosed to the amount:
column7: A. Necessary for treatment, payment, or operations.B. Reasonably necessary to achieve the purpose of the disclosure.C. That is required by law.D. Contained in the entire medical record.
column12: B. Reasonably necessary to achieve the purpose of the disclosure.
column23: For routine and recurring disclosures, the covered entity must implement policies that limit PHI disclosed to the amount reasonably necessary to achieve the purpose.
column47: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary: reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Data Record Set (DRS) Components and Penalty Factors: A request is received for PHI contained in the Designated Record Set (DRS). The Privacy Official is auditing the effectiveness of the minimum necessary policy for billing.
column4: The organization may not use, disclose, or request an entire medical record unless the entire record is specifically justified as the amount that is:
column7: A. Needed for quality review.B. Required for legal services.C. Reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose.D. Necessary for the public good.
column12: C. Reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose.
column23: The organization may not use, disclose, or request an entire medical record, except when the entire medical record is specifically justified as reasonably necessary.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff, Management
column47: Prohibition on using, disclosing, or requesting entire medical records unless specifically justified as reasonably necessary.

column2: Scenario: Data Record Set (DRS) Components and Penalty Factors: A request is received for PHI contained in the Designated Record Set (DRS). The Privacy Official is auditing the effectiveness of the minimum necessary policy for billing.
column4: The financial condition of the organization may be considered by the Secretary (HHS) as a factor in determining a Civil Money Penalty (CMP). Which is an additional factor?
column7: A. The size of the workforce.B. The history of prior compliance.C. The length of the notice of privacy practices.D. The percentage of billing done electronically.
column12: B. The history of prior compliance.
column23: Factors considered in determining a CMP amount include nature and extent of the violation, harm, financial condition, and history of prior compliance [1135–1139, 2013–2017].
column47: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column2: Scenario: Amendment Request and Denial: Ms. Carla requests a written amendment to her billing record, claiming the charge for a lab test was incorrect. She submits the request with supporting documentation to the Billing Department on 1 July.
column4: The Billing Department must act on Ms. Carla’s request for amendment no later than:
column7: A. 15 business days.B. 60 calendar days.C. 30 calendar days.D. 90 calendar days.
column12: B. 60 calendar days.
column23: The covered entity must act on the individual’s request for an amendment no later than 60 days after receipt of the request.
column47: Right to request amendment of PHI, required steps to grant/deny, and duties to inform recipients.

column2: Scenario: Amendment Request and Denial: Ms. Carla requests a written amendment to her billing record, claiming the charge for a lab test was incorrect. She submits the request with supporting documentation to the Billing Department on 1 July.
column4: If the department grants the amendment, they must make reasonable efforts to inform and provide the amendment to which of the following?
column7: A. Only the individual.B. Persons identified by the individual and persons the entity knows may have relied on the info.C. Only other covered entities (excluding business associates).D. Only external auditors.
column12: B. Persons identified by the individual and persons the entity knows may have relied on the info.
column23: The entity must inform and provide the amendment to persons identified by the individual and persons, including BAs, known to have relied on such info.
column47: Right to request amendment of PHI, required steps to grant/deny, and duties to inform recipients.

column2: Scenario: Amendment Request and Denial: Ms. Carla requests a written amendment to her billing record, claiming the charge for a lab test was incorrect. She submits the request with supporting documentation to the Billing Department on 1 July.
column4: If the department denies Ms. Carla’s request because the record is determined to be accurate and complete, the denial is permissible under which regulation?
column7: A. Denial based on unreviewable grounds.B. Denial because the record is accurate and complete.C. Denial based on the Privacy Act.D. Denial because the request concerns payment.
column12: B. Denial because the record is accurate and complete.
column23: An entity may deny an amendment request if it determines that the PHI/record is accurate and complete.
column47: Right to request amendment of PHI, required steps to grant/deny, and duties to inform recipients.

column2: Scenario: Amendment Request and Denial: Ms. Carla requests a written amendment to her billing record, claiming the charge for a lab test was incorrect. She submits the request with supporting documentation to the Billing Department on 1 July.
column4: If the request is denied, the written denial must contain a description of how she may complain to the organization or to which federal office?
column7: A. The Department of Justice (DOJ).B. The Secretary (HHS) of the Department of Health and Human Services.C. The FBI.D. The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO).
column12: B. The Secretary (HHS) of the Department of Health and Human Services.
column23: The denial must include a description of how the individual may complain to the covered entity or to the Secretary.
column47: Right to request amendment of PHI, required steps to grant/deny, and duties to inform recipients.

column2: Scenario: Amendment Request and Denial: Ms. Carla requests a written amendment to her billing record, claiming the charge for a lab test was incorrect. She submits the request with supporting documentation to the Billing Department on 1 July.
column4: If Ms. Carla disagrees with the denial, she can submit a statement of disagreement. In response, the Billing Department:
column7: A. May prepare a written rebuttal and must provide her a copy.B. Must prepare a written rebuttal but may refuse to provide a copy.C. Must grant the amendment regardless of the rebuttal.D. Must terminate her right to request future amendments.
column12: A. May prepare a written rebuttal and must provide her a copy.
column23: The covered entity may prepare a written rebuttal to the individual’s statement of disagreement, and if prepared, must provide a copy to the individual.
column47: Right to request amendment of PHI, required steps to grant/deny, and duties to inform recipients.

column2: Scenario: Restriction Request: Mr. Davis pays for a procedure entirely out-of-pocket. He submits a request asking the Billing Department not to disclose any PHI related to this service to his health plan for payment or operations.
column4: In this specific scenario (paid in full out-of-pocket), the organization must agree to the restriction request, provided the disclosure is not otherwise:
column7: A. Permitted under judicial proceedings.B. Required by law.C. Limited to the Minimum Necessary rule.D. Restricted to a limited data set.
column12: B. Required by law.
column23: A covered entity must agree to the request to restrict disclosure to a health plan if the disclosure is for payment/operations and is not otherwise required by law.
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans.

column2: Scenario: Restriction Request: Mr. Davis pays for a procedure entirely out-of-pocket. He submits a request asking the Billing Department not to disclose any PHI related to this service to his health plan for payment or operations.
column4: If the organization agrees, this agreement is effective in preventing disclosure for payment or operations, but does NOT restrict disclosures that are permitted or required under:
column7: A. Disclosures for TPO (Treatment, Payment, Operations).B. Disclosures to the Secretary for compliance investigations.C. Uses for payment processing.D. Uses for health care operations.
column12: B. Disclosures to the Secretary for compliance investigations.
column23: A restriction is not effective to prevent uses or disclosures permitted or required under sections such as § 164.502(a)(2)(ii) (disclosure to the Secretary).
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans.

column2: Scenario: Restriction Request: Mr. Davis pays for a procedure entirely out-of-pocket. He submits a request asking the Billing Department not to disclose any PHI related to this service to his health plan for payment or operations.
column4: If Mr. Davis had not paid the service in full out-of-pocket, the organization’s obligation regarding the restriction request would be to:
column7: A. Automatically deny the request.B. Agree to the restriction only if it benefits the provider’s operations.C. Permit the individual to request the restriction, but the entity is not required to agree.D. Permit the request but only for 30 days.
column12: C. Permit the individual to request the restriction, but the entity is not required to agree.
column23: The covered entity must permit an individual to request a restriction, but except for the “paid in full” exception, the entity is not required to agree.
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans.

column2: Scenario: Restriction Request: Mr. Davis pays for a procedure entirely out-of-pocket. He submits a request asking the Billing Department not to disclose any PHI related to this service to his health plan for payment or operations.
column4: If the organization agrees to the restriction, this agreement must be documented in accordance with which administrative requirement?
column7: A. Sanction Policy.B. Documentation and Retention (§ 164.530(j)).C. Evaluation standard.D. Security Management Process.
column12: B. Documentation and Retention (§ 164.530(j)).
column23: A covered entity must document a restriction in accordance with § 164.530(j).
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans.

column2: Scenario: Restriction Request: Mr. Davis pays for a procedure entirely out-of-pocket. He submits a request asking the Billing Department not to disclose any PHI related to this service to his health plan for payment or operations.
column4: The department later agrees to terminate the restriction because Mr. Davis orally requested it. To finalize the termination, the department must ensure that the oral agreement is:
column7: A. Documented.B. Certified by the Privacy Official.C. Communicated to the health plan.D. Agreed to in writing by the Privacy Official.
column12: A. Documented.
column23: An entity may terminate a restriction if the individual orally agrees to the termination and the oral agreement is documented.
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans.

column2: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of all disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic over the last seven years. The request is submitted on 1 October 2024.
column4: The maximum time period covered by the accounting must go back to:
column7: A. 1 October 2023 (1 year).B. 1 October 2018 (6 years).C. 1 October 2017 (7 years, as requested).D. The compliance date for the covered entity.
column12: B. 1 October 2018 (6 years).
column23: An individual has a right to receive an accounting of disclosures made by a covered entity in the six years prior to the request date.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical, All Staff
column47: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column2: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of all disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic over the last seven years. The request is submitted on 1 October 2024.
column4: Which disclosure is explicitly excluded from the required accounting that must be provided to Ms. Elena?
column7: A. Disclosures made to a public health authority.B. Disclosures made for health care operations.C. Disclosures made for health oversight activities.D. Disclosures made for research purposes without authorization.
column12: B. Disclosures made for health care operations.
column23: Disclosures to carry out treatment, payment, and health care operations (TPO) are excluded from the accounting requirement.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, Clinical, All Staff
column47: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column2: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of all disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic over the last seven years. The request is submitted on 1 October 2024.
column4: The organization must act on Ms. Elena’s request for an accounting no later than:
column7: A. 30 days.B. 60 days.C. 90 days.D. 180 days.
column12: B. 60 days.
column23: The covered entity must act on the request for an accounting no later than 60 days after receipt of the request.
column47: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column2: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of all disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic over the last seven years. The request is submitted on 1 October 2024.
column4: If the organization made multiple routine disclosures to the same health oversight agency during the period, it may satisfy the accounting requirement by providing:
column7: A. The full details of every disclosure made.B. A single entry for the first disclosure, the frequency, and the date of the last disclosure.C. Only a verbal summary.D. Only the disclosure date of the first instance.
column12: B. A single entry for the first disclosure, the frequency, and the date of the last disclosure.
column23: For multiple disclosures to the same person/entity for a single purpose, the accounting may provide frequency and date of last disclosure.
column47: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column2: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of all disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic over the last seven years. The request is submitted on 1 October 2024.
column4: If the organization denies Ms. Elena access based on reviewable grounds (e.g., safety), she retains the right to an accounting of disclosures because:
column7: A. The right to access is always subject to the right to an accounting.B. The right to an accounting applies except where limited by § 164.512.C. The denial of access on reviewable grounds constitutes a breach.D. The right to an accounting is not subject to the Minimum Necessary rule.
column12: B. The right to an accounting applies except where limited by § 164.512.
column23: An agreed-upon restriction or denial of access is not effective to prevent uses or disclosures permitted or required under § 164.528 (accounting).
column47: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column2: Scenario: Device Reuse and Administrative Functions: IT is preparing to reuse several old hard drives used by the billing department by wiping them and deploying them to non-PHI related operational staff.
column4: The required procedure for the re-use of electronic media involves implementing procedures for:
column7: A. Encrypting the PHI prior to removal.B. Removal of ePHI from the media before the media are made available for re-use.C. Retaining the records for 6 years from the date of the last use.D. Documenting the transfer of ownership.
column12: B. Removal of ePHI from the media before the media are made available for re-use.
column23: Media Re-use requires implementing procedures for the removal of ePHI from electronic media before the media are made available for re-use.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, All Staff
column47: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Device Reuse and Administrative Functions: IT is preparing to reuse several old hard drives used by the billing department by wiping them and deploying them to non-PHI related operational staff.
column4: The administrative action of applying appropriate sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies is a:
column7: A. Required implementation specification.B. Addressable implementation specification.C. Security awareness training program.D. Technical safeguard.
column12: A. Required implementation specification.
column23: The Sanction Policy is a required implementation specification under the Security Management Process standard.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, Management
column47: Requirement to apply sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies and procedures.

column2: Scenario: Device Reuse and Administrative Functions: IT is preparing to reuse several old hard drives used by the billing department by wiping them and deploying them to non-PHI related operational staff.
column4: If the billing department uses a standard protocol to determine the precise PHI fields needed for routine eligibility verification, this process aligns primarily with:
column7: A. Designated Record Set documentation.B. Minimum Necessary disclosure policies for routine transactions.C. Review of security incident reports.D. Auditing of authentication mechanisms.
column12: B. Minimum Necessary disclosure policies for routine transactions.
column23: For routine disclosures, an entity must implement policies and procedures (standard protocols) that limit the PHI disclosed to the amount reasonably necessary.
column47: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary: reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Device Reuse and Administrative Functions: IT is preparing to reuse several old hard drives used by the billing department by wiping them and deploying them to non-PHI related operational staff.
column4: As required by the Security Rule, the organization must implement procedures to regularly review records of info system activity (audit logs, access reports). This is:
column7: A. Risk Management.B. Information System Activity Review.C. Contingency Planning.D. Evaluation.
column12: B. Information System Activity Review.
column23: The specification Information System Activity Review mandates implementing procedures to regularly review records of information system activity.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, IT, Management
column47: Regular review of audit logs, access reports, and securityincident tracking.

column2: Scenario: Device Reuse and Administrative Functions: IT is preparing to reuse several old hard drives used by the billing department by wiping them and deploying them to non-PHI related operational staff.
column4: When requesting PHI from another CE for payment, the requesting entity must limit the request to what is reasonably necessary. This falls under:
column7: A. Minimum Necessary uses.B. Minimum Necessary disclosures.C. Minimum Necessary requests.D. Minimum Necessary content.
column12: C. Minimum Necessary requests.
column23: Minimum Necessary requests requires limiting any request for PHI to that which is reasonably necessary when requesting info from other CEs.
column29: Admin and Billing Staff, All Staff
column47: Requirement to limit outgoing requests for PHI from other entities to the minimum necessary.

column2: Scenario: Unauthorized Internal Use: Accounts Manager Bob accesses the EHR system to view the diagnosis of a former high school acquaintance whose file he handles for billing. He uses his appropriate login credentials but accesses info unnecessary for his payment duties.
column5: Bob’s unauthorized access, even though he used his own credentials, is classified as an impermissible use of PHI under the Privacy Rule because:
column8: A. He did not obtain a signed patient authorization.B. The use was not for TPO or required by law.C. The Minimum Necessary rule was exceeded.D. All of the above.
column13: B. The use was not for TPO or required by law.
column24: A covered entity may not use or disclose PHI except as permitted (e.g., TPO, Authorization) or required. Personal curiosity is not a permitted purpose.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates; OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Unauthorized Internal Use: Accounts Manager Bob accesses the EHR system to view the diagnosis of a former high school acquaintance whose file he handles for billing. He uses his appropriate login credentials but accesses info unnecessary for his payment duties.
column5: If the organization imposes sanctions against Bob for this impermissible access, the entity must document the sanctions applied and retain this documentation for a minimum of:
column8: A. 1 year.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. Until the workforce member leaves employment.
column13: B. 6 years.
column24: A covered entity must document the sanctions applied and retain the documentation for six years from the date of creation or when last in effect.
column47: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column2: Scenario: Unauthorized Internal Use: Accounts Manager Bob accesses the EHR system to view the diagnosis of a former high school acquaintance whose file he handles for billing. He uses his appropriate login credentials but accesses info unnecessary for his payment duties.
column5: If Bob’s unauthorized use was accidental, made in good faith, and did not result in further impermissible disclosure, this event would be excluded from the definition of a breach because it was:
column8: A. An unintentional acquisition or access by a workforce member within the scope of authority.B. Properly mitigated.C. An inadvertent disclosure to an authorized person.D. Due to willful neglect.
column13: A. An unintentional acquisition or access by a workforce member within the scope of authority.
column24: A breach excludes any unintentional acquisition, access, or use of PHI by a workforce member in good faith and within the scope of authority, if no further use occurs.
column47: Definition of “breach,” exceptions (for example, unintentional goodfaith access within scope, inadvertent disclosures within an entity, and disclosures where risk is low).

column2: Scenario: Unauthorized Internal Use: Accounts Manager Bob accesses the EHR system to view the diagnosis of a former high school acquaintance whose file he handles for billing. He uses his appropriate login credentials but accesses info unnecessary for his payment duties.
column5: The administrative responsibility to establish (and implement as needed) policies and procedures for creating and maintaining retrievable exact copies of ePHI is known as the:
column8: A. Disaster Recovery Plan.B. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.C. Data Backup Plan.D. Evaluation Plan.
column13: C. Data Backup Plan.
column24: The Data Backup Plan is a required implementation specification mandating procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI.
column47: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column2: Scenario: Unauthorized Internal Use: Accounts Manager Bob accesses the EHR system to view the diagnosis of a former high school acquaintance whose file he handles for billing. He uses his appropriate login credentials but accesses info unnecessary for his payment duties.
column5: When protecting paper billing records from unauthorized access during normal business hours (e.g., keeping sensitive documents secured when away from desk), the organization is primarily applying:
column8: A. Technical safeguards.B. Administrative safeguards related to sanctions.C. Physical and administrative safeguards to limit incidental disclosure.D. Minimum necessary disclosures for payment.
column13: C. Physical and administrative safeguards to limit incidental disclosure.
column24: A covered entity must reasonably safeguard PHI (using appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safeguards) to limit incidental uses or disclosures.
column47: Administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect PHI and limit incidental uses/disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Transactions and Identifiers: The Accounts Manager routinely handles eligibility verification and claim status inquiries using standard electronic transactions.
column5: The primary goal of standardizing electronic transactions for administrative activities (like eligibility verification and payment) is rooted in which HIPAA requirement?
column8: A. Privacy Rule.B. Security Rule.C. Administrative Simplification.D. Breach Notification Rule.
column13: C. Administrative Simplification.
column24: HIPAA’s administrative simplification provisions standardize electronic transactions (e.g., claims, eligibility) and require the use of unique identifiers.
column47: Requirements for covered entities to conduct transactions in standard format.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Transactions and Identifiers: The Accounts Manager routinely handles eligibility verification and claim status inquiries using standard electronic transactions.
column5: If a covered healthcare provider initiates an electronic transaction to verify a patient’s coverage, benefits, or eligibility, this activity is defined as:
column8: A. Eligibility for a health plan: The correct transaction type for verifying an enrollee's plan-related info.B. Referral certification and authorization.C. Health care claim status.D. Coordination of benefits.
column13: A. Eligibility for a health plan: The correct transaction type for verifying an enrollee's plan-related info.
column24: Under Administrative Simplification, eligibility for a health plan is defined as the transmission of an inquiry to a health plan to obtain eligibility, coverage, or benefits info.
column47: Transmission of subscriber enrollment information from the sponsor of the insurance coverage, benefits, or policy, to a health plan to establish or terminate insurance coverage.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Transactions and Identifiers: The Accounts Manager routinely handles eligibility verification and claim status inquiries using standard electronic transactions.
column5: When submitting an electronic transaction that requires the identification of a group health plan sponsor (employer), the entity must use which standard unique identifier?
column8: A. National Provider Identifier (NPI).B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).C. Social Security Number (SSN).D. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).
column13: B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).
column24: The Secretary adopts the EIN as the standard unique employer identifier, which must be used in standard transactions requiring an employer identifier.
column47: Standards and compliance for implementing the EIN as the employer identifier.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Transactions and Identifiers: The Accounts Manager routinely handles eligibility verification and claim status inquiries using standard electronic transactions.
column5: If a health care clearinghouse acting as a BA receives a standard transaction but translates it into a nonstandard format before sending it to the covered entity, this function is:
column8: A. Prohibited by HIPAA.B. Permissible for a health care clearinghouse acting as a BA.C. Allowed only if the BA obtains patient authorization.D. Permitted only if the BA uses a Limited Data Set.
column13: B. Permissible for a health care clearinghouse acting as a BA.
column24: When acting as a business associate, a health care clearinghouse may receive a standard transaction and translate it into a nonstandard transaction for the CE.
column47: Processes or facilitates the processing of health information received from another entity in a nonstandard format into standard data elements or a standard transaction.

column2: Scenario: Electronic Transactions and Identifiers: The Accounts Manager routinely handles eligibility verification and claim status inquiries using standard electronic transactions.
column5: If a health plan requests the billing department to conduct a transaction (for which a standard exists) as a standard transaction, the billing department:
column8: A. May reject the request if it is too complex.B. Must do so.C. Must obtain patient consent first.D. May only do so if it is for treatment purposes.
column13: B. Must do so.
column24: If an entity requests a health plan (or a covered entity involved in a transaction) to conduct a transaction as a standard transaction, the entity must do so.
column47: Additional requirements for health plans regarding standard transaction rejection.

column2: Scenario: Minimum Necessary Implementation: The Privacy Official is auditing the billing department to ensure compliance with the minimum necessary standard when staff access patient records.
column5: The minimum necessary standard applies specifically to uses and disclosures for Payment and Operations activities, requiring staff to limit the PHI used to the amount:
column8: A. Necessary for treatment.B. That excludes all dates.C. Reasonably necessary to accomplish the intended purpose.D. That includes the entire billing record.
column13: C. Reasonably necessary to accomplish the intended purpose.
column24: When using or disclosing PHI for purposes like Payment or Operations, an entity must make reasonable efforts to limit PHI to the minimum necessary.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Minimum Necessary Implementation: The Privacy Official is auditing the billing department to ensure compliance with the minimum necessary standard when staff access patient records.
column5: To implement minimum necessary uses within the organization, staff policies must identify all the following except:
column8: A. Persons who need access to PHI to carry out their duties.B. The category of PHI to which access is needed.C. That PHI is disclosed only to the Secretary of HHS.D. Conditions appropriate to such access.
column13: C. That PHI is disclosed only to the Secretary of HHS.
column24: Implementation specifications require identifying persons who need access, the categories of PHI needed, and any conditions appropriate to such access.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: Minimum Necessary Implementation: The Privacy Official is auditing the billing department to ensure compliance with the minimum necessary standard when staff access patient records.
column5: When performing a compliance review, the organization must permit access by the Secretary of HHS to its facilities and records during normal business hours, unless:
column8: A. The review concerns a violation that occurred more than six years ago.B. The Secretary determines that exigent circumstances exist.C. The organization denies the access based on reviewable grounds.D. The organization has corrected the violation within 30 days.
column13: B. The Secretary determines that exigent circumstances exist.
column24: A covered entity must permit access by the Secretary during normal business hours: if exigent circumstances exist, access must be permitted at any time.
column47: Requirement to provide a process to receive complaints about privacy/breach compliance and document all complaints and dispositions.

column2: Scenario: Minimum Necessary Implementation: The Privacy Official is auditing the billing department to ensure compliance with the minimum necessary standard when staff access patient records.
column5: If the department reviews a disclosure request from a public official permitted under § 164.512, it may rely on the official’s representation that the info is the minimum necessary, provided the reliance is:
column8: A. Documented for future audits.B. Reasonable under the circumstances.C. Limited to demographic information.D. Accompanied by a written complaint.
column13: B. Reasonable under the circumstances.
column24: A covered entity may rely, if such reliance is reasonable under the circumstances, on a requested disclosure as the minimum necessary if made by a public official.
column47: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary; reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Minimum Necessary Implementation: The Privacy Official is auditing the billing department to ensure compliance with the minimum necessary standard when staff access patient records.
column5: If a manager finds a workforce member deliberately circumventing minimum necessary procedures for non-work reasons, the entity must apply sanctions. This is a(n):
column8: A. Physical Safeguard.B. Technical Safeguard.C. Administrative Safeguard.D. Organizational Requirement.
column13: C. Administrative Safeguard.
column24: The Sanction Policy is a required implementation specification under the Administrative Safeguards.
column47: Duty to have and apply sanctions against workforce members who violate privacy or breachrelated policies, and to document sanctions.

column2: Scenario: Access and Fees: A patient requests a copy of their billing records. The patient wishes the records to be provided on a CD-ROM provided by the patient.
column5: If the patient requests a copy of their PHI, the covered entity may impose a reasonable, cost-based fee that includes all the following, EXCEPT:
column8: A. Labor for copying the PHI.B. Cost of supplies for creating the electronic media copy.C. Labor for reviewing the PHI for appropriateness.D. Postage costs if the copy is mailed.
column13: C. Labor for reviewing the PHI for appropriateness.
column24: The fee may include labor for copying, supplies, and postage, but generally not labor for review of the PHI.
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Access and Fees: A patient requests a copy of their billing records. The patient wishes the records to be provided on a CD-ROM provided by the patient.
column5: If the patient agrees, the organization may provide a summary or explanation of the PHI instead of the full copy, provided the individual also agrees in advance to:
column8: A. Waive their right to future amendments.B. The fees imposed for the summary/explanation.C. The use of the PHI for marketing purposes.D. The destruction of the records after delivery.
column13: B. The fees imposed for the summary/explanation.
column24: If providing a summary or explanation, the individual must agree in advance to both the summary and the fees imposed for it.
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Access and Fees: A patient requests a copy of their billing records. The patient wishes the records to be provided on a CD-ROM provided by the patient.
column5: If the patient requests the records be transmitted directly to a designated third person, the request must be in writing, signed, and clearly identify the person and:
column8: A. That the disclosure is for Payment purposes.B. The reason the individual is unable to receive it directly.C. Where to send the copy of protected health information.D. The fee structure for the disclosure.
column13: C. Where to send the copy of protected health information.
column24: If the request directs transmission to another person, the request must be in writing, signed, and clearly identify the person and where to send the copy.
column47: Individual right to inspect and obtain copies (including electronic), timeliness, form/format, transmission to third parties, and fees.

column2: Scenario: Access and Fees: A patient requests a copy of their billing records. The patient wishes the records to be provided on a CD-ROM provided by the patient.
column5: When the billing department processes a transaction (e.g., claim status) that must meet an adopted standard, it is a Standard Transaction only if it also complies with:
column8: A. The HIPAA Privacy Rule in its entirety.B. The associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.C. A special HIPAA authorization signed by the individual.D. The full requirements of the Minimum Necessary rule.
column13: B. The associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column24: A standard transaction is a transaction that complies with an applicable standard and associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column47: Requirements for covered entities to conduct transactions in standard format.

column2: Scenario: Access and Fees: A patient requests a copy of their billing records. The patient wishes the records to be provided on a CD-ROM provided by the patient.
column5: If the department agrees to a patient’s restriction request (paid in full out-of-pocket), this restriction is NOT effective to prevent disclosures of PHI if the disclosure is:
column8: A. For patient billing.B. For health care operations.C. Required for auditing purposes under health oversight activities.D. Required for eligibility verification by the health plan.
column13: C. Required for auditing purposes under health oversight activities.
column24: A restriction agreed to is not effective to prevent uses or disclosures permitted or required under § 164.512 (e.g., health oversight).
column47: Right to request restrictions on uses/disclosures and mandatory restriction for selfpaid services with health plans; documentation and termination of restrictions.

column2: Scenario: Documentation and Retention: During a routine internal review, the compliance team checks records pertaining to privacy policies, accounting logs, and employee sanction documentation.
column5: The required retention period for privacy policies, sanctions applied against workforce members, and accounting of disclosures documentation is:
column8: A. 6 years from the date of creation or last effect, whichever is later.B. 6 years from the date of the individual’s last encounter.C. The minimum time set by state law.D. Until the document is reviewed and updated.
column13: A. 6 years from the date of creation or last effect, whichever is later.
column24: A covered entity must retain required documentation (including policies and records of actions) for six years from creation or last effect.
column47: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column2: Scenario: Documentation and Retention: During a routine internal review, the compliance team checks records pertaining to privacy policies, accounting logs, and employee sanction documentation.
column5: The designation of the contact person responsible for receiving complaints and providing further information about the privacy notice must be:
column8: A. Approved by the CEO.B. Documented and retained for six years.C. A licensed health care professional.D. Updated annually regardless of change.
column13: B. Documented and retained for six years.
column24: The personnel designation of the contact person/office responsible for receiving complaints must be documented and retained for six years.
column47: Designation of a privacy official and a contact person/office for complaints and NPP inquiries.

column2: Scenario: Documentation and Retention: During a routine internal review, the compliance team checks records pertaining to privacy policies, accounting logs, and employee sanction documentation.
column5: As required by HIPAA, documentation (such as policies and procedures) must be maintained in a written form and also must be made available to which specific group?
column8: A. All federal regulatory agencies.B. The public upon request.C. Those persons responsible for implementing the procedures.D. The Security Official only.
column13: C. Those persons responsible for implementing the procedures.
column24: The Security Rule requires that documentation be maintained in written form and made available to those persons responsible for implementing the procedures.
column47: Maintaining written/electronic security policies, procedures, and other required documentation for six years, making it available, and updating it.

column2: Scenario: Documentation and Retention: During a routine internal review, the compliance team checks records pertaining to privacy policies, accounting logs, and employee sanction documentation.
column5: If the department contracts with a BA for collections, and the BA uses an unauthorized external server to store PHI, violating the contract, the organization must:
column8: A. Document the violation and notify HHS immediately.B. Terminate the contract immediately and pay a fine.C. Take reasonable steps to cure the breach or end the violation, and terminate if unsuccessful.D. Re-negotiate the contract and reduce the BA’s remuneration.
column13: C. Take reasonable steps to cure the breach or end the violation, and terminate if unsuccessful.
column24: If a CE knew of a material violation by the BA, it must take reasonable steps to cure the breach and, if unsuccessful, terminate the contract.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Documentation and Retention: During a routine internal review, the compliance team checks records pertaining to privacy policies, accounting logs, and employee sanction documentation.
column5: Which implementation specification mandates procedures to establish safeguards for ePHI created by the plan sponsor on behalf of a group health plan?
column8: A. Group health plan sponsor safeguards.B. Security Management Process.C. Contingency Plan.D. Information Access Management.
column13: A. Group health plan sponsor safeguards.
column24: The plan documents must be amended to require the plan sponsor to implement administrative, physical, and technical safeguards for ePHI.
column47: Security obligations imposed on plan sponsors receiving ePHI from group health plans.

column2: Scenario: Breach and Administrative Functions: A billing employee accidentally emails an invoice batch containing the PHI of 15 patients to an incorrect, unsecure external email address. The information includes names and insurance ID numbers.
column5: The impermissible disclosure is presumed to be a breach unless the organization demonstrates a low probability that the PHI was compromised, based on which factor?
column8: A. The size of the billing department.B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.C. The financial status of the organization.D. Whether the information was encrypted.
column13: B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.
column24: The risk assessment to rebut the presumption of breach must consider, among other factors, whether the protected health information was actually acquired or viewed.
column47: Required fourfactor risk assessment to determine probability that PHI has been compromised: nature/extent of data, unauthorized person, whether PHI was acquired/viewed, and mitigation.

column2: Scenario: Breach and Administrative Functions: A billing employee accidentally emails an invoice batch containing the PHI of 15 patients to an incorrect, unsecure external email address. The information includes names and insurance ID numbers.
column5: If the risk assessment determines that notification is required (i.e., it was a breach), the organization must notify the affected individuals:
column8: A. Within 30 days of the breach.B. Within 60 calendar days after discovery of the breach.C. Within 90 calendar days after discovery of the breach.D. Only if the breach involved 500 or more individuals.
column13: B. Within 60 calendar days after discovery of the breach.
column24: Notification must be provided without unreasonable delay and in no case later than 60 calendar days after discovery of a breach.
column47: Requirement to provide notice without unreasonable delay and no later than 60 calendar days after discovery.

column2: Scenario: Breach and Administrative Functions: A billing employee accidentally emails an invoice batch containing the PHI of 15 patients to an incorrect, unsecure external email address. The information includes names and insurance ID numbers.
column5: Since the breach involved fewer than 500 individuals, the organization must notify the Secretary (HHS) of the breach:
column8: A. Contemporaneously with notice to the individuals.B. Never, as the number of individuals is too low.C. Annually, no later than 60 days after the end of the calendar year in which discovered.D. Only if the Privacy Official determines notification is warranted.
column13: C. Annually, no later than 60 days after the end of the calendar year in which discovered.
column24: For breaches involving fewer than 500 individuals, a covered entity must notify the Secretary annually, no later than 60 days after the end of the calendar year.
column38: Notification to the Secretary of HHS
column47: Reporting to HHS for breaches affecting 500 or more individuals without unreasonable delay and annual log submission for smaller breaches.

column2: Scenario: Breach and Administrative Functions: A billing employee accidentally emails an invoice batch containing the PHI of 15 patients to an incorrect, unsecure external email address. The information includes names and insurance ID numbers.
column5: Which administrative requirement mandates that the organization address this incident’s negative effects, such as the risk of identity theft for the 15 patients?
column8: A. Sanction Policy.B. Mitigation Standard.C. Evaluation Standard.D. Workforce Training.
column13: B. Mitigation Standard.
column24: A covered entity must mitigate, to the extent practicable, any known harmful effect of a use or disclosure of PHI in violation of its policies.
column47: Obligation to mitigate, to the extent practicable, harmful effects from known improper uses/disclosures of PHI.

column2: Scenario: Breach and Administrative Functions: A billing employee accidentally emails an invoice batch containing the PHI of 15 patients to an incorrect, unsecure external email address. The information includes names and insurance ID numbers.
column5: The notification sent to affected individuals must include a description of what happened, mitigation steps, and:
column8: A. The exact identity of the employee responsible.B. Contact procedures for individuals to ask questions.C. A mandatory offer of free credit monitoring.D. A copy of the written denial.
column13: B. Contact procedures for individuals to ask questions.
column24: The notification must include contact procedures for individuals to ask questions, including a toll-free number, email, or website.
column47: Obligation to notify affected individuals after discovery of a breach, including content, form, and method.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory and Deceased Individuals: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. Ms. Finch passes away in the facility.
column5: Ms. Harper’s daughter calls asking for her mother by name. The provider may disclose which items from the directory to the daughter?
column8: A. Name, location, condition, and religious affiliation.B. Name, prognosis, and treatment plan.C. Name, location, and condition in general terms, but not religious affiliation.D. Only her location.
column13: C. Name, location, and condition in general terms, but not religious affiliation.
column24: A provider may disclose directory info (name, location, condition) to persons who ask for the individual by name, except for religious affiliation.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column47: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care; opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory and Deceased Individuals: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. Ms. Finch passes away in the facility.
column5: If a member of the clergy arrives seeking Ms. Harper by name, the provider may disclose her religious affiliation because:
column8: A. Clergy members are considered health oversight agencies.B. Clergy disclosures are exempt from the Minimum Necessary standard.C. Disclosures to clergy are explicitly permitted to include religious affiliation.D. Religious affiliation is only disclosed upon written authorization.
column13: C. Disclosures to clergy are explicitly permitted to include religious affiliation.
column24: A covered healthcare provider may use or disclose for directory purposes the permitted information, including religious affiliation, to members of the clergy.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column47: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care; opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory and Deceased Individuals: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. Ms. Finch passes away in the facility.
column5: Following Ms. Finch’s death, the provider may disclose PHI relevant to her care to family members involved prior to her death, unless:
column8: A. The disclosure is for purposes of payment.B. Doing so is inconsistent with any known prior expressed preference of Ms. Finch.C. The family member is not the legal executor of the estate.D. The PHI is maintained in electronic format.
column13: B. Doing so is inconsistent with any known prior expressed preference of Ms. Finch.
column24: Disclosure is permitted to involved persons unless doing so is inconsistent with any prior expressed preference of the individual known to the CE.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column47: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care; opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory and Deceased Individuals: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. Ms. Finch passes away in the facility.
column5: For how long must the provider continue to comply with the Privacy Rule concerning Ms. Finch’s PHI after her death?
column8: A. Until five years after her death.B. Until 50 years following the death of the individual.C. For six years from the date of creation.D. PHI ceases to be protected immediately upon death.
column13: B. Until 50 years following the death of the individual.
column24: A covered entity must comply with requirements of Subpart E with respect to PHI of a deceased individual for 50 years following the individual's death.
column47: Obligation to protect PHI of deceased individuals for 50 years; OCR tests related policies and sample cases.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory and Deceased Individuals: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. Ms. Finch passes away in the facility.
column5: If Ms. Finch’s executor requests her medical records, the provider must treat that person as the individual because:
column8: A. The executor has authority under law to act on behalf of the deceased individual’s estate.B. The executor is liable for the deceased individual’s debts.C. The deceased individual signed an authorization prior to death.D. The disclosure is considered a public health activity.
column13: A. The executor has authority under law to act on behalf of the deceased individual’s estate.
column24: If under applicable law an executor has authority to act on behalf of a deceased individual, the CE must treat them as a personal representative.
column47: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Regulatory Compliance and Workforce Training: The clinic implemented a policy requiring medical professionals to shred patient info immediately after use. The clinic must also maintain staff training records.
column5: The policy requiring the immediate shredding of paper PHI addresses the requirement to implement policies for:
column8: A. Re-use of electronic media.B. Disposal of PHI and electronic media.C. Facility access controls.D. Technical integrity of electronic information.
column13: B. Disposal of PHI and electronic media.
column24: The disposal specification requires policies to address the final disposition of ePHI and/or media. Shredding paper PHI falls under general safeguarding.
column47: Administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect PHI and limit incidental uses/disclosures.
