column2: Scenario: Regulatory Compliance and Workforce Training: The clinic implemented a policy requiring medical professionals to shred patient info immediately after use. The clinic must also maintain staff training records.
column5: If the clinic discovers a newly hired nurse failed to complete mandatory HIPAA training, the clinic must ensure she receives it:
column8: A. Immediately upon discovery of the oversight.B. Within a reasonable period of time after joining the workforce.C. Only after she passes a certification exam.D. Within 60 calendar days of joining the workforce.
column13: B. Within a reasonable period of time after joining the workforce.
column24: Training must be provided to each new member of the workforce within a reasonable period of time after the person joins the workforce.
column47: Training requirements for workforce on Privacy Rule and breachrelated policies and documentation of that training.

column2: Scenario: Regulatory Compliance and Workforce Training: The clinic implemented a policy requiring medical professionals to shred patient info immediately after use. The clinic must also maintain staff training records.
column5: A temporary contract physician providing services for three months is considered part of the organization’s:
column8: A. Workforce.B. Subcontractor list.C. Business associate network.D. Plan sponsor group.
column13: A. Workforce.
column24: Workforce includes employees, volunteers, trainees, and other persons whose conduct is under the direct control of the covered entity.
column47: Training requirements for workforce on Privacy Rule and breachrelated policies and documentation of that training.

column2: Scenario: Regulatory Compliance and Workforce Training: The clinic implemented a policy requiring medical professionals to shred patient info immediately after use. The clinic must also maintain staff training records.
column5: If a workforce member believing in good faith that the clinic is endangering patients discloses PHI to an attorney, this disclosure:
column8: A. Is a violation of the Privacy Rule.B. Requires prior patient authorization.C. Is protected under the whistleblower provisions.D. Is permitted only if the disclosure is to the media.
column13: C. Is protected under the whistleblower provisions.
column24: A covered entity has not violated the rule if a workforce member discloses PHI to an attorney to determine legal options regarding conduct believed to be unlawful.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates; OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Regulatory Compliance and Workforce Training: The clinic implemented a policy requiring medical professionals to shred patient info immediately after use. The clinic must also maintain staff training records.
column5: How long must the clinic retain documentation of its policies, procedures, and security-related actions (e.g., sanction logs)?
column8: A. For 6 years from the date of its creation or last effect, whichever is later.B. Indefinitely.C. For 3 years from the compliance date.D. For 50 years following the death of the last patient referenced.
column13: A. For 6 years from the date of its creation or last effect, whichever is later.
column24: A covered entity must retain documentation required by HIPAA for six years from the date of its creation or the date when it last was in effect.
column47: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column2: Scenario: Physical Security and Technical Controls: The hospital uses electronic door locks for its server room. Kiosks are set to automatically lock the screen after a period of inactivity.
column5: The policy implementing the electronic door locks to restrict entry to the server room addresses which required Security Rule standard?
column8: A. Workstation Security.B. Device and Media Controls.C. Facility Access Controls.D. Audit Controls.
column13: C. Facility Access Controls.
column24: Facility Access Controls requires implementing policies and procedures to limit physical access to electronic information systems and facilities.
column47: Physical safeguards to limit facility access to ePHI systems, including contingency operations, security plans, access validation, and maintenance records.

column2: Scenario: Physical Security and Technical Controls: The hospital uses electronic door locks for its server room. Kiosks are set to automatically lock the screen after a period of inactivity.
column5: The practice of automatically locking the screen on kiosks after a predetermined time of inactivity relates to which specification?
column8: A. Automatic Logoff (Addressable).B. Encryption and Decryption (Addressable).C. Emergency Access Procedure (Required).D. Person or Entity Authentication (Required).
column13: A. Automatic Logoff (Addressable).
column24: Automatic Logoff implements electronic procedures that terminate an electronic session after a predetermined time of inactivity.
column47: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column2: Scenario: Physical Security and Technical Controls: The hospital uses electronic door locks for its server room. Kiosks are set to automatically lock the screen after a period of inactivity.
column5: If the hospital elects NOT to implement the automatic logoff feature due to legacy systems, what action must it take to remain compliant?
column8: A. Immediately implement an equivalent required measure.B. Document why implementation is not reasonable and implement an equivalent measure.C. Obtain written permission from the Secretary of HHS.D. Implement the technical safeguard as an administrative safeguard instead.
column13: B. Document why implementation is not reasonable and implement an equivalent measure.
column24: For Addressable specifications not implemented, the entity must document why and implement an equivalent alternative measure if reasonable.
column47: Requirement to implement reasonable and appropriate security policies and procedures.

column2: Scenario: Physical Security and Technical Controls: The hospital uses electronic door locks for its server room. Kiosks are set to automatically lock the screen after a period of inactivity.
column5: The mandatory Emergency Access Procedure requires establishing procedures for:
column8: A. Notifying individuals of a system breach within 60 days.B. Temporarily suspending access for maintenance during an emergency.C. Obtaining necessary ePHI during an emergency.D. Ensuring all staff know whom to call during a fire.
column13: C. Obtaining necessary ePHI during an emergency.
column24: The Emergency Access Procedure requires establishing procedures for obtaining necessary electronic protected health information during an emergency.
column47: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column2: Scenario: Physical Security and Technical Controls: The hospital uses electronic door locks for its server room. Kiosks are set to automatically lock the screen after a period of inactivity.
column5: The requirement to implement audit controls requires the use of hardware, software, and/or procedural mechanisms to:
column8: A. Track the movement of hardware devices within the facility.B. Record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use ePHI.C. Implement procedures for terminating workforce access upon resignation.D. Protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction.
column13: B. Record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use ePHI.
column24: Audit controls implement mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use electronic protected health information.
column47: Mechanisms to record and examine system activity involving ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Public Health and Professional Discretion: Dr. Adams treats an unemancipated minor who received counseling without parental consent. The minor asks not to disclose this to her parents. Dr. Adams also discovers a rare disease outbreak.
column5: Regarding the minor, Dr. Adams should treat the minor as the individual (and deny the parent access to that PHI) if:
column8: A. The parent is responsible for the payment for treatment.B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the rep.C. The parent signs an authorization to release the PHI.D. The minor turns 18 within the next 30 days.
column13: B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the rep.
column24: A minor has the authority to act as an individual if they consent to a service where no other consent is required by law and no personal rep is requested.
column47: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Public Health and Professional Discretion: Dr. Adams treats an unemancipated minor who received counseling without parental consent. The minor asks not to disclose this to her parents. Dr. Adams also discovers a rare disease outbreak.
column5: The disclosure of info about the communicable disease outbreak to the local public health authority is:
column8: A. A prohibited disclosure under all circumstances.B. A permitted disclosure for public health activities.C. A disclosure requiring prior patient authorization.D. Permitted only if required by a court order.
column13: B. A permitted disclosure for public health activities.
column24: Disclosure is permitted to a public health authority authorized by law to collect or receive such info for preventing or controlling disease.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates; OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Public Health and Professional Discretion: Dr. Adams treats an unemancipated minor who received counseling without parental consent. The minor asks not to disclose this to her parents. Dr. Adams also discovers a rare disease outbreak.
column5: If Dr. Adams needs to speak urgently to an incapacitated patient’s family member, the PHI disclosed must be:
column8: A. Directly relevant to the person’s involvement with the care or payment.B. The entire designated record set.C. Limited to the patient’s medical history.D. Only disclosed if the patient provided prior written consent.
column13: A. Directly relevant to the person’s involvement with the care or payment.
column24: If the individual is incapacitated, the provider may disclose PHI that is directly relevant to the person's involvement with the care or payment.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column47: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care; opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Public Health and Professional Discretion: Dr. Adams treats an unemancipated minor who received counseling without parental consent. The minor asks not to disclose this to her parents. Dr. Adams also discovers a rare disease outbreak.
column5: To meet the minimum necessary requirement for a public official's request, Dr. Adams may rely on the official’s representation that the info is:
column8: A. Protected by the Public Health Authority.B. The minimum necessary for the stated purpose(s).C. Required by law.D. Not subject to further re-identification.
column13: B. The minimum necessary for the stated purpose(s).
column24: A covered entity may rely, if reasonable under the circumstances, on a public official’s representation that the info requested is the minimum necessary.
column47: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary; reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Public Health and Professional Discretion: Dr. Adams treats an unemancipated minor who received counseling without parental consent. The minor asks not to disclose this to her parents. Dr. Adams also discovers a rare disease outbreak.
column5: When establishing a protocol for a patient’s relative to pick up a prescription, the provider makes what reasonable inference?
column8: A. The relative has full authority to make health care decisions.B. The disclosure is inconsistent with prior preferences.C. The patient does not object, as it is in their best interest.D. The pharmacist does not require additional patient authorization.
column13: C. The patient does not object, as it is in their best interest.
column24: A covered entity may use professional judgment to make reasonable inferences of the individual’s best interest in allowing a person to pick up filled prescriptions.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column47: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care; opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Requirements and BA Management: The CE hires a new data storage vendor classified as a Business Associate (BA). The management team must ensure the BAA is robust and understand the BA’s specific HIPAA obligations.
column6: The BAA must authorize termination of the contract by the Covered Entity if the CE determines that the BA has violated:
column7: A. Any term of the contract.B. A material term of the contract.C. The security training requirements.D. The Minimum Necessary requirements only.
column10: B. A material term of the contract.
column24: The contract must authorize termination by the covered entity if the CE determines that the BA has violated a material term of the contract.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Requirements and BA Management: The CE hires a new data storage vendor classified as a Business Associate (BA). The management team must ensure the BAA is robust and understand the BA’s specific HIPAA obligations.
column6: If the CE discovers a pattern of activity or practice by the BA that constitutes a material breach or violation, the CE must take reasonable steps to cure the breach and, if unsuccessful, must:
column7: A. Notify the Secretary (HHS).B. Report the problem to the media.C. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.D. Initiate the CMP process directly against the BA.
column10: C. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.
column24: If reasonable steps to cure the violation are unsuccessful, the CE must terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Requirements and BA Management: The CE hires a new data storage vendor classified as a Business Associate (BA). The management team must ensure the BAA is robust and understand the BA’s specific HIPAA obligations.
column6: The BAA must provide that the BA will make its internal practices, books, and records related to PHI use or disclosure available to whom for purposes of determining compliance?
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. The Secretary (HHS).C. The FBI.D. An Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).
column10: B. The Secretary (HHS).
column24: The BAA must require the BA to make its internal practices, books, and records relating to PHI available to the Secretary for purposes of determining the covered entity’s compliance.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Requirements and BA Management: The CE hires a new data storage vendor classified as a Business Associate (BA). The management team must ensure the BAA is robust and understand the BA’s specific HIPAA obligations.
column6: At the termination of the BAA, if feasible, the BA must perform which action regarding the PHI it received or created on behalf of the CE?
column7: A. Encrypt all remaining PHI.B. Archive all PHI for 6 years.C. Return or destroy all PHI maintained in any form and retain no copies.D. Transfer all PHI to a successor BA.
column10: C. Return or destroy all PHI maintained in any form and retain no copies.
column24: At termination, if feasible, the BA must return or destroy all PHI received from, or created on behalf of, the CE and retain no copies of such information.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Requirements and BA Management: The CE hires a new data storage vendor classified as a Business Associate (BA). The management team must ensure the BAA is robust and understand the BA’s specific HIPAA obligations.
column6: Under the Security Rule, a BA is generally liable for a Civil Money Penalty (CMP) for a violation based on the act or omission of any agent, including which downstream partner?
column7: A. The CE that hired the BA.B. The BA’s subcontractor.C. The Department of Defense.D. An Organized Health Care Arrangement (OHCA).
column10: B. The BA’s subcontractor.
column24: A business associate is liable for a CMP for a violation based on the act or omission of any agent of the business associate, including a workforce member or subcontractor, acting within the scope of the agency.
column47: Written contracts/arrangements requiring BAs and their subcontractors to safeguard ePHI and report security incidents and breaches.

column2: Scenario: Disclosure Requirements and Policy Implementation: Management reviews policies on PHI disclosures, including legal obligations, and ensures that their required Documentation standard is consistently met.
column6: Disclosure of PHI is required to an individual when requested under the right of access. What is the other instance where disclosure is required by the Secretary?
column7: A. To notify the public of a major breach.B. To investigate or determine the covered entity’s compliance with HIPAA.C. To provide protective services for the President.D. To provide technical assistance to the CE.
column10: B. To investigate or determine the covered entity’s compliance with HIPAA.
column24: Disclosures are required when requested under the right of access or accounting OR when required by the Secretary under Subpart C of Part 160 to investigate or determine compliance.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Disclosure Requirements and Policy Implementation: Management reviews policies on PHI disclosures, including legal obligations, and ensures that their required Documentation standard is consistently met.
column6: The term “Required by law” includes mandates contained in law that compel an entity to make a use or disclosure. Which of the following is an example of such a mandate?
column7: A. A request for marketing purposes.B. Medicare conditions of participation with respect to health care providers participating in the program.C. A request for minimum necessary information by another covered entity.D. An optional disclosure for public health activities.
column10: B. Medicare conditions of participation with respect to health care providers participating in the program.
column24: “Required by law” includes, but is not limited to, court orders, grand jury subpoenas, and Medicare conditions of participation with respect to health care providers participating in the program.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Disclosure Requirements and Policy Implementation: Management reviews policies on PHI disclosures, including legal obligations, and ensures that their required Documentation standard is consistently met.
column6: The Documentation standard requires the CE to maintain records in written or electronic form for at least six years. This includes documentation sufficient to meet the CE’s burden of proof under which rule?
column7: A. Security Rule.B. Privacy Rule.C. Breach Notification Rule.D. Transactions Rule.
column10: C. Breach Notification Rule.
column24: The CE must maintain documentation sufficient to meet its burden of proof under the Breach Notification Rule (§ 164.414(b)).
column47: Application of certain Privacy Rule administrative requirements to breach notification activities, and burden of proof to show notifications were made or not required.

column2: Scenario: Disclosure Requirements and Policy Implementation: Management reviews policies on PHI disclosures, including legal obligations, and ensures that their required Documentation standard is consistently met.
column6: A disclosure of PHI for remuneration is considered a “Sale of protected health information” unless the disclosure is for an exempted purpose, such as:
column7: A. For the proper management and administration of the BA.B. For fundraising purposes.C. For the creation of a Limited Data Set.D. For treatment and payment purposes.
column10: D. For treatment and payment purposes.
column24: Sale of PHI does not include disclosure for treatment and payment purposes pursuant to § 164.506(a).
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Disclosure Requirements and Policy Implementation: Management reviews policies on PHI disclosures, including legal obligations, and ensures that their required Documentation standard is consistently met.
column6: Adherence to the Flexibility of Approach means that if a CE or BA chooses to use security measures that allow it to reasonably implement standards, the entity must implement:
column7: A. Only technical measures.B. Any security measures.C. Only measures endorsed by NIST.D. Only measures explicitly required by HHS guidance.
column10: B. Any security measures.
column24: Covered entities and business associates may use any security measures that allow them to reasonably and appropriately implement the standards.
column47: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research and Security Incidents: Management oversees a research project and must respond to a security incident involving ePHI.
column6: To disclose PHI without authorization for a review preparatory to research, management must obtain representations that:
column7: A. The Institutional Review Board (IRB) waiver has been secured.B. The researcher will return or destroy the PHI at the end of the research.C. No PHI is to be removed from the covered entity by the researcher.D. The PHI is de-identified prior to review.
column10: C. No PHI is to be removed from the covered entity by the researcher.
column24: For reviews preparatory to research, the CE must obtain representations that use or disclosure is sought solely for review and no PHI is to be removed from the covered entity by the researcher.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research and Security Incidents: Management oversees a research project and must respond to a security incident involving ePHI.
column6: A security incident is the attempted or successful unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction of information or what other event?
column7: A. Interception of network traffic.B. Implementation of a new security control.C. Interference with system operations in an information system.D. Failure of a software patch.
column10: C. Interference with system operations in an information system.
column24: A security incident means the attempted or successful unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction of information or interference with system operations in an information system.
column47: Policies and procedures to prevent, detect, contain, and correct security violations, including risk analysis, risk management, sanctions, and activity review.

column2: Scenario: Research and Security Incidents: Management oversees a research project and must respond to a security incident involving ePHI.
column6: When must all members of the organization’s workforce receive training on policies and procedures related to PHI?
column7: A. Only when hired.B. By the compliance date, thereafter to new workforce members, and when functions are affected by a material change.C. Annually, regardless of changes.D. Only after a security incident has occurred.
column10: B. By the compliance date, thereafter to new workforce members, and when functions are affected by a material change.
column24: Training must be provided by the compliance date, thereafter to each new member within a reasonable time, and to members whose functions are affected by a material change.
column47: Training requirements for workforce on Privacy Rule and breach-related policies and documentation of that training.

column2: Scenario: Research and Security Incidents: Management oversees a research project and must respond to a security incident involving ePHI.
column6: The standard for Person or Entity Authentication requires implementing procedures to verify what?
column7: A. That the person or entity has paid their fees.B. That a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed.C. That the security controls comply with all addressable specifications.D. That the person is located within the facility.
column10: B. That a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed.
column24: Person or Entity Authentication requires implementing procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed.
column47: Verification that a person or entity seeking ePHI access is the one claimed.

column2: Scenario: Research and Security Incidents: Management oversees a research project and must respond to a security incident involving ePHI.
column6: The Minimum Necessary standard requires reasonable efforts to limit PHI to the minimum necessary for the purpose. This requirement does NOT apply to:
column7: A. Disclosure for Health Care Operations.B. Disclosure for Payment activities.C. Disclosure to the individual.D. Disclosures to an external accountant serving as a BA.
column10: C. Disclosure to the individual.
column24: The Minimum Necessary requirement does not apply to uses or disclosures made to the individual, as permitted under § 164.502(a)(1)(i) or required by § 164.524.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define role-based access.

column2: Scenario: Strategic Policy Decisions and Compliance Mandates: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column6: Management must consider the probability and criticality of potential risks to ePHI. This factor is weighed against:
column7: A. The size and complexity of the CE.B. The CE’s technical infrastructure.C. The costs of security measures.D. All of the above.
column10: D. All of the above.
column24: Decisions on security measures must take into account size, complexity, infrastructure, hardware/software capabilities, costs, and the probability/criticality of potential risks.
column47: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats.

column2: Scenario: Strategic Policy Decisions and Compliance Mandates: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column6: The security policy for granting workforce members access to ePHI must be consistent with the requirements of which other Security Rule provision?
column7: A. Contingency Plan standard.B. Subpart E (Privacy Rule).C. Physical Safeguards standard.D. Breach Notification Rule.
column10: B. Subpart E (Privacy Rule).
column24: Policies for authorizing access to ePHI must be consistent with the applicable requirements of Subpart E (Privacy Rule).
column47: Policies for authorizing access to ePHI, including managing access establishment/modification.

column2: Scenario: Strategic Policy Decisions and Compliance Mandates: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column6: The Security Awareness and Training standard requires providing periodic security updates known as:
column7: A. Security Reminders.B. Log-in Monitoring.C. Password Management.D. Protection from Malicious Software.
column10: A. Security Reminders.
column24: Security Reminders is the addressable implementation specification for periodic security updates under the Security Awareness and Training standard.
column47: Security awareness program: reminders, malicious software protection, login monitoring, password management.

column2: Scenario: Strategic Policy Decisions and Compliance Mandates: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column6: The Standard: Policies and procedures requires policies to be reasonably designed taking into account the CE/BA’s size and which other factor?
column7: A. The type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.B. The maximum number of individuals whose PHI is maintained.C. The minimum level of technical competence of the workforce.D. The geographical location of the headquarters.
column10: A. The type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.
column24: Policies and procedures must be reasonably designed, taking into account the size and the type of activities that relate to protected health information.
column47: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column2: Scenario: Strategic Policy Decisions and Compliance Mandates: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column6: If management decides to use Encryption for ePHI stored on laptops, this is classified as a(n):
column7: A. Required Administrative Safeguard.B. Required Technical Safeguard.C. Addressable Technical Safeguard.D. Required Physical Safeguard.
column10: C. Addressable Technical Safeguard.
column24: Encryption and Decryption is an addressable implementation specification under the Access Control standard.
column47: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column2: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Minimum Necessary: Management oversees a Group Health Plan (GHP) and needs to ensure PHI access between the GHP and the Plan Sponsor is compliant. They must also define policies for granting minimum necessary access to their own workforce.
column6: If the GHP discloses PHI to the Plan Sponsor, the plan documents must specifically restrict the Plan Sponsor from using the info for:
column7: A. Obtaining premium bids.B. Modifying or terminating the plan.C. Employment-related actions and decisions.D. Plan administration functions.
column10: C. Employment-related actions and decisions.
column24: The plan documents must restrict the Plan Sponsor from using or disclosing information for employment-related actions or decisions.
column47: Security obligations imposed on plan sponsors receiving ePHI from group health plans.

column2: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Minimum Necessary: Management oversees a Group Health Plan (GHP) and needs to ensure PHI access between the GHP and the Plan Sponsor is compliant. They must also define policies for granting minimum necessary access to their own workforce.
column6: When must the GHP disclose PHI to the Plan Sponsor (other than summary/enrollment info) only upon receipt of a certification from the Sponsor?
column7: A. After the Plan Sponsor agrees to obtain a BAA.B. After the Plan Sponsor certifies that plan documents have been amended to incorporate required provisions.C. After the Plan Sponsor agrees to destroy all PHI immediately.D. After the Plan Sponsor agrees to use the PHI only for treatment.
column10: B. After the Plan Sponsor certifies that plan documents have been amended to incorporate required provisions.
column24: The GHP will disclose PHI only upon receipt of a certification by the Plan Sponsor that the plan documents have been amended to incorporate specific required provisions.
column47: Security obligations imposed on plan sponsors receiving ePHI from group health plans.

column2: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Minimum Necessary: Management oversees a Group Health Plan (GHP) and needs to ensure PHI access between the GHP and the Plan Sponsor is compliant. They must also define policies for granting minimum necessary access to their own workforce.
column6: When documenting adequate separation between the GHP and Plan Sponsor, the plan documents must restrict access and use of PHI to:
column7: A. The entire Designated Record Set.B. The PHI of the GHP’s CEO.C. The Plan Administration Functions that the Plan Sponsor performs for the GHP.D. PHI required for health care operations only.
column10: C. The Plan Administration Functions that the Plan Sponsor performs for the GHP.
column24: The plan documents must restrict access and use by such authorized employees to the plan administration functions that the plan sponsor performs for the group health plan.
column47: Security obligations imposed on plan sponsors receiving ePHI from group health plans.

column2: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Minimum Necessary: Management oversees a Group Health Plan (GHP) and needs to ensure PHI access between the GHP and the Plan Sponsor is compliant. They must also define policies for granting minimum necessary access to their own workforce.
column6: For implementing Minimum Necessary uses, management must identify workforce persons needing access, the category of PHI needed, and:
column7: A. The security official responsible for the PHI.B. The training records for the person.C. Any conditions appropriate to such access.D. Whether the information is electronic or paper.
column10: C. Any conditions appropriate to such access.
column24: The CE must identify persons needing access, the category of PHI needed, and any conditions appropriate to such access.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define role-based access.

column2: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Minimum Necessary: Management oversees a Group Health Plan (GHP) and needs to ensure PHI access between the GHP and the Plan Sponsor is compliant. They must also define policies for granting minimum necessary access to their own workforce.
column6: When may the organization disclose or request an entire medical record?
column7: A. If the entire record is needed for TPO.B. If specifically justified as the amount that is reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose.C. Never, as the entire record always exceeds the minimum necessary rule.D. Only if required by law.
column10: B. If specifically justified as the amount that is reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose.
column24: A CE may not use, disclose, or request an entire medical record, except when specifically justified as the amount that is reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose.
column47: Prohibition on using, disclosing, or requesting entire medical records unless specifically justified as reasonably necessary.

column2: Scenario: Breach Liability and Enforcement Actions: A business associate (BA) informs the CE management of a breach affecting 450 individuals. The CE needs to prepare documentation for a potential OCR inquiry.
column6: Because the breach affected fewer than 500 individuals, the CE must notify the Secretary (HHS) of the breach no later than:
column7: A. 30 calendar days after discovery.B. 60 days after the end of each calendar year.C. Contemporaneously with notification to the individual.D. Within 15 business days of discovery.
column10: B. 60 days after the end of each calendar year.
column24: For breaches involving less than 500 individuals, the CE must maintain a log and notify the Secretary annually, no later than 60 days after the end of each calendar year.
column38: Notification to the Secretary of HHS
column47: Reporting to HHS for breaches affecting 500 or more individuals without unreasonable delay and annual log submission for smaller breaches.

column2: Scenario: Breach Liability and Enforcement Actions: A business associate (BA) informs the CE management of a breach affecting 450 individuals. The CE needs to prepare documentation for a potential OCR inquiry.
column6: If the CE rebuts the presumption of compromise, the CE carries the burden of proof for demonstrating this determination under which provision?
column7: A. Notification to individuals.B. Administrative requirements and burden of proof.C. Security incident procedures.D. Compliance reviews.
column10: B. Administrative requirements and burden of proof.
column24: The CE or BA shall have the burden of demonstrating that all notifications were made OR that the use or disclosure did not constitute a breach.
column47: Application of certain Privacy Rule administrative requirements to breach notification activities, and burden of proof.

column2: Scenario: Breach Liability and Enforcement Actions: A business associate (BA) informs the CE management of a breach affecting 450 individuals. The CE needs to prepare documentation for a potential OCR inquiry.
column6: During an OCR review, if exigent circumstances exist (e.g., documents may be hidden), access must be permitted:
column7: A. Only with a warrant.B. Only with 24 hours’ notice.C. At any time and without notice.D. Only if the disclosure relates to TPO.
column10: C. At any time and without notice.
column24: If the Secretary determines that exigent circumstances exist, such as when documents may be hidden or destroyed, the CE/BA must permit access at any time and without notice.
column47: Requirement to provide a process to receive complaints about privacy/breach compliance and document all complaints.

column2: Scenario: Breach Liability and Enforcement Actions: A business associate (BA) informs the CE management of a breach affecting 450 individuals. The CE needs to prepare documentation for a potential OCR inquiry.
column6: If an LEO states in writing that a Breach notification would impede a criminal investigation, the CE/BA must delay the notification:
column7: A. For the time period specified by the official.B. For no longer than 30 days.C. Until the individual provides written consent.D. Indefinitely, until the case is closed.
column10: A. For the time period specified by the official.
column24: If the statement is in writing and specifies the time for which a delay is required, the entity must delay notification for the time period specified by the official.
column47: Permissible delay of notifications if a law-enforcement official determines notice would impede an investigation.

column2: Scenario: Breach Liability and Enforcement Actions: A business associate (BA) informs the CE management of a breach affecting 450 individuals. The CE needs to prepare documentation for a potential OCR inquiry.
column6: The antiretaliation standard protects a workforce member from retaliation if they oppose an unlawful act, provided they disclose PHI:
column7: A. Only to a court or administrative tribunal.B. Not in violation of Subpart E (Privacy Rule).C. In violation of the Minimum Necessary standard.D. Only to a public health authority.
column10: B. Not in violation of Subpart E (Privacy Rule).
column24: Retaliation is prohibited for opposing any act made unlawful by this subchapter, provided the opposition does not involve a disclosure of PHI in violation of Subpart E.
column47: Prohibition on intimidating or retaliatory acts against individuals for exercising HIPAA rights or filing complaints.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Compliance and Documentation: Management must ensure its documentation standards are met and understand key aspects of organizational risk.
column6: The minimum retention period for records, such as an accounting of disclosures or security policies, is:
column7: A. 3 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. Until the data is de-identified.
column10: B. 6 years.
column24: Documentation required by § 164.316 (Security) and § 164.530 (Privacy) must be retained for six years from the date of its creation or when it last was in effect.
column47: Maintaining written/electronic security policies, procedures, and other documentation for six years.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Compliance and Documentation: Management must ensure its documentation standards are met and understand key aspects of organizational risk.
column6: The standard of Workstation Security requires implementing physical safeguards for all workstations that access ePHI to:
column7: A. Encrypt the hard drive.B. To restrict access to authorized users.C. To install anti-malware software.D. To implement an automatic logoff feature.
column10: B. To restrict access to authorized users.
column24: Workstation Security requires implementing physical safeguards for all workstations that access ePHI, to restrict access to authorized users.
column47: Physical safeguards for workstations to restrict access to authorized users.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Compliance and Documentation: Management must ensure its documentation standards are met and understand key aspects of organizational risk.
column6: If a CE elects to limit permitted uses or disclosures in its Notice of Privacy Practices (NPP), the CE:
column7: A. Must describe its more limited uses in its NPP.B. May include a statement regarding its limited uses in its NPP, as an optional element.C. Must obtain authorization for any use that exceeds its stated limitation.D. Must immediately report the policy to the Secretary.
column10: B. May include a statement regarding its limited uses in its NPP, as an optional element.
column24: If a CE elects to limit permitted uses or disclosures, the CE may describe its more limited uses or disclosures in its NPP.
column47: Required NPP content: permitted uses/disclosures, rights, duties, etc.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Compliance and Documentation: Management must ensure its documentation standards are met and understand key aspects of organizational risk.
column6: Which statement accurately defines Willful Neglect?
column7: A. An act the CE knew or should have known violated a provision, but without willful neglect.B. Conscious, intentional failure or reckless indifference to the obligation to comply.C. An act that occurred due to circumstances making it unreasonable to comply.D. An action that is corrected immediately upon discovery.
column10: B. Conscious, intentional failure or reckless indifference to the obligation to comply.
column24: Willful neglect means conscious, intentional failure or reckless indifference to the obligation to comply with the administrative simplification provision violated.
column47: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column2: Scenario: Organizational Compliance and Documentation: Management must ensure its documentation standards are met and understand key aspects of organizational risk.
column6: Assessing the criticality of specific applications and data in support of other contingency plan components is classified as:
column7: A. Required.B. Mandatory.C. Addressable.D. Technical.
column10: C. Addressable.
column24: Applications and Data Criticality Analysis is an addressable implementation specification under the Contingency Plan standard.
column47: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergency mode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column2: Scenario: Hybrid Entity and Disclosure Control: The CE operates as a Hybrid Entity. Management wants to ensure that internal PHI movement and external disclosures are tightly controlled.
column6: The Privacy Official implements privacy policies. Which additional designation must the CE document regarding complaints?
column7: A. A security auditor monitoring PHI access.B. A contact person or office responsible for receiving complaints.C. A chief enforcement officer.D. A compliance lawyer responsible for all CMPs.
column10: B. A contact person or office responsible for receiving complaints.
column24: The CE must designate a privacy official and a contact person or office who is responsible for receiving complaints.
column47: Designation of a privacy official and a contact person/office for complaints and NPP inquiries.

column2: Scenario: Hybrid Entity and Disclosure Control: The CE operates as a Hybrid Entity. Management wants to ensure that internal PHI movement and external disclosures are tightly controlled.
column6: If the Hybrid Entity discloses ePHI to a non-healthcare component, it must protect that ePHI to the same extent as if the components were:
column7: A. Separate and distinct legal entities.B. Affiliated covered entities.C. Business associates.D. In a disaster relief effort.
column10: A. Separate and distinct legal entities.
column24: The HCC must protect ePHI with respect to another component to the same extent required under Subpart C if the components were separate and distinct legal entities.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations.

column2: Scenario: Hybrid Entity and Disclosure Control: The CE operates as a Hybrid Entity. Management wants to ensure that internal PHI movement and external disclosures are tightly controlled.
column6: When disclosing PHI to public officials where authorization is not required, management may rely on the official’s representation if the reliance is:
column7: A. Documented as an organizational requirement.B. Reasonable under the circumstances.C. Limited to demographic information.D. Approved by the Privacy Official.
column10: B. Reasonable under the circumstances.
column24: A CE may rely, if such reliance is reasonable under the circumstances, on a public official’s representation that the requested information is the minimum necessary.
column47: Policies to limit disclosures to the minimum necessary; reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Hybrid Entity and Disclosure Control: The CE operates as a Hybrid Entity. Management wants to ensure that internal PHI movement and external disclosures are tightly controlled.
column6: Management is considering creating a Limited Data Set (LDS). The LDS may only be used or disclosed for the purposes of:
column7: A. Treatment, payment, or research.B. Research, marketing, or payment.C. Research, public health, or health care operations.D. Fundraising, legal services, or TPO.
column10: C. Research, public health, or health care operations.
column24: A limited data set may be used or disclosed only for the purposes of research, public health, or health care operations.
column38: Limited data sets and data use agreements
column47: Conditions for using/disclosing limited data sets and required contents of data use agreements.

column2: Scenario: Hybrid Entity and Disclosure Control: The CE operates as a Hybrid Entity. Management wants to ensure that internal PHI movement and external disclosures are tightly controlled.
column6: External parties must verify their identity. This requirement is excused when the CE relies on:
column7: A. Professional judgment in disclosures for involvement in care or good faith belief in serious threats.B. The completion of a BAA.C. The use of an administrative subpoena.D. The Minimum Necessary rule being satisfied.
column10: A. Professional judgment in disclosures for involvement in care or good faith belief in serious threats.
column24: Verification requirements are met if the CE relies on professional judgment in § 164.510 disclosures or acts on a good faith belief in § 164.512(j) (serious threat).
column47: Duty to verify identity/authority of requestors before disclosing PHI and to document verification.

column2: Scenario: BAA, Permitted Use, and Minimum Necessary: A Business Associate (BA) processes claims for CE X. The BAA permits data aggregation services. Alice, a BA employee, needs to review claims fields but accesses Ms. Smith’s entire therapy notes.
column6: A BA’s permitted uses and disclosures of PHI are primarily defined by which document or mandate?
column7: A. The BA’s internal operations manual.B. The Privacy Rule (§ 164.502(a)(1)).C. The Business Associate Contract (BAA) or as required by law.D. The BA’s status as a data aggregation provider.
column10: C. The Business Associate Contract (BAA) or as required by law.
column24: A business associate may use or disclose PHI only as permitted or required by its BAA or as required by law.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures.

column2: Scenario: BAA, Permitted Use, and Minimum Necessary: A Business Associate (BA) processes claims for CE X. The BAA permits data aggregation services. Alice, a BA employee, needs to review claims fields but accesses Ms. Smith’s entire therapy notes.
column6: If the BAA permits, your organization (the BA) may provide data aggregation services relating to which activities of the Covered Entity (CE)?
column7: A. Marketing activities.B. Fundraising activities.C. Health care operations.D. Law enforcement activities.
column10: C. Health care operations.
column24: The BAA may permit the BA to provide data aggregation services relating to the health care operations of the covered entity.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column2: Scenario: BAA, Permitted Use, and Minimum Necessary: A Business Associate (BA) processes claims for CE X. The BAA permits data aggregation services. Alice, a BA employee, needs to review claims fields but accesses Ms. Smith’s entire therapy notes.
column6: Alice accesses Ms. Smith’s entire medical record for claims processing, even though only billing codes are needed. This violates which core standard?
column7: A. The Authorization Standard.B. The Integrity Standard.C. The Minimum Necessary Standard.D. The Confidential Communications Standard.
column10: C. The Minimum Necessary Standard.
column24: When using, disclosing, or requesting PHI, a BA must make reasonable efforts to limit information to the minimum necessary to accomplish the purpose.
column47: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define role-based access.

column2: Scenario: BAA, Permitted Use, and Minimum Necessary: A Business Associate (BA) processes claims for CE X. The BAA permits data aggregation services. Alice, a BA employee, needs to review claims fields but accesses Ms. Smith’s entire therapy notes.
column6: Alice wants to use client PHI for the BA’s own internal marketing strategy unrelated to CE services. This use is:
column7: A. Permitted if the BA applies the Minimum Necessary rule.B. Permitted if the information is used for the BA’s own management.C. Prohibited unless the BA obtains a specific patient authorization.D. Permitted if the patient signed the CE’s NPP.
column10: C. Prohibited unless the BA obtains a specific patient authorization.
column24: Except for specific exemptions, a CE or BA may not sell or use PHI for marketing without an authorization.
column47: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: BAA, Permitted Use, and Minimum Necessary: A Business Associate (BA) processes claims for CE X. The BAA permits data aggregation services. Alice, a BA employee, needs to review claims fields but accesses Ms. Smith’s entire therapy notes.
column6: If the BAA is terminated, what action must the contract require the BA to take concerning the PHI maintained on behalf of the CE, if feasible?
column7: A. Retain copies for six years for audit purposes.B. Only use the PHI for the BA’s own proper management.C. Return or destroy all PHI maintained in any form and retain no copies.D. Transfer the PHI only to the Secretary of HHS.
column10: C. Return or destroy all PHI maintained in any form and retain no copies.
column24: The BAA must require the BA to return or destroy all PHI maintained in any form at termination, if feasible, and retain no copies.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column2: Scenario: Subcontractors and Downstream Liability: Your BA organization contracts with Subcontractor Y for data archival. Subcontractor Y stores data on its cloud. A BA employee notices Subcontractor Y is violating security standards.
column6: Before engaging Subcontractor Y, what must your organization (the BA) obtain from Y?
column7: A. A formal risk analysis report.B. Satisfactory assurances that the subcontractor will appropriately safeguard the information.C. A complete list of all CE clients.D. Written permission from the CE client.
column10: B. Satisfactory assurances that the subcontractor will appropriately safeguard the information.
column24: A BA may permit a subcontractor BA to handle PHI only if the BA obtains satisfactory assurances that the subcontractor will appropriately safeguard the info.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column2: Scenario: Subcontractors and Downstream Liability: Your BA organization contracts with Subcontractor Y for data archival. Subcontractor Y stores data on its cloud. A BA employee notices Subcontractor Y is violating security standards.
column6: If the BA knew of a pattern of material breach by Subcontractor Y, and steps to cure were unsuccessful, what must the BA do?
column7: A. Notify the CE and the Secretary of the violation.B. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.C. Conduct a new risk analysis.D. Provide additional training to Subcontractor Y’s workforce.
column10: B. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.
column24: A BA must take reasonable steps to cure a material breach by a subcontractor and, if unsuccessful, terminate the contract, if feasible.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column2: Scenario: Subcontractors and Downstream Liability: Your BA organization contracts with Subcontractor Y for data archival. Subcontractor Y stores data on its cloud. A BA employee notices Subcontractor Y is violating security standards.
column6: The BA must ensure that Subcontractor Y agrees to comply with which HIPAA subpart for electronic PHI?
column7: A. Subpart D (Breach Notification).B. Subpart E (Privacy).C. Subpart C (Security Standards).D. Subpart A (General Provisions).
column10: C. Subpart C (Security Standards).
column24: The contract must provide that the subcontractor agrees to comply with the applicable requirements of Subpart C (Security Rules).
column47: Written contracts/arrangements requiring BAs and their subcontractors to safeguard ePHI.

column2: Scenario: Subcontractors and Downstream Liability: Your BA organization contracts with Subcontractor Y for data archival. Subcontractor Y stores data on its cloud. A BA employee notices Subcontractor Y is violating security standards.
column6: If Subcontractor Y discloses PHI for its own management (per BAA), Y must obtain reasonable assurances that the recipient will notify Y of:
column7: A. The full audit log review results.B. Any instances in which the confidentiality of the info has been breached.C. Changes in Subcontractor Y’s IT infrastructure.D. Completion of HIPAA training.
column10: B. Any instances in which the confidentiality of the info has been breached.
column24: When disclosing PHI for its own management, the BA must obtain assurances of confidentiality and that the recipient will notify the BA of any confidentiality breaches.
column47: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column2: Scenario: Subcontractors and Downstream Liability: Your BA organization contracts with Subcontractor Y for data archival. Subcontractor Y stores data on its cloud. A BA employee notices Subcontractor Y is violating security standards.
column6: If Subcontractor Y fails to protect ePHI, who is primarily liable for a Civil Money Penalty (CMP) for that violation under Federal law?
column7: A. Only the CE.B. Only the workforce member responsible.C. The BA, in addition to the subcontractor itself.D. Only the Privacy Official.
column10: C. The BA, in addition to the subcontractor itself.
column24: A BA is liable for a CMP for a violation based on the act or omission of any agent (subcontractor), acting within the scope of agency.
column47: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column2: Scenario: Whistleblowers and Patient Safety: A workforce member believes in good faith that the clinic is engaging in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or potentially endangers patients. The member decides to disclose PHI to an attorney to determine legal options.
column5: If a workforce member discloses PHI to an attorney under these circumstances, this disclosure:
column7: A. Is a violation of the Privacy Rule.B. Requires prior patient authorization.C. Is protected under the whistleblower provisions.D. Is permitted only if the disclosure is made to the media.
column10: C. Is protected under the whistleblower provisions.
column24: A covered entity is not considered to have violated the Privacy Rule if a workforce member discloses PHI to an attorney to determine legal options regarding conduct believed in good faith to be unlawful or dangerous,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Whistleblowers and Patient Safety: A workforce member believes in good faith that the clinic is engaging in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or potentially endangers patients. The member decides to disclose PHI to an attorney to determine legal options.
column5: To qualify for whistleblower protection when disclosing to a health oversight agency, the workforce member must believe in good faith that the entity:
column7: A. Failed to pay overtime wages.B. Is engaging in conduct that violates clinical standards or endangers the public.C. Has not updated its Notice of Privacy Practices.D. Is using outdated encryption software.
column10: B. Is engaging in conduct that violates clinical standards or endangers the public.
column24: The disclosure is permitted if the member believes the entity has engaged in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or endangers patients, workers, or the public,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Whistleblowers and Patient Safety: A workforce member believes in good faith that the clinic is engaging in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or potentially endangers patients. The member decides to disclose PHI to an attorney to determine legal options.
column5: HIPAA prohibits an organization from taking which action against a member of the workforce who files a complaint or reports a violation in good faith?
column7: A. Mandatory retraining.B. Performance reviews.C. Intimidating or retaliatory acts.D. Internal audits of their access logs.
column10: C. Intimidating or retaliatory acts.
column24: A covered entity may not intimidate, threaten, coerce, discriminate against, or take other retaliatory action against any individual for exercising any right or participating in any process provided for by HIPAA,.
column41: Prohibition on intimidating or retaliatory acts against individuals for exercising HIPAA rights or filing complaints.

column2: Scenario: Whistleblowers and Patient Safety: A workforce member believes in good faith that the clinic is engaging in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or potentially endangers patients. The member decides to disclose PHI to an attorney to determine legal options.
column5: If an employee believes their privacy rights were violated and brings the concern to the Privacy Official, the organization's primary obligation is to:
column7: A. Immediately terminate the involved staff.B. Offer a financial settlement.C. Ensure no retaliation and investigate the concern.D. Wait for an OCR subpoena before acting.
column10: C. Ensure no retaliation and investigate the concern.
column24: The organization must provide a process for complaints, document all dispositions, and refrain from any retaliatory acts against the complainant,,.
column41: Requirement to provide a process to receive complaints about privacy/breach compliance and document all complaints and dispositions.

column2: Scenario: Whistleblowers and Patient Safety: A workforce member believes in good faith that the clinic is engaging in conduct that is unlawful, violates professional standards, or potentially endangers patients. The member decides to disclose PHI to an attorney to determine legal options.
column5: The whistleblower provision protecting disclosures to an attorney is intended to allow a workforce member to:
column7: A. Sell the information for legal profit.B. Determine their legal options regarding the suspected misconduct.C. Publicly leak information to news reporters.D. Bypass the organization's internal compliance officer.
column10: B. Determine their legal options regarding the suspected misconduct.
column24: The disclosure is specifically permitted to an attorney for the purpose of determining the legal options of the workforce member regarding the suspected unlawful conduct,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research Protocol Review: A researcher requests access to PHI solely to review records necessary to prepare a research protocol. No PHI will be removed from the organization's premises during this review.
column5: To disclose PHI to the researcher for this purpose without an individual authorization, the organization must obtain representations that:
column7: A. The PHI will be destroyed after the review.B. The review is for payment purposes.C. No PHI is to be removed from the covered entity by the researcher.D. The researcher has a valid BAA with the clinic.
column10: C. No PHI is to be removed from the covered entity by the researcher.
column24: For reviews preparatory to research, the entity must obtain representations that the use is sought solely for the protocol and no PHI will be removed from the entity,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research Protocol Review: A researcher requests access to PHI solely to review records necessary to prepare a research protocol. No PHI will be removed from the organization's premises during this review.
column5: Which body must provide documentation of an alteration to or waiver of the individual authorization for a larger research study that goes beyond a preparatory review?
column7: A. The CEO of the clinic.B. An Institutional Review Board (IRB) or a Privacy Board.C. The local law enforcement agency.D. The billing department.
column10: B. An Institutional Review Board (IRB) or a Privacy Board.
column24: A covered entity may use or disclose PHI for research if it obtains documentation that a waiver of authorization has been approved by an IRB or a Privacy Board,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research Protocol Review: A researcher requests access to PHI solely to review records necessary to prepare a research protocol. No PHI will be removed from the organization's premises during this review.
column5: Documentation of a waiver approval for research must include a statement that the IRB or Privacy Board has determined the research involves:
column7: A. High financial risk to the entity.B. No more than a minimal risk to the privacy of individuals.C. Only deceased individuals' information.D. Only psychotherapy notes.
column10: B. No more than a minimal risk to the privacy of individuals.
column24: The IRB or Privacy Board must determine that the use of PHI involves no more than a minimal risk to privacy based on an adequate plan to protect identifiers,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research Protocol Review: A researcher requests access to PHI solely to review records necessary to prepare a research protocol. No PHI will be removed from the organization's premises during this review.
column5: If a researcher seeks PHI specifically for research on deceased individuals, the covered entity must obtain:
column7: A. A court order signed by a judge.B. Written authorization from the deceased's next of kin.C. Representation that the PHI is necessary for the research and documentation of death if requested.D. A BAA signed by the researcher.
column10: C. Representation that the PHI is necessary for the research and documentation of death if requested.
column24: For research on decedents, the entity must obtain representations that the use is solely for that purpose and the PHI is necessary for the research,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Research Protocol Review: A researcher requests access to PHI solely to review records necessary to prepare a research protocol. No PHI will be removed from the organization's premises during this review.
column5: When disclosing PHI to a researcher for research purposes (including preparatory reviews), the Minimum Necessary standard:
column7: A. Does not apply.B. Applies only to the researchers themselves.C. Applies, but the entity may rely on the researcher's representations or the IRB's documentation.D. Requires the removal of all 18 identifiers.
column10: C. Applies, but the entity may rely on the researcher's representations or the IRB's documentation.
column24: The organization may rely on representations or documentation that comply with research requirements as meeting the Minimum Necessary standard,.
column41: Policies to limit routine and nonroutine disclosures to the minimum necessary: reliance rules for certain requestors.

column2: Scenario: Litigation and Subpoenas: A covered entity receives a subpoena for a patient's medical records for use in a civil case. The subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, and the patient has not provided a written authorization.
column5: Before disclosing the PHI in response to the subpoena, the organization must receive satisfactory assurance that the party seeking the info has:
column7: A. Paid the reasonable, cost-based fee.B. Provided notice to the individual or made reasonable efforts to secure a qualified protective order.C. Obtained a waiver from the Secretary of HHS.D. Certified that the information is relevant to public health.
column10: B. Provided notice to the individual or made reasonable efforts to secure a qualified protective order.
column24: If a subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, the entity must receive satisfactory assurance of notice to the individual or efforts to secure a protective order,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Litigation and Subpoenas: A covered entity receives a subpoena for a patient's medical records for use in a civil case. The subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, and the patient has not provided a written authorization.
column5: What constitutes "satisfactory assurance" that an individual was notified of a records request in a lawsuit?
column7: A. A verbal confirmation from the requesting attorney.B. A copy of the lawsuit's initial filing document.C. A written statement and documentation that a good faith attempt was made to provide notice.D. A signed waiver from the individual's employer.
column10: C. A written statement and documentation that a good faith attempt was made to provide notice.
column24: Satisfactory assurance includes a written statement demonstrating that a good faith attempt was made to provide notice to the individual at their last known address,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Litigation and Subpoenas: A covered entity receives a subpoena for a patient's medical records for use in a civil case. The subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, and the patient has not provided a written authorization.
column5: A "qualified protective order" (QPO) must require the return to the covered entity or the destruction of the PHI at the:
column7: A. End of the calendar year.B. End of the litigation or proceeding.C. Time the records are six years old.D. Discretion of the court reporter.
column10: B. End of the litigation or proceeding.
column24: A QPO must require the return or destruction of the PHI (including all copies made) at the conclusion of the litigation or proceeding,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Litigation and Subpoenas: A covered entity receives a subpoena for a patient's medical records for use in a civil case. The subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, and the patient has not provided a written authorization.
column5: If a covered entity discloses PHI in response to an order of a court or administrative tribunal, the entity must disclose:
column7: A. The entire medical record.B. Only the information expressly authorized by the order.C. Only demographic information.D. All records created within the last six years.
column10: B. Only the information expressly authorized by the order.
column24: The covered entity must disclose only the protected health information that is expressly authorized by the court order,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Litigation and Subpoenas: A covered entity receives a subpoena for a patient's medical records for use in a civil case. The subpoena is not accompanied by a court order, and the patient has not provided a written authorization.
column5: When litigation involves the discovery of communications between doctors and patients about a diagnosis, which privacy principle still applies to limit the scope?
column7: A. The Preemption Standard.B. The Minimum Necessary Standard.C. The De-identification safe harbor.D. The Right of Access timeline.
column10: B. The Minimum Necessary Standard.
column24: Even in litigation, the organization should provide only the PHI that directly responds to the request, applying the minimum necessary principle,.
column41: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column2: Scenario: De-identification Standards: A startup application collects PHI from 100 patients. A researcher requests a dataset for a study. The startup hires an expert to de-identify the PHI. Later, the researcher manages to re-identify some patients using external data.
column5: To determine that health information is NOT individually identifiable using the "Expert Determination" method, the expert must:
column7: A. Sign a BAA with the researcher.B. Remove all 18 specified identifiers.C. Determine that the risk of re-identification is very small.D. Encrypt the data with a key held only by the clinic.
column10: C. Determine that the risk of re-identification is very small.
column24: Under the expert determination method, a person with appropriate knowledge determines that the risk is very small that the info could be used to identify an individual,,.
column41: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column2: Scenario: De-identification Standards: A startup application collects PHI from 100 patients. A researcher requests a dataset for a study. The startup hires an expert to de-identify the PHI. Later, the researcher manages to re-identify some patients using external data.
column5: Under the "Safe Harbor" method of de-identification, which geographic element must be removed?
column7: A. The state of residence.B. The initial three digits of a ZIP code if the unit contains more than 20,000 people.C. All geographic subdivisions smaller than a State (e.g., street address, city, precinct).D. Only the full street address.
column10: C. All geographic subdivisions smaller than a State (e.g., street address, city, precinct).
column24: The safe harbor method requires removal of all geographic subdivisions smaller than a state, with limited exceptions for certain ZIP code populations,.
column41: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column2: Scenario: De-identification Standards: A startup application collects PHI from 100 patients. A researcher requests a dataset for a study. The startup hires an expert to de-identify the PHI. Later, the researcher manages to re-identify some patients using external data.
column5: Which of the following is an identifier that must be removed under the safe harbor method for information to be considered de-identified?
column7: A. Year of birth.B. Full-face photographic images and any comparable images.C. The name of the treating facility.D. The diagnosis code.
column10: B. Full-face photographic images and any comparable images.
column24: The safe harbor standard requires removal of 18 identifiers, including full-face photos and comparable images,.
column41: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column2: Scenario: De-identification Standards: A startup application collects PHI from 100 patients. A researcher requests a dataset for a study. The startup hires an expert to de-identify the PHI. Later, the researcher manages to re-identify some patients using external data.
column5: If the startup properly de-identified the data per § 164.514, and the researcher later re-identified individuals using external data, is the startup liable under HIPAA?
column7: A. Yes, the re-identification proves de-identification failed.B. No, properly de-identified data is no longer PHI and researcher misuse is not the startup's liability.C. Yes, because a BAA was not signed by the researcher.D. No, provided the researcher is a health care provider.
column10: B. No, properly de-identified data is no longer PHI and researcher misuse is not the startup's liability.
column24: Once data is properly de-identified, it is no longer PHI and HIPAA does not apply: re-identification by an external party is not the original entity's liability,.
column41: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column2: Scenario: De-identification Standards: A startup application collects PHI from 100 patients. A researcher requests a dataset for a study. The startup hires an expert to de-identify the PHI. Later, the researcher manages to re-identify some patients using external data.
column5: If an organization assigns a code to allow de-identified info to be re-identified by the organization, the code must not:
column7: A. Be alphanumeric.B. Be derived from or related to information about the individual.C. Be stored for more than six months.D. Be shared with the Privacy Official.
column10: B. Be derived from or related to information about the individual.
column24: A code for re-identification must not be derived from info about the individual and must not be capable of being translated to identify the individual,.
column41: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory Disclosures: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. A day later, her adult daughter calls asking for Ms. Harper's specific medical prognosis.
column5: Which information may the clinic disclose to the daughter from the directory if she asks for Ms. Harper by name?
column7: A. Name, location, condition in general terms, and religious affiliation.B. Name, prognosis, and detailed vitals.C. Name, location, and condition in general terms, but not religious affiliation.D. Only the patient's room number.
column10: C. Name, location, and condition in general terms, but not religious affiliation.
column24: A provider may disclose directory info (name, location, condition) to persons asking by name, but religious affiliation is excluded for non-clergy,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory Disclosures: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. A day later, her adult daughter calls asking for Ms. Harper's specific medical prognosis.
column5: Under what condition is a provider allowed to disclose a patient's religious affiliation to a member of the clergy?
