column7: A. Only if the patient provides written authorization.B. Only if the clergy member asks for the patient by name.C. Disclosures to clergy for directory purposes may include religious affiliation.D. Disclosures to clergy are prohibited for all directory information.
column10: C. Disclosures to clergy for directory purposes may include religious affiliation.
column24: A healthcare provider may disclose the permitted directory information, including religious affiliation, specifically to members of the clergy,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory Disclosures: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. A day later, her adult daughter calls asking for Ms. Harper's specific medical prognosis.
column5: If an individual is incapacitated (emergency), the provider may include them in the directory if the disclosure is consistent with prior preferences and:
column7: A. The individual's primary care physician authorizes it.B. In the individual's best interest as determined by the provider's professional judgment.C. The individual is a minor.D. A court order is obtained.
column10: B. In the individual's best interest as determined by the provider's professional judgment.
column24: In emergency circumstances where an opportunity to object cannot be provided, the provider may disclose directory info if it is in the individual's best interest,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory Disclosures: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. A day later, her adult daughter calls asking for Ms. Harper's specific medical prognosis.
column5: When a patient is incapacitated, a provider may disclose PHI to a relative involved in the patient's care if the PHI is:
column7: A. The entire medical record.B. Directly relevant to the person's involvement with the individual's care or payment.C. Limited to name and room number.D. Required for health oversight activities.
column10: B. Directly relevant to the person's involvement with the individual's care or payment.
column24: If the individual is incapacitated, the provider may disclose PHI directly relevant to the person's involvement with the care or payment,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Facility Directory Disclosures: Ms. Harper is admitted and agrees to be listed in the facility directory. A day later, her adult daughter calls asking for Ms. Harper's specific medical prognosis.
column5: Before including a patient in a directory, a provider MUST:
column7: A. Obtain a signed HIPAA authorization.B. Inform the individual and provide an opportunity to restrict or prohibit the disclosure.C. Perform a risk analysis of the directory database.D. Notify the patient's health plan.
column10: B. Inform the individual and provide an opportunity to restrict or prohibit the disclosure.
column24: Providers must inform individuals of the PHI included in a directory and provide the opportunity to object or restrict the use,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Deceased Individuals and Executors: Ms. Finch passes away in a medical facility. Her adult son, who is the legal executor of her estate, requests a complete copy of her medical records.
column5: How long must the medical facility continue to protect Ms. Finch's PHI under the Privacy Rule after her death?
column7: A. For 6 years from the date of her death.B. For 10 years after her death.C. For 50 years following the death of the individual.D. Protection ends immediately upon death.
column10: C. For 50 years following the death of the individual.
column24: A covered entity must comply with Privacy Rule requirements regarding the PHI of a deceased individual for 50 years following their death,,.
column41: Obligation to protect PHI of deceased individuals for 50 years: OCR tests related policies and sample cases.

column2: Scenario: Deceased Individuals and Executors: Ms. Finch passes away in a medical facility. Her adult son, who is the legal executor of her estate, requests a complete copy of her medical records.
column5: Why must the provider treat Ms. Finch's executor as "the individual" for the purpose of granting access to her medical records?
column7: A. The executor is a family member.B. The executor has authority under law to act on behalf of the deceased individual or the estate.C. The executor has a medical power of attorney.D. The PHI is needed for public health activities.
column10: B. The executor has authority under law to act on behalf of the deceased individual or the estate.
column24: If a person has authority under law to act on behalf of a deceased individual or their estate, the entity must treat them as a personal representative,,.
column41: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Deceased Individuals and Executors: Ms. Finch passes away in a medical facility. Her adult son, who is the legal executor of her estate, requests a complete copy of her medical records.
column5: The provider may disclose PHI relevant to Ms. Finch's care to her family members involved prior to her death, UNLESS:
column7: A. The family member is not the legal executor.B. The disclosure is inconsistent with any known prior expressed preference of the deceased.C. The PHI is in electronic form.D. The disclosure is for healthcare operations.
column10: B. The disclosure is inconsistent with any known prior expressed preference of the deceased.
column24: Disclosure to involved family/persons is permitted after death unless inconsistent with the individual's prior expressed preference known to the entity,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Deceased Individuals and Executors: Ms. Finch passes away in a medical facility. Her adult son, who is the legal executor of her estate, requests a complete copy of her medical records.
column5: If a coroner or medical examiner requests PHI regarding Ms. Finch, the provider is permitted to disclose it for:
column7: A. Determining the cause of death or other duties authorized by law.B. Marketing funeral services.C. Billing the estate for previous services.D. Creating a limited data set for research.
column10: A. Determining the cause of death or other duties authorized by law.
column24: Disclosures to coroners or medical examiners are permitted for identifying a deceased person, determining cause of death, or other legal duties,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Deceased Individuals and Executors: Ms. Finch passes away in a medical facility. Her adult son, who is the legal executor of her estate, requests a complete copy of her medical records.
column5: To notify a deceased individual's next of kin about their death, a provider:
column7: A. Must obtain written authorization from a judge.B. May use or disclose PHI for such notification purposes.C. Is prohibited from using PHI for notification after death.D. Must first notify the Secretary of HHS.
column10: B. May use or disclose PHI for such notification purposes.
column24: A covered entity may use or disclose PHI to notify a family member, personal representative, or involved person of the individual's death,.
column38: Uses and disclosures requiring an opportunity for the individual to agree or to object
column41: Permitted uses/disclosures for facility directories and for involvement in the individual's care: opportunity to agree or object.

column2: Scenario: Minors and Privacy: A teenage patient (unemancipated minor) consents to medical counseling where state law allows her to do so without parental consent. She asks the provider not to disclose these details to her parents.
column5: Under which condition must the provider treat the minor (and not the parent) as the "individual" regarding the PHI for that service?
column7: A. The minor pays for the service out-of-pocket.B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the representative.C. The parent agrees in writing to waive their access rights.D. The minor is at least 16 years old.
column10: B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the representative.
column24: A minor has authority to act as an individual if they consent to a service where no other consent is required by law and no personal rep is requested,,.
column41: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Minors and Privacy: A teenage patient (unemancipated minor) consents to medical counseling where state law allows her to do so without parental consent. She asks the provider not to disclose these details to her parents.
column5: If the provider reasonably believes the parent or guardian may subject the minor to abuse or neglect, the provider:
column7: A. Must still grant the parent access to the PHI.B. May elect not to treat the person as the personal representative of the minor.C. Must obtain authorization from the minor to deny parent access.D. Is required to notify the Secretary of HHS.
column10: B. May elect not to treat the person as the personal representative of the minor.
column24: An entity may elect not to treat a person as a personal rep if there is a belief that the individual may be subjected to domestic violence or abuse by that person,,.
column41: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Minors and Privacy: A teenage patient (unemancipated minor) consents to medical counseling where state law allows her to do so without parental consent. She asks the provider not to disclose these details to her parents.
column5: A provider may disclose PHI about a minor to a parent if such disclosure is:
column7: A. Required for health care operations.B. Permitted or required by an applicable provision of State or other law (including case law).C. Requested by the parent's insurance provider.D. Accompanied by a written complaint.
column10: B. Permitted or required by an applicable provision of State or other law (including case law).
column24: An entity may disclose PHI about a minor to a parent if and to the extent permitted or required by applicable State or other law,.
column41: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Minors and Privacy: A teenage patient (unemancipated minor) consents to medical counseling where state law allows her to do so without parental consent. She asks the provider not to disclose these details to her parents.
column5: When a provider makes a professional judgment to deny a parent access to a minor's PHI (where no state access provision exists), the decision must be made by:
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. A licensed health care professional.C. The clinic's legal counsel.D. The health plan administrator.
column10: B. A licensed health care professional.
column24: Decisions to provide or deny access to a parent when not clearly mandated by state law must be made by a licensed healthcare professional in the exercise of professional judgment,.
column41: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column2: Scenario: Minors and Privacy: A teenage patient (unemancipated minor) consents to medical counseling where state law allows her to do so without parental consent. She asks the provider not to disclose these details to her parents.
column5: If a provider believes a patient is a victim of abuse (where state law does not mandate reporting), disclosure to a social service agency is permitted to:
column7: A. Facilitate payment activities.B. Prevent serious harm to the individual or other potential victims.C. Create a limited data set.D. Perform quality assessment studies.
column10: B. Prevent serious harm to the individual or other potential victims.
column24: If authorized by regulation, an entity may disclose PHI to a government authority if it believes the disclosure is necessary to prevent serious harm,,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column2: Scenario: Marketing and Testimonials: A health tech startup wants to use patient testimonials and photos in its marketing materials. Patients provided verbal consent during the onboarding process.
column5: Marketing to individuals generally requires which of the following before PHI can be used?
column7: A. A valid Business Associate Agreement (BAA).B. A written authorization signed by the individual.C. A notice sent to the Secretary of HHS.D. A statement in the Notice of Privacy Practices only.
column10: B. A written authorization signed by the individual.
column24: A covered entity must obtain an authorization for any use or disclosure of PHI for marketing, except for narrow exceptions like face-to-face communications,,.
column38: Uses and disclosures for which an authorization is required
column41: Individual authorization required for certain uses, including marketing and sale of PHI.

column2: Scenario: Marketing and Testimonials: A health tech startup wants to use patient testimonials and photos in its marketing materials. Patients provided verbal consent during the onboarding process.
column5: If the marketing involves financial remuneration from a third party to the covered entity, the authorization must:
column7: A. Be filed with the state health department.B. State that such remuneration is involved.C. Be encrypted and stored for ten years.D. Only be signed by the Privacy Official.
column10: B. State that such remuneration is involved.
column24: If marketing involves financial remuneration to the covered entity from a third party, the authorization must explicitly state that remuneration is involved,.
column38: Uses and disclosures for which an authorization is required
column41: Individual authorization required for certain uses, including marketing and sale of PHI.

column2: Scenario: Marketing and Testimonials: A health tech startup wants to use patient testimonials and photos in its marketing materials. Patients provided verbal consent during the onboarding process.
column5: Which of the following is NOT included in the narrow definition of "Marketing" (and thus may not require an authorization)?
column7: A. Selling a patient list to a pharmaceutical company.B. Promotional gifts of nominal value provided by the covered entity.C. Using patient photos on a public website for recruitment.D. Emails from a BA for patient satisfaction data mining.
column10: B. Promotional gifts of nominal value provided by the covered entity.
column24: Marketing excludes face-to-face communications and promotional gifts of nominal value provided by the entity,.
column38: Uses and disclosures for which an authorization is required
column41: Individual authorization required for certain uses, including marketing and sale of PHI.

column2: Scenario: Marketing and Testimonials: A health tech startup wants to use patient testimonials and photos in its marketing materials. Patients provided verbal consent during the onboarding process.
column5: If an organization wants to send "disease education emails" sponsored by a third-party pharmaceutical company, it should:
column7: A. Launch immediately if the content is educational.B. Describe these communications in the NPP and provide an opt-out, or obtain authorization.C. Only send them to employees.D. Use de-identified data for the mailing labels.
column10: B. Describe these communications in the NPP and provide an opt-out, or obtain authorization.
column24: Material secondary uses like sponsored education should be described in the NPP, and potentially require authorization if they fall under the marketing definition,.
column41: Required NPP content: permitted uses/disclosures, rights, duties, etc.

column2: Scenario: Marketing and Testimonials: A health tech startup wants to use patient testimonials and photos in its marketing materials. Patients provided verbal consent during the onboarding process.
column5: An authorization is considered "defective" and invalid if:
column7: A. It is printed on white paper instead of blue.B. The expiration date has passed or the expiration event is known to have occurred.C. It contains only one diagnostic code.D. It is signed by a personal representative.
column10: B. The expiration date has passed or the expiration event is known to have occurred.
column24: An authorization is invalid if the expiration date has passed or if required elements are incomplete or false,.
column38: Uses and disclosures for which an authorization is required
column41: Individual authorization required for certain uses, including marketing and sale of PHI.

column5: A startup operates in a state with a privacy law requiring data deletion within 30 days of a patient request. HIPAA requires records retention for "reasonable" periods. Which applies?
column7: A. HIPAA always applies as federal law preempts state law.B. State law applies if it is more stringent (stricter) than HIPAA.C. The startup may choose whichever law is easier to implement.D. Both are voided by the Administrative Simplification rules.
column10: B. State law applies if it is more stringent (stricter) than HIPAA.
column24: HIPAA preempts state law unless the state law relates to privacy and is "more stringent" (stricter) than the federal standard,,.
column41: Rules for determining when HIPAA standards preempt contrary state law and exceptions for more stringent state privacy laws.

column5: Which statement accurately describes the definition of Protected Health Information (PHI)?
column7: A. It includes only electronic records stored on cloud servers.B. It is Individually Identifiable Health Information transmitted or maintained in any form or medium.C. It explicitly excludes billing and payment records.D. It excludes genetic information of deceased individuals.
column10: B. It is Individually Identifiable Health Information transmitted or maintained in any form or medium.
column24: PHI means individually identifiable health information transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or in any other form or medium,,.
column41: Key definitions, including PHI, covered entity, and business associate.

column5: A health tech startup employee needs to access records for a billing discrepancy. The record contains detailed psychiatric notes unrelated to billing. What is the compliant action?
column7: A. Access the full record to be thorough.B. Request only the billing-related information needed.C. Ask a coworker to view the notes and summarize them.D. Access the record but do not read the psychiatric section.
column10: B. Request only the billing-related information needed.
column24: Regulated entities must limit PHI access, use, and disclosure to the minimum necessary: psychiatric notes are not needed for billing,.
column41: Requirement to limit workforce uses of PHI to the minimum necessary and to define rolebased access.

column5: Which body has authority to investigate a covered entity's compliance with HIPAA rules and require disclosures of PHI for that purpose?
column7: A. The Department of Labor.B. The Secretary (HHS) of the Department of Health and Human Services.C. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS).D. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) only.
column10: B. The Secretary (HHS) of the Department of Health and Human Services.
column24: Entities are required to disclose PHI when required by the Secretary to investigate or determine compliance,.
column41: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column5: If a startup is a "Hybrid Entity," what is the primary requirement for its components?
column7: A. They must share all PHI without encryption.B. The entity must designate health care components and implement firewalls separating them from non-covered components.C. They are exempt from all technical safeguards.D. They must only hire clinicians as administrators.
column10: B. The entity must designate health care components and implement firewalls separating them from non-covered components.
column24: Hybrid entities must designate health care components and ensure they protect PHI as if the components were separate legal entities,,.
column41: Requirements for hybrid entities, affiliated covered entities, and documentation of designations.

column5: When must an individual's right to receive an accounting of disclosures be temporarily suspended?
column7: A. When the individual has not paid their bill.B. When a health oversight agency provides a written statement that an accounting would likely impede its activities.C. When the Privacy Official is on vacation.D. When the breach involves more than 1,000 people.
column10: B. When a health oversight agency provides a written statement that an accounting would likely impede its activities.
column24: An entity must suspend the right to an accounting if a health oversight agency or law enforcement official states that it would impede their activities,.
column41: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column5: The standard for "Integrity" under the Security Rule primarily requires:
column7: A. High-level encryption for all data in motion.B. Policies and procedures to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction.C. Annual psychological testing of all IT staff.D. A mandatory report to the media every time a system crashes.
column10: B. Policies and procedures to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction.
column24: Integrity means the property that data has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner: policies must be in place to ensure this,,.
column41: Policies and mechanisms to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction and to authenticate ePHI.

column5: If an organization elects not to implement an "Addressable" specification (like encryption), it must:
column7: A. Ignore the specification entirely.B. Pay a waiver fee to HHS.C. Document why it is not reasonable and implement an equivalent alternative measure if reasonable.D. Only implement it if a breach occurs.
column10: C. Document why it is not reasonable and implement an equivalent alternative measure if reasonable.
column24: For addressable specifications, the entity must assess them and either implement them or document the rationale for an equivalent alternative,,.
column41: Requirement to implement reasonable and appropriate security policies and procedures.

column5: Which factor is considered in determining the amount of a Civil Money Penalty (CMP) for a violation?
column7: A. The size of the workforce.B. The history of prior compliance.C. The number of patients the clinic sees daily.D. The brand of security software used.
column10: B. The history of prior compliance.
column24: CMP factors include the nature of the violation, harm, financial condition, and prior compliance history [1135–1139, 2013–2017].
column41: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column5: A Business Associate (BA) is required by HIPAA to train all workforce members on policies related to:
column7: A. The Privacy Rule only.B. The Security Rule only.C. The Privacy Rule and the Breach Notification Rule.D. The Employment Law standards.
column10: C. The Privacy Rule and the Breach Notification Rule.
column24: Covered entities and BAs must train workforce members on the policies and procedures with respect to PHI required by Subpart E (Privacy) and Subpart D (Breach),.
column41: Training requirements for workforce on Privacy Rule and breachrelated policies and documentation of that training.

column3: Scenario: Risk Management and Security Standards: The IT Security team is preparing for an annual review by reassessing threats and vulnerabilities to the Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, which contains extensive ePHI.
column4: The primary goal of protecting ePHI by ensuring the property that data or information is accessible and usable upon demand by an authorized person is known as:
column7: A. Confidentiality.B. Integrity.C. Availability.D. Authentication.
column22: Availability is defined as the property that data or information is accessible and usable upon demand by an authorized person.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Risk Management and Security Standards: The IT Security team is preparing for an annual review by reassessing threats and vulnerabilities to the Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, which contains extensive ePHI.
column4: As part of the Security Management Process, IT staff must conduct a Risk Analysis. This required implementation specification involves assessing potential risks to which objectives of ePHI?
column7: A. Identity, Access, and Control.B. Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.C. Authorization, Sanctions, and Evaluation.D. Documentation, Mitigation, and Reporting.
column22: Risk Analysis requires an assessment of potential risks and vulnerabilities to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of ePHI.
column42: Accurate and thorough assessment of risks and vulnerabilities to ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Risk Management and Security Standards: The IT Security team is preparing for an annual review by reassessing threats and vulnerabilities to the Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, which contains extensive ePHI.
column4: The Risk Management (Required) implementation specification mandates that the entity must implement security measures sufficient to:
column7: A. Avoid all potential threats and hazards to ePHI.B. Reduce risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level.C. Eliminate all unauthorized disclosures of ePHI.D. Certify the technical infrastructure annually.
column11: B. Reduce risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level.
column22: Risk Management requires implementing measures to reduce risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level.
column42: Security measures sufficient to reduce identified risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level.

column3: Scenario: Risk Management and Security Standards: The IT Security team is preparing for an annual review by reassessing threats and vulnerabilities to the Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, which contains extensive ePHI.
column4: If the IT team determines that implementing an addressable implementation specification is not reasonable and appropriate, the team must:
column7: A. Implement an equivalent alternative measure and document the rationale.B. Implement a different required specification instead.C. Document only the cost of implementation.D. Obtain written approval from the Secretary of HHS.
column11: A. Implement an equivalent alternative measure and document the rationale.
column22: If implementation is not reasonable, the entity must document why and implement an equivalent alternative measure if reasonable and appropriate.
column42: Requirement to implement reasonable and appropriate security policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Risk Management and Security Standards: The IT Security team is preparing for an annual review by reassessing threats and vulnerabilities to the Electronic Health Record (EHR) system, which contains extensive ePHI.
column4: The Access Control standard requires technical policies and procedures for electronic information systems maintaining ePHI to allow access only to those persons or software programs that:
column7: A. Are physically located within the facility.B. Are verified by multi:factor authentication.C. Have been granted access rights as specified in § 164.308(a)(4).D. Are covered entities or business associates.
column11: C. Have been granted access rights as specified in § 164.308(a)(4).
column22: Access control requires technical policies to allow access only to those granted access rights as specified in the Information Access Management standard.
column42: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column3: Scenario: User Access and Oversight: The organization is provisioning access for a new batch of temporary contractors and updating its policies for monitoring user activity, focusing on remote access points.
column4: When setting up accounts for the new temporary contractors, the technical requirement to assign a unique name and/or number for identifying and tracking user identity is a:
column7: A. Required implementation specification under Access Control.B. Addressable implementation specification under Audit Controls.C. Required Administrative safeguard.D. Addressable Physical safeguard.
column11: A. Required implementation specification under Access Control.
column22: Unique User Identification is a required specification under the Access Control standard.
column42: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column3: Scenario: User Access and Oversight: The organization is provisioning access for a new batch of temporary contractors and updating its policies for monitoring user activity, focusing on remote access points.
column4: To strengthen security for remote users, the Security Official suggests implementing a mechanism to encrypt and decrypt ePHI stored on devices. This is classified as a(n):
column7: A. Required Administrative safeguard.B. Required Technical safeguard.C. Addressable Technical safeguard.D. Required Physical safeguard.
column22: Encryption and Decryption is an addressable implementation specification under the Access Control standard.
column42: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column3: Scenario: User Access and Oversight: The organization is provisioning access for a new batch of temporary contractors and updating its policies for monitoring user activity, focusing on remote access points.
column4: The requirement to implement hardware, software, and/or procedural mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems is defined under which standard?
column7: A. Access Control.B. Audit Controls.C. Integrity.D. Person or Entity Authentication.
column22: Audit Controls is a required standard mandating mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use ePHI.
column42: Mechanisms to record and examine system activity involving ePHI.

column3: Scenario: User Access and Oversight: The organization is provisioning access for a new batch of temporary contractors and updating its policies for monitoring user activity, focusing on remote access points.
column4: When responding to a major system compromise, the organization must ensure compliance with the Security Rule by its workforce. This falls under which category?
column7: A. Flexibility of Approach.B. Standards.C. General Requirements.D. Implementation Specifications.
column22: Regulated entities must ensure compliance with the Security Rule by their workforce as a general requirement.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column3: Scenario: User Access and Oversight: The organization is provisioning access for a new batch of temporary contractors and updating its policies for monitoring user activity, focusing on remote access points.
column4: The requirement to apply appropriate sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies and procedures is a:
column7: A. Required implementation specification.B. Addressable implementation specification.C. Security awareness training program element.D. Component of the Physical Safeguards.
column22: Sanction Policy is a required implementation specification under the Security Management Process standard.
column42: Requirement to apply sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Specifications and Definitions: The Security Official is writing a policy document explaining the classification of safeguards and required implementation steps for addressing new technical threats, including ransomware.
column4: The technical policies and procedures implemented for electronic information systems that protect ePHI and control access to it are defined as:
column7: A. Administrative safeguards.B. Physical safeguards.C. Technical safeguards.D. Confidentiality mechanisms.
column22: Technical safeguards are the technology and the policy and procedures for its use that protect ePHI and control access to it.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Specifications and Definitions: The Security Official is writing a policy document explaining the classification of safeguards and required implementation steps for addressing new technical threats, including ransomware.
column4: Procedures for creating, changing, and safeguarding passwords fall under which category of implementation specification?
column7: A. Required, under Information Access Management.B. Addressable, under Security Awareness and Training.C. Required, under Audit Controls.D. Addressable, under Workforce Security.
column11: B. Addressable, under Security Awareness and Training.
column22: Password Management is an addressable implementation specification under the Security Awareness and Training standard.
column42: Security awareness program: reminders, malicioussoftware protection, login monitoring, password management.

column3: Scenario: Specifications and Definitions: The Security Official is writing a policy document explaining the classification of safeguards and required implementation steps for addressing new technical threats, including ransomware.
column4: The standard that mandates the implementation of procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed is known as:
column7: A. Access Control.B. Audit Controls.C. Integrity.D. Person or Entity Authentication.
column22: Person or Entity Authentication requires procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed.
column42: Verification that a person or entity seeking ePHI access is the one claimed.

column3: Scenario: Specifications and Definitions: The Security Official is writing a policy document explaining the classification of safeguards and required implementation steps for addressing new technical threats, including ransomware.
column4: The core objective of Transmission Security is to implement technical security measures to:
column7: A. Ensure that only encrypted PHI is transmitted over networks.B. Guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over an electronic communications network.C. Automatically log off users after data transmission.D. Record and examine all activity logs related to transmission.
column11: B. Guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over an electronic communications network.
column22: Transmission Security requires measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over an electronic communications network.
column42: Integrity controls and encryption for ePHI transmitted over electronic networks.

column3: Scenario: Specifications and Definitions: The Security Official is writing a policy document explaining the classification of safeguards and required implementation steps for addressing new technical threats, including ransomware.
column4: The standard requiring a periodic technical and nontechnical evaluation to establish the extent to which security policies and procedures meet requirements is:
column7: A. Risk Analysis.B. Risk Management.C. Contingency Plan.D. Evaluation.
column22: Evaluation requires periodic technical and nontechnical evaluations based on the standards implemented under the rule.
column42: Technical and nontechnical evaluations of security policies and procedures in light of changes.

column3: Scenario: Contingency and Disaster Recovery: A major weather event threatens the primary data center. The IT team must rely on contingency plans to ensure the continuation of critical services and protection of ePHI.
column4: The Contingency Plan standard requires establishing procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI. This is the definition of the:
column7: A. Disaster Recovery Plan (Required).B. Data Backup Plan (Required).C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan (Required).D. Applications and Data Criticality Analysis (Addressable).
column22: The Data Backup Plan specification requires procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Contingency and Disaster Recovery: A major weather event threatens the primary data center. The IT team must rely on contingency plans to ensure the continuation of critical services and protection of ePHI.
column4: The Contingency Plan must include procedures to restore any loss of data. This required implementation specification is defined as the:
column7: A. Disaster Recovery Plan.B. Data Backup Plan.C. Testing and Revision Procedure.D. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.
column22: Disaster Recovery Plan requires establishing procedures to restore any loss of data.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Contingency and Disaster Recovery: A major weather event threatens the primary data center. The IT team must rely on contingency plans to ensure the continuation of critical services and protection of ePHI.
column4: The implementation specification requiring procedures for periodic testing and revision of contingency plans is categorized as:
column7: A. Required.B. Addressable.C. Optional.D. Administrative.
column22: Testing and Revision Procedure is an addressable implementation specification under the Contingency Plan standard.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Contingency and Disaster Recovery: A major weather event threatens the primary data center. The IT team must rely on contingency plans to ensure the continuation of critical services and protection of ePHI.
column4: To prioritize restoration efforts, the team should perform an Applications and Data Criticality Analysis. This process is categorized as:
column7: A. Required.B. Mandatory.C. Addressable.D. Integrity control.
column22: Applications and Data Criticality Analysis is an addressable specification under the Contingency Plan standard.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Contingency and Disaster Recovery: A major weather event threatens the primary data center. The IT team must rely on contingency plans to ensure the continuation of critical services and protection of ePHI.
column4: The IT team needs procedures to enable the continuation of critical business processes while operating in emergency mode. This required specification is the:
column7: A. Disaster Recovery Plan.B. Emergency Access Procedure.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Facility Security Plan.
column22: Emergency Mode Operation Plan requires procedures for continuation of critical processes to protect ePHI while in emergency mode.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Device and Physical Controls: An obsolete server containing backup ePHI is being replaced and disposed of, and old storage media are being prepared for reuse.
column4: Before the obsolete server is transferred to a disposal vendor, the organization must address the final disposition of ePHI and the hardware. This is:
column7: A. Accountability.B. Data Backup and Storage.C. Media Re-use.D. Disposal.
column22: Disposal is a required implementation specification addressing the final disposition of ePHI and/or the hardware/media on which it is stored.
column42: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Device and Physical Controls: An obsolete server containing backup ePHI is being replaced and disposed of, and old storage media are being prepared for reuse.
column4: If the IT team intends to reuse old hard drives, they must implement procedures for removal of ePHI before the media are made available. This is:
column7: A. Required.B. Addressable.C. Technical.D. Administrative.
column22: Media Re-use is a required implementation specification under Device and Media Controls.
column42: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Device and Physical Controls: An obsolete server containing backup ePHI is being replaced and disposed of, and old storage media are being prepared for reuse.
column4: To satisfy the Accountability implementation specification (Addressable), the organization should maintain a record of media movements and:
column7: A. Costs associated with replacement.B. Any person responsible therefore.C. Date the Risk Analysis was completed.D. Nearest authorized repair facility.
column22: Accountability requires maintaining a record of movements of hardware/media and any person responsible therefore.
column42: Receipt, movement, reuse, backup, and disposal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Device and Physical Controls: An obsolete server containing backup ePHI is being replaced and disposed of, and old storage media are being prepared for reuse.
column4: The Workstation Use standard requires policies and procedures that specify all the following except:
column7: A. Physical attributes of workstation surroundings.B. Proper functions to be performed.C. Manner in which functions are performed.D. Name of the Security Official responsible for the workstation.
column11: D. Name of the Security Official responsible for the workstation.
column22: Workstation Use requires specifying functions, manner of performance, and physical attributes of surroundings.
column42: Rules for appropriate functions, manner of use, and physical attributes of workstations accessing ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Device and Physical Controls: An obsolete server containing backup ePHI is being replaced and disposed of, and old storage media are being prepared for reuse.
column4: When deploying physical measures to limit access to electronic information systems and facilities, the organization is complying with the standard for:
column7: A. Contingency Plan.B. Facility Access Controls.C. Workstation Security.D. Device and Media Controls.
column22: Facility Access Controls requires policies to limit physical access to electronic systems and the facilities where they are housed.
column42: Physical safeguards to limit facility access to ePHI systems, including contingency operations, security plans, access validation, and maintenance records.

column3: Scenario: Integrity and Technical Reviews: The IT team deploys a cryptographic hashing mechanism to ensure that critical ePHI files have not been compromised during transfer or storage.
column4: The standard mandating the implementation of policies and procedures to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction is:
column7: A. Access Control.B. Audit Controls.C. Integrity.D. Confidentiality.
column22: The Integrity standard requires policies and procedures to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction.
column42: Policies and mechanisms to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction and to authenticate ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Integrity and Technical Reviews: The IT team deploys a cryptographic hashing mechanism to ensure that critical ePHI files have not been compromised during transfer or storage.
column4: The hashing mechanism used to corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed addresses which Addressable specification?
column7: A. Automatic Logoff.B. Integrity Controls.C. Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI.D. Encryption and Decryption.
column22: Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI implements electronic mechanisms to corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
column42: Policies and mechanisms to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction and to authenticate ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Integrity and Technical Reviews: The IT team deploys a cryptographic hashing mechanism to ensure that critical ePHI files have not been compromised during transfer or storage.
column4: The technical requirement to implement security measures ensuring that electronically transmitted ePHI is not improperly modified without detection is:
column7: A. Integrity Controls (Addressable).B. Encryption (Addressable).C. Emergency Access Procedure (Required).D. Authentication (Required).
column22: Integrity Controls is an addressable implementation specification under Transmission Security.
column42: Integrity controls and encryption for ePHI transmitted over electronic networks.

column3: Scenario: Integrity and Technical Reviews: The IT team deploys a cryptographic hashing mechanism to ensure that critical ePHI files have not been compromised during transfer or storage.
column4: The property that data or information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes is the definition of:
column7: A. Integrity.B. Availability.C. Confidentiality.D. Authentication.
column22: Confidentiality is the property that data or information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Integrity and Technical Reviews: The IT team deploys a cryptographic hashing mechanism to ensure that critical ePHI files have not been compromised during transfer or storage.
column4: A mobile cart cart workstation in the facility must have physical safeguards implemented to restrict access to authorized users. This is required under:
column7: A. Device and Media Controls.B. Facility Access Controls.C. Workstation Security.D. Workstation Use.
column22: Workstation Security requires implementing physical safeguards for all workstations that access ePHI to restrict access to authorized users.
column42: Physical safeguards for workstations to restrict access to authorized users.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents and Breach Reporting: The IT team discovers that an external attacker successfully deployed ransomware, encrypting unsecured ePHI on the central server.
column4: The Security Incident Procedures standard requires the entity to implement policies and procedures to address:
column7: A. All physical security breaches.B. Only breaches that affect 500 or more individuals.C. Security incidents.D. Workforce policy violations.
column22: The Security Incident Procedures standard requires implementing policies and procedures to address security incidents.
column42: Policies to identify, respond to, mitigate, and document security incidents.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents and Breach Reporting: The IT team discovers that an external attacker successfully deployed ransomware, encrypting unsecured ePHI on the central server.
column4: The required implementation specification Response and Reporting mandates that the IT team must identify and respond to the incident, mitigate effects, and:
column7: A. Immediately notify the media.B. Document security incidents and their outcomes.C. Determine Civil Money Penalties.D. Obtain legal review for sanctions.
column11: B. Document security incidents and their outcomes.
column22: Response and Reporting requires identifying/responding to incidents, mitigating harmful effects, and documenting security incidents and their outcomes.
column42: Policies to identify, respond to, mitigate, and document security incidents.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents and Breach Reporting: The IT team discovers that an external attacker successfully deployed ransomware, encrypting unsecured ePHI on the central server.
column4: The breach of unsecured PHI is considered discovered by the organization on the first day such breach is known to any workforce member, EXCEPT the person:
column7: A. Who is the Security Official.B. Who is committing the breach.C. Who is responsible for mitigation.D. Who is a business associate.
column11: B. Who is committing the breach.
column22: A breach is treated as discovered by a CE on the first day it is known to any person (other than the person committing the breach) who is a workforce member or agent.
column42: Requirement to provide notice without unreasonable delay and no later than 60 calendar days after discovery.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents and Breach Reporting: The IT team discovers that an external attacker successfully deployed ransomware, encrypting unsecured ePHI on the central server.
column4: If the organization is a Business Associate (BA) and discovers a breach of unsecured PHI, the breach is treated as discovered on the first day known to:
column7: A. Any employee, officer, or agent of the BA (except the perpetrator).B. Only the BA’s Privacy Official.C. The BA’s CEO.D. The Covered Entity’s Security Official.
column11: A. Any employee, officer, or agent of the BA (except the perpetrator).
column22: A breach is treated as discovered by a BA as of the first day it is known to any person (other than the person committing the breach) who is an employee, officer, or other agent of the BA.
column42: Business associate duty to notify covered entities of breaches, including time frames and information to be provided.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents and Breach Reporting: The IT team discovers that an external attacker successfully deployed ransomware, encrypting unsecured ePHI on the central server.
column4: Following the discovery of a breach, a Business Associate must notify the Covered Entity of the breach without unreasonable delay and in no case later than:
column7: A. 30 calendar days.B. 60 calendar days.C. 90 calendar days.D. 6 months.
column22: A business associate must provide notification without unreasonable delay and in no case later than 60 calendar days after discovery of a breach.
column42: Business associate duty to notify covered entities of breaches, including time frames and information to be provided.

column3: Scenario: Breach Risk Assessment and Burden of Proof: The IT team is working with compliance staff to perform a risk assessment on the ransomware incident to determine if breach notification is required.
column4: If the organization is a Business Associate, the notification to the Covered Entity must include, to the extent possible, the identification of:
column7: A. The system responsible for the intrusion.B. Each individual whose unsecured PHI was involved.C. The encryption technology used prior to the breach.D. The Security Official responsible for the incident.
column11: B. Each individual whose unsecured PHI was involved.
column22: The BA notification to the CE must include, to the extent possible, the identification of each individual whose unsecured PHI has been accessed, acquired, used, or disclosed.
column42: Business associate duty to notify covered entities of breaches, including time frames and information to be provided.

column3: Scenario: Breach Risk Assessment and Burden of Proof: The IT team is working with compliance staff to perform a risk assessment on the ransomware incident to determine if breach notification is required.
column4: Which event is excluded from the definition of a breach altogether?
column7: A. Disclosure by an employee to a family member.B. Acquisition of PHI by a workforce member in good faith and within scope, with no further impermissible use.C. Loss of a portable device secured with a strong password.D. Use of encrypted data by an unauthorized party.
column11: B. Acquisition of PHI by a workforce member in good faith and within scope, with no further impermissible use.
column22: Breach excludes any unintentional acquisition, access, or use of PHI by a workforce member in good faith and within the scope of authority, with no further impermissible use/disclosure.
column42: Definition of “breach,” exceptions (for example, unintentional goodfaith access within scope, inadvertent disclosures within an entity, and disclosures where risk is low).

column3: Scenario: Breach Risk Assessment and Burden of Proof: The IT team is working with compliance staff to perform a risk assessment on the ransomware incident to determine if breach notification is required.
column4: Any impermissible acquisition, access, use, or disclosure of PHI is presumed to be a breach unless the entity demonstrates there is a:
column7: A. Low probability that the PHI has been compromised.B. High likelihood that the PHI was encrypted.C. Failure of the Contingency Plan.D. Willful neglect violation.
column11: A. Low probability that the PHI has been compromised.
column22: Impermissible PHI activity is presumed to be a breach unless the entity demonstrates a low probability that the PHI has been compromised based on a risk assessment.
column42: Required fourfactor risk assessment to determine probability that PHI has been compromised: nature/extent of data, unauthorized person, whether PHI was acquired/viewed, and mitigation.

column3: Scenario: Breach Risk Assessment and Burden of Proof: The IT team is working with compliance staff to perform a risk assessment on the ransomware incident to determine if breach notification is required.
column4: When conducting the required breach risk assessment, the organization must consider at least four factors, including:
column7: A. Size, complexity, and capabilities of the entity.B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.C. Cost of technical security measures.D. Existence of a valid BAA.
column11: B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.
column22: The risk assessment must consider factors including the nature/extent of PHI, the unauthorized person, whether the PHI was acquired or viewed, and the extent of mitigation.
column42: Required fourfactor risk assessment to determine probability that PHI has been compromised: nature/extent of data, unauthorized person, whether PHI was acquired/viewed, and mitigation.

column3: Scenario: Breach Risk Assessment and Burden of Proof: The IT team is working with compliance staff to perform a risk assessment on the ransomware incident to determine if breach notification is required.
column4: If a disclosure occurred in violation of Subpart E (Privacy Rule), the organization (CE or BA) carries the burden of proof for demonstrating:
column7: A. That the disclosure was required by law.B. That all notifications were made OR that the disclosure did not constitute a breach.C. That the Security Official was not negligent.D. That the Civil Money Penalty should be reduced.
column11: B. That all notifications were made OR that the disclosure did not constitute a breach.
column22: The CE or BA has the burden of demonstrating that all notifications were made or that the use/disclosure did not constitute a breach.
column42: Application of certain Privacy Rule administrative requirements to breach notification activities, and burden of proof to show notifications were made or not required.

column3: Scenario: Organizational Security: The IT/Security team manages contracts and electronic data exchange with Business Associates (BAs) and must ensure that organizational policies are up to standard.
column4: If the Covered Entity (CE) hires a BA, the CE must ensure that any subcontractors hired by the BA agree to comply with Subpart C by entering into a contract that complies with:
column7: A. § 164.504(e) (Privacy Rule BAA).B. § 164.314 (Organizational Security Rule BAA).C. § 164.306 (Security General Rules).D. § 164.402 (Breach Definitions).
column22: The contract must provide that the BA will ensure that any subcontractors agree to comply with Subpart C by entering into a contract that complies with § 164.314.
column42: Written contracts/arrangements requiring BAs and their subcontractors to safeguard ePHI and report security incidents and breaches.

column3: Scenario: Organizational Security: The IT/Security team manages contracts and electronic data exchange with Business Associates (BAs) and must ensure that organizational policies are up to standard.
column4: The Business Associate Contract (BAC) between the CE and BA must include a specification that the BA report to the CE any security incident, including:
column7: A. All malicious software incidents.B. Breaches of unsecured PHI as required by § 164.410.C. All log:in monitoring discrepancies.D. Any termination procedure failures.
column11: B. Breaches of unsecured PHI as required by § 164.410.
column22: The BAC must require the BA to report any security incident, including breaches of unsecured PHI as required by § 164.410.
column42: Written contracts/arrangements requiring BAs and their subcontractors to safeguard ePHI and report security incidents and breaches.

column3: Scenario: Organizational Security: The IT/Security team manages contracts and electronic data exchange with Business Associates (BAs) and must ensure that organizational policies are up to standard.
column4: The Breach Notification Rule administrative requirements specify that all workforce members must receive training on policies and procedures related to:
column7: A. The Privacy Rule only.B. Subpart C (Security) only.C. The Privacy Rule and Subpart D (Breach Notification).D. The Security Rule and Administrative Simplification rules.
column11: C. The Privacy Rule and Subpart D (Breach Notification).
column22: A CE must train all workforce members on the policies and procedures with respect to PHI required by Subpart E (Privacy) and Subpart D (Breach).
column42: Training requirements for workforce on Privacy Rule and breachrelated policies and documentation of that training.

column3: Scenario: Organizational Security: The IT/Security team manages contracts and electronic data exchange with Business Associates (BAs) and must ensure that organizational policies are up to standard.
column4: The required standard necessitating procedures to restore any loss of data is the:
column7: A. Data Backup Plan.B. Disaster Recovery Plan.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Applications and Data Criticality Analysis.
column22: Disaster Recovery Plan requires establishing and implementing procedures to restore any loss of data.
column42: Data backup, disaster recovery, emergencymode operation, testing, and application/data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Organizational Security: The IT/Security team manages contracts and electronic data exchange with Business Associates (BAs) and must ensure that organizational policies are up to standard.
column4: The Business Associate Contract permit the BA to disclose PHI for its management if the BA obtains assurances of confidentiality and the recipient notifies the BA of:
column7: A. Any changes in their security technology.B. The destruction of all PHI copies.C. Any instances in which the confidentiality of the info has been breached.D. The completion of all required HIPAA training.
column11: C. Any instances in which the confidentiality of the info has been breached.
column22: The contract may permit disclosure for management if the BA obtains assurances that the recipient will notify the BA of any breaches of confidentiality.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts, and to limit BA uses/disclosures to the contract and rule.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for security awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column4: A key factor management must consider when selecting security measures is the probability and criticality of potential risks to ePHI, weighed against:
column7: A. Size and complexity of the CE.B. Technical infrastructure and capabilities.C. Costs of security measures.D. All of the above.
column22: Decision factors for security measures include size, complexity, technical infrastructure, software/hardware capabilities, costs, and probability/criticality of risks.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI and protect against reasonably anticipated threats and impermissible uses/disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for security awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column4: The security policy for granting workforce members access to ePHI must be consistent with the requirements of which other Security Rule provision?
column7: A. Contingency Plan standard.B. Subpart E (Privacy Rule).C. Physical Safeguards standard.D. Breach Notification Rule.
column22: Policies for authorizing access to ePHI must be consistent with the applicable requirements of Subpart E (Privacy Rule).
column42: Policies for authorizing access to ePHI, including isolating clearinghouse functions and managing access establishment/modification.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for security awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column4: The Security Awareness and Training standard requires a program for all workforce members, including an addressable specification for periodic security updates known as:
column7: A. Security Reminders.B. Log:in Monitoring.C. Password Management.D. Protection from Malicious Software.
column22: Security Reminders is the addressable implementation specification for providing periodic security updates.
column42: Security awareness program: reminders, malicioussoftware protection, login monitoring, password management.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for security awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column4: The Policies and Procedures standard requires policies to be reasonably designed, taking into account the CE/BA’s size and which other factor related to PHI?
column7: A. The type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.B. The maximum number of individuals whose PHI is maintained.C. The minimum level of technical competence of the workforce.D. The geographical location of the headquarters.
column11: A. The type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.
column22: Policies and procedures must be reasonably designed, taking into account the size and type of activities related to PHI undertaken by the entity.
column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy: The management team is reviewing security measures and policies. They must decide on the proper approach for security awareness, authorization, and technical safeguards.
column4: If management decides to use Encryption for ePHI stored on laptops, this is classified as a(n):
column7: A. Required Administrative Safeguard.B. Required Technical Safeguard.C. Addressable Technical Safeguard.D. Required Physical Safeguard.
column22: Encryption and Decryption is an addressable implementation specification under the Access Control technical standard.
column42: Technical measures (unique user IDs, emergency access, automatic logoff, encryption/decryption) to limit ePHI access.

column3: Scenario: Minor’s Privacy Rights: A 16-year-old patient consents to a sensitive medical service where state law does not require parental consent. She specifically requests her parents not be informed.
column4: Under what condition MUST the provider treat the minor as the "individual" and deny the parent access to the PHI for that specific service?
column7: A. The minor pays for the service in full.B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the representative.C. The parent is currently under investigation for child neglect.D. The provider believes the parent has a conflict of interest.
column17: B. The minor lawfully obtained the service without parental consent and has not requested the parent be the representative.
column22: A minor has the authority to act as an individual if they consent to a service where no other consent is required by law and no personal representative is requested.
column42: Requirement to recognise personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column3: Scenario: Minor’s Privacy Rights: A 16-year-old patient consents to a sensitive medical service where state law does not require parental consent. She specifically requests her parents not be informed.
column4: If a provider reasonably believes that a parent or guardian may subject a minor to domestic violence or abuse, the provider:
column7: A. Must still treat the parent as the personal representative.B. May elect not to treat the person as the personal representative.C. Is required to notify the Secretary of HHS before denying access.D. Must obtain a court order to revoke the parent’s representative status.
column17: B. May elect not to treat the person as the personal representative.
column22: A covered entity may elect not to treat a person as a personal representative if it has a reasonable belief the individual may be subjected to abuse or neglect by that person.
column42: Requirement to recognise personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column3: Scenario: Minor’s Privacy Rights: A 16-year-old patient consents to a sensitive medical service where state law does not require parental consent. She specifically requests her parents not be informed.
column4: If there is no applicable access provision under State or other law regarding a parent’s access to a minor's PHI, the decision to provide or deny access must be made by:
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. A licensed health care professional.C. The minor’s primary care physician only.D. The organization’s legal counsel.
column17: B. A licensed health care professional.
column22: In the absence of a specific state law, a decision to provide or deny access to a parent must be made by a licensed health care professional in the exercise of professional judgment.
column42: Requirement to recognise personal representatives for adults, minors, and decedents, with exceptions for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: Dr. Chen may disclose the PHI of Armed Forces personnel for military mission purposes if which condition is met?
column7: A. The disclosure is limited to the minimum necessary for treatment.B. The military authority has published a notice in the FEDERAL REGISTER listing the purposes.C. The soldier provides a signed HIPAA authorization.D. The disclosure is required by the soldier's health plan.
column17: B. The military authority has published a notice in the FEDERAL REGISTER listing the purposes.
column22: A covered entity may disclose PHI of Armed Forces personnel if appropriate military command authorities have published notice in the Federal Register.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations, and via business associates; OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: Disclosure of PHI for a "Medical Suitability Determination" by a Department of State component is specifically permitted for:
column7: A. Determining an employee’s worldwide availability or mandatory service abroad.B. Assessing an employee’s eligibility for life insurance.C. Reporting infectious diseases to the CDC.D. Verifying the employee’s tax identification number.
column17: A. Determining an employee’s worldwide availability or mandatory service abroad.
column22: The Department of State may use or disclose PHI to determine worldwide availability or availability for mandatory service abroad.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI, including for treatment, payment, health care operations.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: A covered entity may disclose PHI to authorized federal officials for the conduct of COUNTER-INTELLIGENCE activities under:
column7: A. The HITECH Act.B. The National Security Act.C. The Privacy Act of 1974.D. The Federal Information Security Modernization Act (FISMA).
column17: B. The National Security Act.
column22: A covered entity may disclose PHI to authorized federal officials for counter-intelligence and other national security activities authorized by the National Security Act.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: Disclosures to a correctional institution regarding an inmate are permitted if the institution represents the PHI is necessary for:
column7: A. The provision of health care to the individual.B. The health and safety of officers or employees at the institution.C. The administration and maintenance of the safety and good order of the institution.D. All of the above.
column17: D. All of the above.
column22: Disclosures to correctional institutions are permitted for health care provision, safety of staff/inmates, and maintaining safety and good order.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: If an individual is released from a correctional institution on parole, are they still considered an "inmate" for the purposes of specialized government function disclosures?
column7: A. Yes, until the parole period ends.B. No, an individual is no longer an inmate when released on parole.C. Yes, if the correctional institution still maintains their medical records.D. Only if the individual is re-arrested within 30 days.
column17: B. No, an individual is no longer an inmate when released on parole.
column22: The provision for correctional institutions ceases to apply when an individual is released on parole, probation, or is otherwise no longer in lawful custody.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: When a health plan that is a government program providing public benefits shares PHI with another such agency, the sharing must be:
column7: A. Authorized by the individual in writing.B. Required or expressly authorized by statute or regulation.C. Limited to name and SSN only.D. For marketing purposes only.
column17: B. Required or expressly authorized by statute or regulation.
column22: Sharing PHI between government agencies providing public benefits is permitted if required or expressly authorized by statute or regulation.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Specialized Government Functions: Dr. Chen operates a clinic on a military base and handles PHI for active Armed Forces personnel. He also responds to a Department of State request for a medical suitability determination.
column4: Disclosures to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) are permitted to report the identity of an individual prohibited from possessing a firearm, provided the disclosure:
column7: A. Includes all psychiatric notes.B. Does not disclose diagnostic or clinical information.C. Is made only after the individual consents.D. Is made to the media within 60 days.
column17: B. Does not disclose diagnostic or clinical information.
column22: NICS disclosures must be limited to demographic and other needed info and must NOT include diagnostic or clinical information.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: If the Secretary determines a violation was due to willful neglect and was NOT corrected within 30 days, the minimum penalty per violation is:
column22: For violations due to willful neglect not corrected within the 30-day period, the penalty is not less than $50,000.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: A "Reasonable Cause" violation is defined as an act where the entity knew (or should have known) of the violation but did NOT act with:
column7: A. Ordinary business care.B. Willful neglect.C. Professional judgment.D. Malicious intent.
column17: B. Willful neglect.
column22: Reasonable cause means the entity knew or should have known of the violation but did not act with willful neglect.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: When determining the amount of a penalty, the Secretary will consider the "Financial Condition" of the entity, including whether the penalty would:
column7: A. Result in a lower tax bracket for the entity.B. Jeopardize the entity’s ability to continue providing health care.C. Exceed the entity’s annual IT budget.D. Require the layoff of more than 5% of staff.
column17: B. Jeopardize the entity’s ability to continue providing health care.
column22: Financial condition factors include whether the penalty would jeopardize the ability of the entity to continue providing or paying for health care.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: A Covered Entity is liable for a CMP based on the act or omission of ANY agent (including BAs or workforce members) acting within:
column7: A. The physical premises of the entity.B. The scope of the agency.C. The duration of the contract.D. The calendar year of discovery.
column17: B. The scope of the agency.
column22: An entity is liable for violations based on the acts of any agent acting within the scope of the agency.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: If a violation is corrected within 30 days of discovery, the Secretary may NOT impose a penalty IF the violation was due to:
column7: A. Willful neglect.B. Reasonable cause (not involving willful neglect).C. Inadvertent error by a temporary contractor.D. A first-time offense.
column17: B. Reasonable cause (not involving willful neglect).
column22: Affirmative defenses prevent penalties if a violation was due to reasonable cause (not willful neglect) and corrected within 30 days.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: If a violation is a "continuing violation," a SEPARATE violation occurs:
column7: A. Every 30 days.B. Each day the entity is in violation.C. For every individual affected.D. Once per calendar year.
column17: B. Each day the entity is in violation.
column22: In the case of a continuing violation, a separate violation occurs each day the entity is in violation.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.
