column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: In any proceeding under HIPAA, the Secretary has the "burden of persuasion" for issues of liability, EXCEPT for:
column7: A. Identifying the persons affected.B. Determining if a disclosure was required by law.C. Compliance with the Breach Notification Rule.D. Calculating the financial harm.
column17: C. Compliance with the Breach Notification Rule.
column22: The respondent (entity) has the burden of persuasion regarding compliance with the Breach Notification Rule (§ 164.414(b)).
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: Which official has the authority to affirm, increase, or reduce penalties imposed by the Secretary?
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. An Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).C. The Attorney General.D. The CEO of the entity.
column17: B. An Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).
column22: An ALJ may affirm, increase, or reduce the penalties imposed by the Secretary.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: An entity may appeal an ALJ decision to the "Board" (Departmental Appeals Board) by filing a notice within:
column7: A. 15 days.B. 30 days.C. 60 days.D. 90 days.
column17: B. 30 days.
column22: Any party may appeal the decision of the ALJ to the Board within 30 days of service.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Civil Money Penalties (CMPs) and Enforcement: Management is reviewing the organization's liability for a breach caused by an employee's willful neglect. The breach was not corrected within 30 days.
column4: No enforcement action may be entertained by the Secretary unless it is commenced within how many years of the violation?
column7: A. 2 years.B. 5 years.C. 6 years.D. 10 years.
column17: C. 6 years.
column22: No action may be entertained unless commenced within 6 years from the date of the occurrence of the violation.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: The requirement to implement measures that ensure transmitted ePHI is not "improperly modified without detection" is the definition of:
column7: A. Encryption.B. Integrity Controls.C. Authentication.D. Access Control.
column17: B. Integrity Controls.
column22: Integrity controls (addressable) require security measures to ensure that electronically transmitted ePHI is not improperly modified without detection.
column42: Integrity controls and encryption for ePHI transmitted over electronic networks.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: Under the Transmission Security standard, the implementation of "Encryption" is:
column7: A. Required.B. Addressable.C. Conditional.D. Mandatory for all email.
column17: B. Addressable.
column22: Encryption under Transmission Security is an addressable implementation specification.
column42: Integrity controls and encryption for ePHI transmitted over electronic networks.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: Which standard requires "technical security measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over an electronic communications network"?
column7: A. Access Control.B. Transmission Security.C. Audit Controls.D. Integrity.
column17: B. Transmission Security.
column22: Transmission security requires technical measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over a network.
column42: Integrity controls and encryption for ePHI transmitted over electronic networks.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: To corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner WHILE AT REST, the organization should implement a:
column7: A. Transmission Integrity Control.B. Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI.C. Data Backup Plan.D. Termination Procedure.
column17: B. Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI.
column22: Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI (addressable) requires mechanisms to corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed.
column42: Policies and mechanisms to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction and to authenticate ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: If the organization decides NOT to encrypt a specific internal transmission, IT must:
column7: A. Document why it is not reasonable and implement an equivalent alternative measure.B. Pay a waiver fee to the Secretary.C. Obtain written permission from the patients.D. Use a non-standard transaction format instead.
column17: A. Document why it is not reasonable and implement an equivalent alternative measure.
column22: For addressable specifications, the entity must document non-implementation and implement an equivalent alternative if reasonable.
column42: Requirement to implement reasonable and appropriate security policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: The use of an "algorithmic process to transform data into a form in which there is a low probability of assigning meaning" is the definition of:
column7: A. Authentication.B. Encryption.C. Integrity.D. De-identification.
column17: B. Encryption.
column22: Encryption is an algorithmic process to transform data to a form with a low probability of meaning without a key.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: Ensuring that ePHI is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes is the definition of:
column7: A. Integrity.B. Availability.C. Confidentiality.D. Authorization.
column17: C. Confidentiality.
column22: Confidentiality is the property that data or information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: The property that data has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner is:
column7: A. Integrity.B. Availability.C. Confidentiality.D. Privacy.
column17: A. Integrity.
column22: Integrity means the property that data or information have not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: "Electronic protected health information" (ePHI) refers to PHI that is:
column7: A. Transmitted by electronic media.B. Maintained in electronic media.C. Both A and B.D. Only PHI that is encrypted.
column17: C. Both A and B.
column22: ePHI means PHI that is transmitted by or maintained in electronic media.
column42: Key definitions, including PHI, covered entity, and business associate.

column3: Scenario: Technical and Transmission Security: The IT department is configuring the security settings for the organization's local area network (LAN) and external data transmissions to cloud vendors.
column4: Which "Electronic Media" category includes the physical movement of removable digital memory cards containing PHI?
column7: A. Storage media.B. Transmission media.C. Both A and B.D. Neither, as physical movement is not electronic.
column17: B. Transmission media.
column22: Transmission media includes the physical movement of removable/transportable electronic storage media.
column42: Key definitions, including PHI, covered entity, and business associate.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: Ms. Elena has a right to receive an accounting of disclosures made in the:
column7: A. 3 years prior to the request.B. 6 years prior to the request.C. 10 years prior to the request.D. Entire history of the clinic's existence.
column17: B. 6 years prior to the request.
column22: An individual has a right to an accounting of disclosures made in the six years prior to the date of the request.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation of accountings.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: Which of the following disclosures is EXCLUDED from the accounting provided to Ms. Elena?
column7: A. Disclosures for public health purposes.B. Disclosures to carry out treatment, payment, and health care operations.C. Disclosures to health oversight agencies.D. Disclosures required by law.
column17: B. Disclosures to carry out treatment, payment, and health care operations.
column22: Disclosures for TPO (treatment, payment, and health care operations) are explicitly excluded from the accounting requirement.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: The clinic must act on Ms. Elena’s request for an accounting no later than:
column7: A. 30 days after receipt.B. 60 days after receipt.C. 90 days after receipt.D. 180 days after receipt.
column17: B. 60 days after receipt.
column22: The covered entity must act on the request for an accounting no later than 60 days after receipt of the request.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: If the clinic cannot provide the accounting within 60 days, it may extend the time by:
column7: A. An additional 15 days.B. An additional 30 days.C. An additional 60 days.D. As much time as is reasonable under the circumstances.
column17: B. An additional 30 days.
column22: The entity may extend the time to provide the accounting by no more than 30 days, provided it gives the individual a written statement of the reasons for delay.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: The first accounting provided to Ms. Elena in any 12-month period must be:
column7: A. Provided at a reasonable, cost-based fee.B. Without charge.C. Provided only if she is currently an active patient.D. Encrypted and mailed via certified mail.
column17: B. Without charge.
column22: The covered entity must provide the first accounting to an individual in any 12-month period without charge.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: For multiple disclosures to the SAME oversight agency for a single purpose, the accounting may simply provide:
column7: A. A link to the oversight agency's website.B. The info for the first disclosure, the frequency, and the date of the last disclosure.C. A generic statement that "oversight disclosures were made."D. The first and last disclosure dates only, without frequency info.
column17: B. The info for the first disclosure, the frequency, and the date of the last disclosure.
column22: Multiple disclosures to the same person/entity for a single purpose may be reported by providing the first instance's info, frequency, and the date of the last instance.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: If a Law Enforcement Official states that an accounting would be likely to impede their activities, the clinic MUST:
column7: A. Deny the accounting request permanently.B. Temporarily suspend the individual's right to an accounting.C. Notify Ms. Elena of the law enforcement request immediately.D. Charge a higher fee for the accounting.
column17: B. Temporarily suspend the individual's right to an accounting.
column22: An entity must temporarily suspend the right to an accounting if a law enforcement official provides a written statement that it would impede their activities.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: If the law enforcement suspension request is made ORALLY, the suspension is limited to:
column7: A. 7 days.B. 30 days.C. 60 days.D. Until a written statement is received.
column17: B. 30 days.
column22: An oral suspension request is limited to 30 days unless a written statement is submitted during that time.
column42: Right to an accounting, required elements, time frames, exclusions, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: The documentation of Ms. Elena's accounting request and the response must be retained for:
column7: A. 3 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. 50 years.
column17: B. 6 years.
column22: A covered entity must retain required documentation (like accountings of disclosures) for six years from the date of creation.
column42: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: Ms. Elena requests a formal accounting of disclosures of her PHI made by the clinic on 1 October 2024.
column4: To support accurate accountings of disclosures, startups should implement which Security Rule standard?
column7: A. Workstation Security.B. Device and Media Controls.C. Audit Controls.D. Contingency Planning.
column17: C. Audit Controls.
column22: Startups must implement audit logs (§ 164.312(b)) to support accounting accuracy.
column42: Mechanisms to record and examine system activity involving ePHI.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: Which de-identification method involves a person with "appropriate knowledge" determining the risk of re-identification is "very small"?
column7: A. Safe Harbor method.B. Expert Determination method.C. Minimum Necessary method.D. Administrative review method.
column17: B. Expert Determination method.
column22: Expert determination requires a person with appropriate knowledge to determine that the risk of re-identification is very small.
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: Under the Safe Harbor method, which of the following identifiers must be aggregated or removed?
column7: A. Month and day of birth.B. Year of birth.C. Year of death.D. Year of admission.
column17: A. Month and day of birth.
column22: Safe harbor removal includes all elements of dates (except year) for dates directly related to an individual, including birth date.
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: Which geographic element must be removed to meet the Safe Harbor de-identification standard?
column7: A. The State of residence.B. All geographic subdivisions smaller than a State (e.g., street address, city, precinct).C. All 5 digits of the ZIP code.D. The name of the country.
column17: B. All geographic subdivisions smaller than a State (e.g., street address, city, precinct).
column22: Safe harbor requires removing all geographic subdivisions smaller than a State, including street address, city, and ZIP codes (with limited exceptions).
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: A ZIP code's initial 3 digits may be retained under Safe Harbor ONLY if the unit formed by all ZIPs with those same digits contains more than:
column7: A. 10,000 people.B. 20,000 people.C. 50,000 people.D. 100,000 people.
column17: B. 20,000 people.
column22: The initial three digits of a ZIP code may be retained only if the geographic unit contains more than 20,000 people.
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: If the geographic unit for the initial 3 digits of a ZIP code contains 20,000 or FEWER people, those digits must be changed to:
column7: A. XXX.B. 000.C. 999.D. The ZIP code of the state capital.
column22: For geographic units containing 20,000 or fewer people, the initial three digits of the ZIP code must be changed to 000.
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: A "Limited Data Set" (LDS) may ONLY be used or disclosed for which purposes?
column7: A. Treatment, payment, or research.B. Research, public health, or health care operations.C. Marketing, fundraising, or legal services.D. Treatment and health oversight activities.
column17: B. Research, public health, or health care operations.
column22: A limited data set may be used or disclosed only for the purposes of research, public health, or health care operations.
column38: Limited data sets and data use agreements
column42: Conditions for using/disclosing limited data sets and required contents of data use agreements.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: An LDS is PHI that EXCLUDES which of the following identifiers?
column7: A. Full faces photographic images.B. City or Town.C. State.D. ZIP code.
column17: A. Full faces photographic images.
column22: A limited data set must exclude direct identifiers, including names and full-face photographic images.
column38: Limited data sets and data use agreements
column42: Conditions for using/disclosing limited data sets and required contents of data use agreements.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: A Data Use Agreement (DUA) for a Limited Data Set must require that the recipient:
column7: A. Not identify the information or contact the individuals.B. Encrypt the data with AES-256.C. Delete the data within 30 days of study completion.D. Pay a remuneration fee to the Secretary of HHS.
column17: A. Not identify the information or contact the individuals.
column22: A DUA must provide that the recipient will not identify the information or contact the individuals.
column38: Limited data sets and data use agreements
column42: Conditions for using/disclosing limited data sets and required contents of data use agreements.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: If an entity discovers a "pattern of activity" where an LDS recipient is violating their agreement, the entity MUST:
column7: A. Report the recipient to the FBI.B. Discontinue disclosure and report the problem to the Secretary.C. Retrain the recipient's workforce.D. Increase the fee for the dataset.
column17: B. Discontinue disclosure and report the problem to the Secretary.
column22: If reasonable steps to cure a breach are unsuccessful, the entity must discontinue disclosure and report to the Secretary.
column38: Limited data sets and data use agreements
column42: Conditions for using/disclosing limited data sets and required contents of data use agreements.

column3: Scenario: De-identification and Research: A health tech startup is providing a dataset to a researcher. They hire a statistician to ensure the data is not individually identifiable.
column4: De-identification "Safe Harbor" requires the removal of ALL ages over:
column22: All ages over 89 and elements indicative of such age must be removed or aggregated into a single category of age 90 or older.
column42: Standards for deidentifying PHI, creating limited data sets, and conditions for reidentification.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Identifiers: A healthcare provider is transitioning to a new billing system. They must ensure that all electronic claims include the correct unique identifiers for all parties involved in a standard transaction.
column4: Which standard unique health identifier must be used to identify a covered health care provider in all standard transactions?
column7: A. Social Security Number (SSN).B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).C. National Provider Identifier (NPI).D. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).
column17: C. National Provider Identifier (NPI).
column22: The standard unique health identifier for health care providers is the National Provider Identifier (NPI), which is a 10-position numeric identifier.
column42: Requirement to use the NPI for all standard transactions where a provider identifier is required.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Identifiers: A healthcare provider is transitioning to a new billing system. They must ensure that all electronic claims include the correct unique identifiers for all parties involved in a standard transaction.
column4: When a standard transaction requires identifying a person or entity as an employer, which identifier must a covered entity use?
column7: A. NPI.B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).C. Social Security Number (SSN).D. HPID.
column17: B. Employer Identification Number (EIN).
column22: The Secretary adopts the EIN, assigned by the Internal Revenue Service, as the standard unique employer identifier.
column42: Requirement to use the EIN to identify employers in standard transactions.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Identifiers: A healthcare provider is transitioning to a new billing system. They must ensure that all electronic claims include the correct unique identifiers for all parties involved in a standard transaction.
column4: A "Transaction" under HIPAA is specifically defined as the transmission of information between two parties to carry out which activities?
column7: A. Clinical research only.B. Marketing and fundraising only.C. Financial or administrative activities related to health care.D. Internal medical record auditing.
column17: C. Financial or administrative activities related to health care.
column22: A transaction is the transmission of information between two parties to carry out financial or administrative activities related to health care.
column42: Key definitions including Transaction and Business Associate.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Identifiers: A healthcare provider is transitioning to a new billing system. They must ensure that all electronic claims include the correct unique identifiers for all parties involved in a standard transaction.
column4: A health plan is prohibited from rejecting a standard transaction solely because it contains which type of information?
column7: A. Unencrypted ePHI.B. Invalid NPIs.C. Data elements not needed or used by the health plan.D. Demographic info about first-degree relatives.
column17: C. Data elements not needed or used by the health plan.
column22: A health plan may not reject a standard transaction on the basis that it contains data elements not needed or used by the health plan.
column42: Rules for health plans regarding the acceptance of standard transactions.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Identifiers: A healthcare provider is transitioning to a new billing system. They must ensure that all electronic claims include the correct unique identifiers for all parties involved in a standard transaction.
column4: When acting as a business associate, a health care clearinghouse is permitted to perform which function for a covered entity?
column7: A. De-identify PHI using only the Safe Harbor method.B. Translate a standard transaction into a nonstandard transaction for the CE.C. Disclose psychotherapy notes for payment without authorization.D. Waive the individual's right to an accounting.
column17: B. Translate a standard transaction into a nonstandard transaction for the CE.
column22: A clearinghouse acting as a BA may receive a standard transaction and translate it into a nonstandard transaction for transmission to the CE.
column42: Permissible activities for clearinghouses acting as business associates.

column3: Scenario: Transaction Standards: The billing department is verifying a patient's coverage before a major procedure. They are using an electronic system to communicate with the patient's health plan.
column4: An inquiry from a provider to a health plan to obtain information about an enrollee's benefits or coverage is defined as which transaction?
column7: A. Coordination of benefits.B. Referral certification and authorization.C. Eligibility for a health plan.D. Health care claim status.
column17: C. Eligibility for a health plan.
column22: This transaction is defined as the inquiry from a provider to a plan to obtain info about eligibility, coverage, or benefits for an enrollee.
column42: Definition and standards for the eligibility for a health plan transaction.

column3: Scenario: Transaction Standards: The billing department is verifying a patient's coverage before a major procedure. They are using an electronic system to communicate with the patient's health plan.
column4: When conducting a covered transaction, which version of a medical data code set (e.g., ICD-10) must a covered entity use?
column7: A. The version valid at the time the claim is paid.B. The version valid at the time the health care is furnished.C. The version valid at the time the transaction is initiated.D. Any version approved by the clearinghouse.
column17: B. The version valid at the time the health care is furnished.
column22: Covered entities must use medical data code sets that are valid at the time the health care is furnished.
column42: Requirement to use valid medical and nonmedical data code sets.

column3: Scenario: Transaction Standards: The billing department is verifying a patient's coverage before a major procedure. They are using an electronic system to communicate with the patient's health plan.
column4: Which identifier is used to uniquely identify health plans in standard transactions?
column7: A. NPI.B. EIN.C. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).D. Other Entity Identifier (OEID).
column17: C. Health Plan Identifier (HPID).
column22: The HPID is assigned by the Enumeration System to identify health plans in transactions for which a standard is adopted.
column42: Use and implementation requirements for the HPID.

column3: Scenario: Transaction Standards: The billing department is verifying a patient's coverage before a major procedure. They are using an electronic system to communicate with the patient's health plan.
column4: A "small health plan" is defined under HIPAA as a health plan with annual receipts of:
column7: A. $1 million or less.B. $5 million or less.C. $10 million or less.C. $50,000 or less.
column17: B. $5 million or less.
column22: A small health plan is defined as a health plan with annual receipts of $5 million or less.
column42: Key definitions including covered entity and small health plan.

column3: Scenario: Transaction Standards: The billing department is verifying a patient's coverage before a major procedure. They are using an electronic system to communicate with the patient's health plan.
column4: A covered entity is prohibited from entering into a trading partner agreement that would do which of the following?
column7: A. Specify the duties of each party in a transaction.B. Require encryption for all transmissions.C. Add any data elements or segments to the maximum defined data set.D. Limit disclosures to the minimum necessary for payment.
column17: C. Add any data elements or segments to the maximum defined data set.
column22: A CE must not enter into an agreement that adds data elements to the maximum defined data set or changes the meaning of a standard's specification.
column42: Prohibitions on modifying standard transaction elements via trading partner agreements.

column3: Scenario: Sensitive Data Management: A hospital's mental health wing maintains detailed records of patient counseling. A local university researcher requests access to these notes for a study on recovery patterns.
column4: A covered entity must obtain a specific individual authorization for any use or disclosure of psychotherapy notes EXCEPT for:
column7: A. Use by the originator for treatment.B. Use for the hospital’s own training programs for mental health students.C. Use by the entity to defend itself in a legal action brought by the individual.D. All of the above.
column17: D. All of the above.
column22: Authorisation is required for psychotherapy notes except for use by the originator for treatment, training programs, or legal defense by the entity.
column42: Specific requirements and exceptions for using or disclosing psychotherapy notes.

column3: Scenario: Sensitive Data Management: A hospital's mental health wing maintains detailed records of patient counseling. A local university researcher requests access to these notes for a study on recovery patterns.
column4: If a marketing communication involves financial remuneration to the covered entity from a third party, the authorization must:
column7: A. Be approved by an IRB.B. State that such remuneration is involved.C. Be documented and retained for 10 years.D. Include a summary of the patient's condition.
column17: B. State that such remuneration is involved.
column22: If marketing involves financial remuneration from a third party, the authorization must state that such remuneration is involved.
column42: Requirement for authorizations to disclose financial remuneration in marketing.

column3: Scenario: Sensitive Data Management: A hospital's mental health wing maintains detailed records of patient counseling. A local university researcher requests access to these notes for a study on recovery patterns.
column4: A "Sale of protected health information" is a disclosure where the CE directly or indirectly receives remuneration, but specifically EXCLUDES:
column7: A. Disclosures for public health purposes.B. Disclosures for treatment and payment purposes.C. Disclosures to the individual upon request.D. All of the above.
column17: D. All of the above.
column22: Sale of PHI excludes disclosures for public health, research (cost-based fee), treatment, payment, and to the individual.
column42: Definitions and exceptions to the prohibition on the sale of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Sensitive Data Management: A hospital's mental health wing maintains detailed records of patient counseling. A local university researcher requests access to these notes for a study on recovery patterns.
column4: A health plan is generally prohibited from using or disclosing which type of PHI for underwriting purposes?
column7: A. Psychotherapy notes.B. Billing records over 6 years old.C. Genetic information.D. De-identified data sets.
column17: C. Genetic information.
column22: A health plan shall not use or disclose PHI that is genetic information for underwriting purposes.
column42: Prohibition on using genetic information for underwriting by most health plans.

column3: Scenario: Patient Restrictions: Mr. Davis requested a restriction on his PHI, which the clinic agreed to. Later, he changes his mind and wants the restriction removed.
column4: A covered entity may terminate an agreed-upon restriction if the individual agrees to the termination:
column7: A. Orally, provided the oral agreement is documented.B. Only in writing with a notarized signature.C. By providing a new signed NPP.D. Only through a personal representative.
column17: A. Orally, provided the oral agreement is documented.
column22: A CE may terminate a restriction if the individual agrees in writing, requests it in writing, or orally agrees and the agreement is documented.
column42: Procedures for terminating agreed-upon restrictions on uses and disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Accounting and Retention: A patient requests a list of all times their data was shared with outside parties. The clinic must pull records and determine the appropriate time frame.
column4: An individual has a right to receive an accounting of disclosures made by a covered entity in the:
column7: A. 3 years prior to the request.B. 6 years prior to the request.C. 50 years following the individual's death.D. Entire duration of the patient-provider relationship.
column17: B. 6 years prior to the request.
column22: An individual has a right to an accounting of disclosures made in the six years prior to the date on which the accounting is requested.
column42: Individual right to receive a list of certain disclosures and the associated time frame.

column3: Scenario: Accounting and Retention: A patient requests a list of all times their data was shared with outside parties. The clinic must pull records and determine the appropriate time frame.
column4: Which type of disclosure is explicitly EXCLUDED from the accounting provided to an individual?
column7: A. Disclosures to a public health authority.B. Disclosures required by law.C. Disclosures to carry out treatment, payment, and health care operations.D. Disclosures to a coroner or medical examiner.
column17: C. Disclosures to carry out treatment, payment, and health care operations.
column22: Disclosures for treatment, payment, and health care operations (TPO) are excluded from the accounting requirement.
column42: List of disclosures that are exempt from the accounting requirement.

column3: Scenario: Accounting and Retention: A patient requests a list of all times their data was shared with outside parties. The clinic must pull records and determine the appropriate time frame.
column4: If a law enforcement official provides an ORAL statement that an accounting would impede their activities, the CE must suspend the right for:
column7: A. No longer than 7 days.B. No longer than 30 days.C. Until the end of the calendar year.D. The duration specified by the official in writing.
column17: B. No longer than 30 days.
column22: An oral statement from law enforcement requires a temporary suspension of no longer than 30 days unless a written statement is provided.
column42: Rules for suspending the right to an accounting due to law enforcement requests.

column3: Scenario: Accounting and Retention: A patient requests a list of all times their data was shared with outside parties. The clinic must pull records and determine the appropriate time frame.
column4: How long must a covered entity retain documentation of an accounting of disclosures provided to an individual?
column7: A. 3 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. 50 years.
column17: B. 6 years.
column22: A covered entity must retain required documentation (including accountings of disclosures) for six years from the date of its creation.
column42: Retention period for policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation.

column3: Scenario: Accounting and Retention: A patient requests a list of all times their data was shared with outside parties. The clinic must pull records and determine the appropriate time frame.
column4: For subsequent accounting requests within a 12-month period, the covered entity:
column7: A. Must provide them free of charge.B. Must deny the request.C. May impose a reasonable, cost-based fee.D. May require a court order.
column17: C. May impose a reasonable, cost-based fee.
column22: The first accounting in any 12-month period is free; a cost-based fee may be charged for subsequent requests within that period.
column42: Fee limitations for providing an accounting of disclosures.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment: The Security Official is following NIST SP 800-66r2 guidance to conduct the required HIPAA risk analysis. They are currently identifying threat events and vulnerabilities.
column4: Under the NIST guidance, "Risk Analysis" specifically refers to which HIPAA Security Rule requirement?
column7: A. Accurate and thorough assessment of threats and vulnerabilities to ePHI.B. Implementation of security measures to reduce risk.C. Periodic evaluation of security policies.D. Assignment of a security official.
column17: A. Accurate and thorough assessment of threats and vulnerabilities to ePHI.
column22: Risk analysis refers to the HIPAA requirement for an accurate and thorough assessment of the potential risks and vulnerabilities to ePHI.
column42: Accurate and thorough assessment of risks and vulnerabilities to ePHI.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment: The Security Official is following NIST SP 800-66r2 guidance to conduct the required HIPAA risk analysis. They are currently identifying threat events and vulnerabilities.
column4: After identified risks are assessed, the process of implementing security measures to reduce those risks to a "reasonable and appropriate" level is:
column7: A. Risk Analysis.B. Risk Management.C. Evaluation.D. Information System Activity Review.
column17: B. Risk Management.
column22: Risk Management is the implementation of security measures sufficient to reduce risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level.
column42: Security measures sufficient to reduce identified risks to a reasonable and appropriate level.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment: The Security Official is following NIST SP 800-66r2 guidance to conduct the required HIPAA risk analysis. They are currently identifying threat events and vulnerabilities.
column4: Ensuring that ePHI is "accessible and usable upon demand by an authorized person" is the definition of:
column7: A. Confidentiality.B. Integrity.C. Availability.D. Authorization.
column17: C. Availability.
column22: Availability is the property that data or information is accessible and usable upon demand by an authorized person.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment: The Security Official is following NIST SP 800-66r2 guidance to conduct the required HIPAA risk analysis. They are currently identifying threat events and vulnerabilities.
column4: The property that data or information has "not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner" is the definition of:
column7: A. Confidentiality.B. Integrity.C. Availability.D. Authentication.
column17: B. Integrity.
column22: Integrity is the property that data or information have not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment: The Security Official is following NIST SP 800-66r2 guidance to conduct the required HIPAA risk analysis. They are currently identifying threat events and vulnerabilities.
column4: "Confidentiality" is defined as the property that data or information is not made available or disclosed to:
column7: A. Business associates without a BAA.B. Unauthorized persons or processes.C. Any individual without signed authorization.D. Public health authorities.
column17: B. Unauthorized persons or processes.
column22: Confidentiality is the property that data or information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes.
column42: Overarching duty to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all ePHI.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment Preparation: The team is starting the "Prepare for the Assessment" step. They are mapping how ePHI moves through their startup.
column4: During preparation, the scope of a risk assessment must include all of the following EXCEPT:
column7: A. Physical boundaries of the facility.B. Logical boundaries (devices and media containing ePHI).C. Removable media and portable computing devices.D. Internal financial payroll records not containing patient data.
column17: D. Internal financial payroll records not containing patient data.
column22: Scope includes physical and logical boundaries of ePHI, including removable media and portable devices, regardless of location.
column42: Guidance on preparation for risk assessments, identifying ePHI flow and system inventory.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment Preparation: The team is starting the "Prepare for the Assessment" step. They are mapping how ePHI moves through their startup.
column4: When identifying threat sources, which of the following is an example of a "Human" threat source?
column7: A. Earthquake or flood.B. Inadvertent data entry or network-based attacks.C. Power surges or liquid leaks.D. Infrastructure failure.
column17: B. Inadvertent data entry or network-based attacks.
column22: Human threat sources include unintentional acts (data entry error) or deliberate actions (network attacks).
column42: Taxonomy of threat sources including human, natural, and environmental.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment Preparation: The team is starting the "Prepare for the Assessment" step. They are mapping how ePHI moves through their startup.
column4: A "vulnerability" is defined by NIST as which of the following?
column7: A. A circumstance that can have a negative impact on ePHI.B. A flaw or weakness that could be exploited by a threat source.C. The probability that a threat event is capable of causing harm.D. The magnitude of harm expected to result from a loss.
column17: B. A flaw or weakness that could be exploited by a threat source.
column22: Vulnerabilities are flaws or weaknesses in a system, procedures, or internal controls that could be exploited.
column42: Definitions of key terms like vulnerability, threat, and risk.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment Preparation: The team is starting the "Prepare for the Assessment" step. They are mapping how ePHI moves through their startup.
column4: The "Likelihood" rating in a risk assessment refers to the:
column7: A. Magnitude of harm to the organization.B. Probability that a threat event will exploit a vulnerability.C. Number of records compromised in a breach.D. Financial cost of a data breach.
column17: B. Probability that a threat event will exploit a vulnerability.
column22: Likelihood refers to the probability that a given threat event is capable of exploiting a given vulnerability to cause harm.
column42: Guidance on determining the likelihood of a threat exploiting a vulnerability.

column3: Scenario: NIST Risk Assessment Preparation: The team is starting the "Prepare for the Assessment" step. They are mapping how ePHI moves through their startup.
column4: "Impact" refers to the magnitude of harm expected to result from:
column7: A. The costs of a security audit.B. The loss of confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of ePHI.C. A failure to update the Notice of Privacy Practices.D. Any violation of a Business Associate Agreement.
column17: B. The loss of confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of ePHI.
column22: Impact is the magnitude of harm resulting from the loss of confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of ePHI.
column42: Guidance on determining the impact of a threat exploiting a vulnerability.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Risk Management: Startup leadership is defining its high-level stance on security risks to guide the IT team's remediation priorities.
column4: "Risk Appetite" is defined as the types and amount of risk that:
column7: A. The IT team is willing to manage daily.B. Senior leaders are willing to accept in pursuit of mission objectives.C. A health plan determines is acceptable for its enrollees.D. Is legally permitted by the Secretary of HHS.
column17: B. Senior leaders are willing to accept in pursuit of mission objectives.
column22: Risk appetite is declared at the enterprise level and provides a guidepost to the amount of risk senior leaders are willing to accept.
column42: Definitions of risk appetite and risk tolerance in organizational strategy.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Risk Management: Startup leadership is defining its high-level stance on security risks to guide the IT team's remediation priorities.
column4: "Risk Tolerance" differs from risk appetite because it represents:
column7: A. The specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite.B. The total number of security violations per year.C. The amount of insurance coverage the entity holds.D. The maximum duration of a system outage.
column17: A. The specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite.
column22: Risk tolerance represents the specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the overall risk appetite.
column42: Definitions of risk appetite and risk tolerance in organizational strategy.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Risk Management: Startup leadership is defining its high-level stance on security risks to guide the IT team's remediation priorities.
column4: If an unacceptable level of risk to ePHI cannot be adequately treated in a cost-effective manner, NIST suggests the risk should be:
column7: A. Accepted and documented.B. Transferred to a business associate.C. Avoided, potentially by redesigning systems or processes.D. Reported to the media.
column17: C. Avoided, potentially by redesigning systems or processes.
column22: If an unacceptable level of risk cannot be adequately treated cost-effectively, that risk should be avoided, which may require redesigning processes.
column42: Guidance on selecting security controls and handling unacceptable risk.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Risk Management: Startup leadership is defining its high-level stance on security risks to guide the IT team's remediation priorities.
column4: When must a "subsequent" Evaluation of security policies be performed?
column7: A. Only during a leap year.B. Every 90 days regardless of status.C. In response to environmental or operational changes affecting ePHI security.D. Only after a Civil Money Penalty has been imposed.
column17: C. In response to environmental or operational changes affecting ePHI security.
column22: Evaluations must be repeated periodically and subsequently in response to environmental or operational changes affecting ePHI security.
column42: Requirement for periodic technical and nontechnical evaluations.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Risk Management: Startup leadership is defining its high-level stance on security risks to guide the IT team's remediation priorities.
column4: The standard for "Assigned Security Responsibility" requires identifying a security official responsible for:
column7: A. Only the technical safeguards.B. Only the physical access logs.C. The development and implementation of the policies and procedures required by the Security Subpart.D. Fulfilling the duties of the Privacy Official.
column17: C. The development and implementation of the policies and procedures required by the Security Subpart.
column22: Assigned Security Responsibility requires identifying the security official responsible for the development and implementation of the policies and procedures required by this subpart.
column42: Designation of a security official responsible for Security Rule implementation.

column3: Scenario: Workforce and Access: The startup is implementing the "Workforce Security" standard and needs to ensure their policies align with the NIST implementation descriptions.
column4: The primary goal of "Workforce Security" is to ensure appropriate ePHI access and:
column7: A. Implement automatic logoff on all mobile devices.B. Prevent unauthorized access by those workforce members who do not have access rights.C. Maintain a record of all media movements.D. Verify the identity of the personal representative.
column17: B. Prevent unauthorized access by those workforce members who do not have access rights.
column22: Workforce Security requires implementing policies to ensure appropriate access for members and to prevent access for those without rights.
column42: Ensuring appropriate ePHI access and preventing unauthorized access.

column3: Scenario: Workforce and Access: The startup is implementing the "Workforce Security" standard and needs to ensure their policies align with the NIST implementation descriptions.
column4: When employment ends, which of the following is suggested by NIST as a part of a standard "Termination Procedure"?
column7: A. Providing the individual with a copy of their personnel file.B. Deactivating computer access accounts and facility access.C. Changing the Notice of Privacy Practices.D. Updating the risk appetite statement.
column17: B. Deactivating computer access accounts and facility access.
column22: Termination Procedures include deactivating computer accounts (user IDs/passwords) and facility access.
column42: Procedures for terminating access when employment or arrangements end.

column3: Scenario: Workforce and Access: The startup is implementing the "Workforce Security" standard and needs to ensure their policies align with the NIST implementation descriptions.
column4: If a health care clearinghouse is part of a larger organization, "Information Access Management" requires it to implement policies to:
column7: A. Share all ePHI with the larger organization for health care operations.B. Protect the ePHI of the clearinghouse from unauthorized access by the larger organization.C. Consolidate its risk assessment with the larger organization.D. Waive the requirement for unique user identification.
column17: B. Protect the ePHI of the clearinghouse from unauthorized access by the larger organization.
column22: Clearinghouses part of a larger organization must protect their ePHI from unauthorized access by the larger organization.
column42: Requirement to isolate clearinghouse functions within a larger organization.

column3: Scenario: Training and Malware: The IT team is developing the "Security Awareness and Training" program for the entire workforce.
column4: Providing "periodic security updates" to the workforce is the definition of which addressable implementation specification?
column7: A. Protection from Malicious Software.B. Log-in Monitoring.C. Password Management.D. Security Reminders.
column17: D. Security Reminders.
column22: Security Reminders are periodic security updates provided to the workforce.
column42: Requirement for periodic security updates known as security reminders.

column3: Scenario: Training and Malware: The IT team is developing the "Security Awareness and Training" program for the entire workforce.
column4: Training workforce members on the "importance of the timely application of system patches" primarily addresses which implementation specification?
column7: A. Transmission Security.B. Access Control.C. Protection from Malicious Software.D. Media Re-use.
column17: C. Protection from Malicious Software.
column22: Patching is crucial for protecting against malicious software and exploitation of vulnerabilities.
column42: Procedures for guarding against, detecting, and reporting malicious software.

column3: Scenario: Incidents and Contingency: The IT team is documenting their response to a server outage and preparing for future emergencies.
column4: A "Security Incident" is defined under HIPAA as the attempted or successful unauthorized access or:
column7: A. Any failure of a software update.B. Interference with system operations in an information system.C. Use of a non-standard transaction format.D. Refusal of a patient to sign an NPP.
column17: B. Interference with system operations in an information system.
column22: A security incident means the attempted or successful unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction of info or interference with system operations.
column42: Definition of a security incident.

column3: Scenario: Incidents and Contingency: The IT team is documenting their response to a server outage and preparing for future emergencies.
column4: The "Contingency Plan" standard requires policies for responding to emergencies that damage systems containing ePHI, specifically including:
column7: A. Fire, vandalism, system failure, and natural disaster.B. Any HIPAA violation by a business associate.C. Changes in a patient's insurance coverage.D. A workforce member's request for an accounting.
column17: A. Fire, vandalism, system failure, and natural disaster.
column22: The standard lists examples like fire, vandalism, system failure, and natural disasters as occurrences that damage systems.
column42: Policies for responding to occurrences that damage ePHI systems.

column3: Scenario: Incidents and Contingency: The IT team is documenting their response to a server outage and preparing for future emergencies.
column4: The addressable specification "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" requires the entity to:
column7: A. Maintain audit logs for 6 years.B. Assess the relative criticality of specific applications and data in support of other plan components.C. Encrypt all databases at rest.D. Terminate access for all contractors during an emergency.
column17: B. Assess the relative criticality of specific applications and data in support of other plan components.
column22: This specification involves identifying activities and material involving ePHI that are critical to business operations.
column42: Assessing relative criticality of applications and data for contingency planning.

column3: Scenario: Incidents and Contingency: The IT team is documenting their response to a server outage and preparing for future emergencies.
column4: The required standard to "create and maintain retrievable exact copies of electronic protected health information" is the:
column7: A. Disaster Recovery Plan.B. Data Backup Plan.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Facility Security Plan.
column17: B. Data Backup Plan.
column22: The Data Backup Plan standard requires establishing procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI.
column42: Requirement to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Incidents and Contingency: The IT team is documenting their response to a server outage and preparing for future emergencies.
column4: Establishing procedures to "enable continuation of critical business processes" while in emergency mode is the:
column7: A. Disaster Recovery Plan.B. Data Backup Plan.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Risk Management Plan.
column17: C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.
column22: The Emergency Mode Operation Plan requires procedures for the continuation of critical business processes to protect ePHI security in emergency mode.
column42: Procedures for critical process continuation during emergency mode.

column3: Scenario: Physical and Technical Controls: The startup is moving into a new office and setting up its local network and workstations.
column4: The standard for "Facility Access Controls" requires policies to limit physical access to systems and facilities while:
column7: A. Ensuring that properly authorized access is allowed.B. Allowing the media access during a crisis.C. Disclosing the floor plan in the NPP.D. Providing unique user IDs for all visitors.
column17: A. Ensuring that properly authorized access is allowed.
column22: Facility Access Controls require limiting physical access to systems and facilities while ensuring properly authorized access is allowed.
column42: Physical safeguards to limit facility access to ePHI systems.

column3: Scenario: Physical and Technical Controls: The startup is moving into a new office and setting up its local network and workstations.
column4: The "Workstation Use" standard specifically requires defining proper functions, the manner of performance, and the:
column7: A. Operating system version.B. Physical attributes of the surroundings.C. Encryption level of the local drive.D. Internet speed of the connection.
column17: B. Physical attributes of the surroundings.
column22: Workstation Use requires specifying functions, manner of performance, and physical attributes of the surroundings.
column42: Rules for appropriate functions and physical attributes of workstations.

column3: Scenario: Physical and Technical Controls: The startup is moving into a new office and setting up its local network and workstations.
column4: The required specification to address the "final disposition of electronic protected health information" is:
column7: A. Media Re-use.B. Accountability.C. Disposal.D. Data Backup and Storage.
column17: C. Disposal.
column22: Disposal is the required implementation specification for the final disposition of ePHI and/or the hardware/media it is stored on.
column42: Policies for the final disposition of ePHI and media.

column3: Scenario: Physical and Technical Controls: The startup is moving into a new office and setting up its local network and workstations.
column4: "Unique user identification" (Required) means the entity must assign a unique name and/or number for:
column7: A. Identifying and tracking user identity.B. Assigning billing codes.C. Identifying business associates.D. Authenticating the facility address.
column17: A. Identifying and tracking user identity.
column22: Unique user identification requires assigning a unique name/number for identifying and tracking user identity.
column42: Requirement to assign unique user IDs.

column3: Scenario: Physical and Technical Controls: The startup is moving into a new office and setting up its local network and workstations.
column4: "Transmission Security" requires technical measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI that is being transmitted over:
column7: A. The internal telephone network.B. An electronic communications network.C. Hard-copy courier services.D. Facsimile transmissions.
column17: B. An electronic communications network.
column22: Transmission Security requires technical measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI transmitted over electronic communication networks.
column42: Measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI during transmission.

column3: Scenario: Audit Inquiries and Management: A Covered Entity (CE) is selected for a Phase 2 OCR audit. Management must provide documentation of its personnel designations and verify consistency with the Audit Protocol requirements.
column4: According to the HHS Audit Protocol, "Management" specifically refers to the officials or persons designated for the implementation of:
column7: A. Financial audits only.B. Policies and procedures and other standards.C. Clinical treatment protocols.D. IT procurement strategies.
column14: B. Policies and procedures and other standards.
column22: The Audit Protocol defines management as the appropriate officials or persons designated by the entity for the implementation of policies, procedures, and other standards.
column42: OCR uses the audit program to assess HIPAA compliance efforts, examine mechanisms, and identify best practices.

column3: Scenario: Audit Inquiries and Management: A Covered Entity (CE) is selected for a Phase 2 OCR audit. Management must provide documentation of its personnel designations and verify consistency with the Audit Protocol requirements.
column4: When an auditor requests documentation of implementation that is unavailable, the entity must provide instances from:
column7: A. The current month only.B. Equivalent previous time periods to complete the sample.C. Future planned implementation dates.D. A different legal entity under common control.
column14: B. Equivalent previous time periods to complete the sample.
column22: If the requested number of documentations is not available, the entity must provide instances from equivalent previous time periods or a statement that none exist.
column42: Requirements for entities to provide specified documents and statements regarding documentation availability.

column3: Scenario: Audit Inquiries and Management: A Covered Entity (CE) is selected for a Phase 2 OCR audit. Management must provide documentation of its personnel designations and verify consistency with the Audit Protocol requirements.
column4: The standard for "Personnel Designations" requires the organization to designate a privacy official and which other specific role?
column7: A. A Chief Information Officer.B. A contact person or office for receiving complaints.C. A lead researcher for de-identification.D. A dedicated legal counsel for CMPs.
column14: B. A contact person or office for receiving complaints.
column22: A covered entity must designate a privacy official and a contact person or office responsible for receiving complaints and providing NPP information.
column42: Designation of a privacy official and a contact person/office for complaints and NPP inquiries.

column3: Scenario: Audit Inquiries and Management: A Covered Entity (CE) is selected for a Phase 2 OCR audit. Management must provide documentation of its personnel designations and verify consistency with the Audit Protocol requirements.
column4: Documentation of the personnel designations for the Privacy Official and contact person must be retained for:
column7: A. 2 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. 50 years after death.
column14: B. 6 years.
column22: Personnel designations must be documented and maintained for a period of six years.
column42: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column3: Scenario: Audit Inquiries and Management: A Covered Entity (CE) is selected for a Phase 2 OCR audit. Management must provide documentation of its personnel designations and verify consistency with the Audit Protocol requirements.
column4: Under the Security Rule, the "Assigned Security Responsibility" standard requires identifying a single security official responsible for:
column7: A. Only the technical safeguards.B. Only physical security plans.C. Development and implementation of Security Rule policies and procedures.D. Filing breach reports to the media.
column14: C. Development and implementation of Security Rule policies and procedures.
column22: The standard requires identifying the security official responsible for the development and implementation of the policies and procedures required by Subpart C.
column42: Designation of a security official responsible for Security Rule implementation.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Sanctions and Mitigation: Management discovers that a workforce member snooped into medical records. They must apply the sanction policy and mitigate any harmful effects of the disclosure.
column4: The CE must apply appropriate sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with privacy policies, EXCEPT in which situation?
column7: A. When the member is a volunteer.B. When the member is a whistleblower under § 164.502(j).C. When the member is a part-time contractor.D. When the violation involves fewer than 10 records.
column14: B. When the member is a whistleblower under § 164.502(j).
column22: The sanction standard does not apply to workforce members with respect to actions that meet the whistleblower or crime victim conditions.
column42: Duty to have and apply sanctions against workforce members who violate privacy or breach-related policies.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Sanctions and Mitigation: Management discovers that a workforce member snooped into medical records. They must apply the sanction policy and mitigate any harmful effects of the disclosure.
column4: To comply with the "Mitigation" standard, the organization must mitigate, to the extent practicable, harmful effects known to the CE caused by:
column7: A. Only the CE's own workforce.B. Only the CE's business associates.C. Either the CE or its business associate.D. Only intentional violations of the Privacy Rule.
column14: C. Either the CE or its business associate.
column22: The entity must mitigate any harmful effect known to the entity of a use or disclosure of PHI in violation of its policies by the entity or its business associate.
column42: Obligation to mitigate harmful effects from known improper uses/disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Sanctions and Mitigation: Management discovers that a workforce member snooped into medical records. They must apply the sanction policy and mitigate any harmful effects of the disclosure.
column4: Documentation of any sanctions applied against workforce members must be maintained for how many years?
column7: A. 3 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. Permanently in the personnel file.
column14: B. 6 years.
column22: Required documentation, including records of actions like sanctions, must be retained for six years from the date of creation or last effect.
column42: Requirements to maintain policies, procedures, and required privacy documentation for at least six years.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Sanctions and Mitigation: Management discovers that a workforce member snooped into medical records. They must apply the sanction policy and mitigate any harmful effects of the disclosure.
column4: If a workforce member is the victim of a criminal act and discloses limited PHI about the suspected perpetrator to law enforcement, this is:
column7: A. A violation requiring immediate sanction.B. Not considered a violation of the Privacy Rule.C. Permitted only if the victim obtains a court order.D. Permitted only for healthcare operations.
column14: B. Not considered a violation of the Privacy Rule.
column22: An entity is not considered to have violated HIPAA if a workforce member who is a crime victim discloses PHI about the suspected perpetrator to law enforcement.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Sanctions and Mitigation: Management discovers that a workforce member snooped into medical records. They must apply the sanction policy and mitigate any harmful effects of the disclosure.
column4: When a CE applies sanctions, the OCR audit protocol directs auditors to evaluate if the process is:
column7: A. Publicly disclosed in the media.B. Reasonable and appropriate and includes required steps and time periods.C. Approved by the individual who was the subject of the snooping.D. Consistent with state-mandated minimum penalties.
column14: B. Reasonable and appropriate and includes required steps and time periods.
column22: Auditors evaluate if sanction policies contain a reasonable process, including involved personnel, required steps, notification, and documentation.
column42: Requirement to apply sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Hybrid and Affiliated Entities: A large corporation has multiple divisions. Some perform HIPAA-covered functions (like a health plan), while others do not (like a retail division). Management is designating health care components.
column4: A "Hybrid Entity" is a single legal entity that performs both:
column7: A. Research and Treatment functions.B. Covered and non-covered functions.C. Payment and Health Care Operations only.D. Domestic and international healthcare.
column14: B. Covered and non-covered functions.
column22: A hybrid entity is a single legal entity whose business activities include both covered and non-covered functions and which designates healthcare components.
column42: Requirements for hybrid entities, affiliated covered entities, and documentation of designations.

column3: Scenario: Hybrid and Affiliated Entities: A large corporation has multiple divisions. Some perform HIPAA-covered functions (like a health plan), while others do not (like a retail division). Management is designating health care components.
column4: The Hybrid Entity must ensure that its health care component (HCC) does not disclose PHI to another component if Subpart E would prohibit it if they were:
column7: A. Under common control.B. Separate and distinct legal entities.C. Both business associates.D. Participating in an OHCA.
column14: B. Separate and distinct legal entities.
column22: The entity must ensure its HCC does not disclose PHI to another component in circumstances where Subpart E would prohibit it if they were separate and distinct legal entities.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Hybrid and Affiliated Entities: A large corporation has multiple divisions. Some perform HIPAA-covered functions (like a health plan), while others do not (like a retail division). Management is designating health care components.
column4: If two legally separate CEs are under common ownership or control, they may designate themselves as a(n):
column7: A. Hybrid Entity.B. Affiliated Covered Entity (ACE).C. Organized Health Care Arrangement (OHCA).D. Business Associate Group.
column14: B. Affiliated Covered Entity (ACE).
column22: Legally separate covered entities may designate themselves as a single affiliated covered entity if all are under common ownership or control.
column42: Requirements for hybrid entities and affiliated covered entities.

column3: Scenario: Hybrid and Affiliated Entities: A large corporation has multiple divisions. Some perform HIPAA-covered functions (like a health plan), while others do not (like a retail division). Management is designating health care components.
column4: "Common ownership" exists if an entity possesses an equity interest of what percentage in another entity?
column7: A. 1 percent.B. 5 percent or more.C. 50 percent or more.D. 100 percent.
column14: B. 5 percent or more.
column22: Common ownership exists if an entity or entities possess an ownership or equity interest of 5 percent or more in another entity.
column42: Key definitions, including PHI, covered entity, and business associate.

column3: Scenario: Hybrid and Affiliated Entities: A large corporation has multiple divisions. Some perform HIPAA-covered functions (like a health plan), while others do not (like a retail division). Management is designating health care components.
column4: A member of an Affiliated Covered Entity (ACE) is jointly and severally liable for a CMP for a violation of the ACE unless:
column7: A. The violation was unintentional.B. It is established that another member of the ACE was responsible.C. The ACE has fewer than 50 employees.D. The CE corrected the violation within 30 days.
column14: B. It is established that another member of the ACE was responsible.
column22: A member of an ACE is jointly and severally liable for a CMP unless it is established that another member was responsible for the violation.
column42: Factors considered in determining the amount of a civil money penalty.

column3: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Plan Sponsors: A company sponsors a Group Health Plan (GHP). Management must ensure that plan documents protect the ePHI used by the Plan Sponsor for administrative tasks.
column4: A GHP may disclose "Summary Health Information" to a Plan Sponsor for the purpose of:
column7: A. Marketing the Plan Sponsor's products.B. Modifying, amending, or terminating the group health plan.C. Employment-related performance reviews.D. Identifying candidates for new hires.
column14: B. Modifying, amending, or terminating the group health plan.
column22: A GHP may disclose summary health information for purposes of obtaining premium bids or modifying, amending, or terminating the plan.
column42: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Plan Sponsors: A company sponsors a Group Health Plan (GHP). Management must ensure that plan documents protect the ePHI used by the Plan Sponsor for administrative tasks.
column4: The GHP is prohibited from disclosing PHI to the Plan Sponsor for the purpose of:
column7: A. Plan administration functions.B. Employment-related actions or decisions.C. Enrollment or disenrollment information.D. Obtaining premium bids.
column14: B. Employment-related actions or decisions.
column22: Plan documents must restrict the Plan Sponsor from using PHI for employment-related actions or decisions.
column42: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Plan Sponsors: A company sponsors a Group Health Plan (GHP). Management must ensure that plan documents protect the ePHI used by the Plan Sponsor for administrative tasks.
column4: "Plan administration functions" refer to functions performed by the Plan Sponsor on behalf of the GHP and explicitly EXCLUDE:
column7: A. Claims processing.B. Quality assurance reviews.C. Functions in connection with any other benefit plan of the sponsor.D. Utilization review.
column14: C. Functions in connection with any other benefit plan of the sponsor.
column22: Plan administration functions exclude functions performed by the plan sponsor in connection with any other benefit or benefit plan of the sponsor.
column42: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI: OCR reviews policies and actual disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Plan Sponsors: A company sponsors a Group Health Plan (GHP). Management must ensure that plan documents protect the ePHI used by the Plan Sponsor for administrative tasks.
column4: Under the Security Rule, a GHP must ensure that Plan Sponsor agents to whom it provides ePHI agree to:
column7: A. Pay a fee for the information.B. Use the information only for treatment.C. Implement reasonable and appropriate security measures to protect the information.D. Delete the information within 30 days.
column14: C. Implement reasonable and appropriate security measures to protect the information.
column22: The GHP must ensure that any agent to whom it provides ePHI agrees to implement reasonable and appropriate security measures to protect the information.
column42: Security obligations imposed on plan sponsors receiving ePHI from group health plans.

column3: Scenario: Group Health Plans and Plan Sponsors: A company sponsors a Group Health Plan (GHP). Management must ensure that plan documents protect the ePHI used by the Plan Sponsor for administrative tasks.
column4: A health plan (except for certain long-term care issuers) is generally prohibited from using PHI that is what for underwriting purposes?
column7: A. Billing records.B. Psychotherapy notes.C. Genetic information.D. De-identified data sets.
column14: C. Genetic information.
column22: A health plan shall not use or disclose PHI that is genetic information for underwriting purposes.
column42: Prohibition on using or disclosing genetic information for underwriting by most health plans.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy and Changes in Law: The management team is reviewing its policies to ensure they are "reasonably designed" and responsive to changes in federal law.
column4: Policies and procedures must be reasonably designed taking into account the size of the entity and the:
column7: A. Type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.B. Number of years the entity has been in business.C. Percentage of the budget allocated to security.D. Geography of the patient population.
column14: A. Type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by the entity.
column22: Policies and procedures must be reasonably designed, taking into account the size and the type of activities that relate to PHI undertaken by a covered entity.
column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy and Changes in Law: The management team is reviewing its policies to ensure they are "reasonably designed" and responsive to changes in federal law.
column4: If a change in law necessitates a change to the CE's policies, the entity must:
column7: A. Wait for the next annual audit to update.B. Promptly document and implement the revised policy.C. Notify all individuals via certified mail.D. Only update if the change involves a Security Rule standard.
column14: B. Promptly document and implement the revised policy.
column22: Whenever there is a change in law that necessitates a change to policies or procedures, the CE must promptly document and implement the revised policy.
