column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy and Changes in Law: The management team is reviewing its policies to ensure they are "reasonably designed" and responsive to changes in federal law.
column4: To apply a change in a privacy practice to PHI created PRIOR to a notice revision, the entity must have:
column7: A. Obtained individual signatures on the new NPP.B. Reserved the right to make such a change in its Notice of Privacy Practices.C. Reported the change to the Secretary.D. Provided a 90-day grace period.
column14: B. Reserved the right to make such a change in its Notice of Privacy Practices.
column22: An entity may make changes effective for PHI created prior to the revision if it has included a statement reserving the right to make such a change in its NPP.
column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy and Changes in Law: The management team is reviewing its policies to ensure they are "reasonably designed" and responsive to changes in federal law.
column4: If an entity has NOT reserved its right to change a practice, it is bound by the NPP in effect with respect to PHI created:
column7: A. After the notice was revised.B. While such notice was in effect.C. Only during the first six years of operations.D. Only if the individual has not revoked authorization.
column14: B. While such notice was in effect.
column22: If the right was not reserved, the CE is bound by the privacy practices stated in the notice with respect to PHI created or received while such notice was in effect.
column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Strategic Policy and Changes in Law: The management team is reviewing its policies to ensure they are "reasonably designed" and responsive to changes in federal law.
column4: A covered entity may change a privacy practice and its related policies AT ANY TIME, provided that the change:
column7: A. Does not materially affect the content of the NPP.B. Is approved by the CEO.C. Is consistent with the Minimum Necessary rule.D. Is documented and complies with Subpart E standards.
column14: D. Is documented and complies with Subpart E standards.
column22: A CE may make other changes to policies at any time, provided the policy complies with Subpart E and is documented prior to the change.
column42: Requirement to implement, document, and update privacy policies and procedures.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement and Burden of Persuasion: In a formal legal proceeding regarding a HIPAA violation, management and legal counsel review the rules for burden of proof and persuasion.
column4: In any HIPAA administrative hearing, the burden of persuasion is judged by which standard?
column7: A. Beyond a reasonable doubt.B. Clear and convincing evidence.C. A preponderance of the evidence.D. Reasonable cause.
column14: C. A preponderance of the evidence.
column22: The burden of persuasion in a hearing will be judged by a preponderance of the evidence.
column42: Standards and procedures for administrative hearings before an ALJ.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement and Burden of Persuasion: In a formal legal proceeding regarding a HIPAA violation, management and legal counsel review the rules for burden of proof and persuasion.
column4: The Respondent (the CE or BA) carries the "burden of persuasion" with respect to:
column7: A. Identifying affected individuals.B. Affirmative defenses and challenges to the penalty amount.C. The existence of aggravating factors.D. The statutory basis for the penalty.
column14: B. Affirmative defenses and challenges to the penalty amount.
column22: The respondent has the burden of persuasion regarding affirmative defenses and challenges to the amount of a proposed penalty.
column42: Standards and procedures for administrative hearings before an ALJ.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement and Burden of Persuasion: In a formal legal proceeding regarding a HIPAA violation, management and legal counsel review the rules for burden of proof and persuasion.
column4: Which party carries the "burden of persuasion" regarding issues of liability?
column7: A. The Respondent.B. The Complainant.C. The Secretary.D. The Administrative Law Judge.
column14: C. The Secretary.
column22: The Secretary has the burden of going forward and the burden of persuasion with respect to all other issues, including issues of liability.
column42: Standards and procedures for administrative hearings before an ALJ.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement and Burden of Persuasion: In a formal legal proceeding regarding a HIPAA violation, management and legal counsel review the rules for burden of proof and persuasion.
column4: If the Secretary relies on a statistical sampling study as evidence of the number of violations, this constitutes:
column7: A. Irrefutable evidence.B. Prima facie evidence.C. Hearsay evidence.D. Privileged information.
column14: B. Prima facie evidence.
column22: A statistical sampling study, if valid, constitutes prima facie evidence of the number of violations and material factors.
column42: Standards and procedures for administrative hearings before an ALJ.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement and Burden of Persuasion: In a formal legal proceeding regarding a HIPAA violation, management and legal counsel review the rules for burden of proof and persuasion.
column4: Once the Secretary makes a prima facie case with sampling, the burden of going forward shifts to the Respondent to:
column7: A. Pay the penalty immediately.B. Appeal to the Supreme Court.C. Produce evidence reasonably calculated to rebut the findings.D. Request a new Privacy Official.
column14: C. Produce evidence reasonably calculated to rebut the findings.
column22: Once a prima facie case is made, the burden shifts to the respondent to produce evidence reasonably calculated to rebut the findings.
column42: Standards and procedures for administrative hearings before an ALJ.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contractual Details: Management reviews the mandatory provisions of their Business Associate Agreements (BAAs) to ensure they cover all required "Implementation Specifications."
column4: The BAA must provide that the BA will not use or further disclose PHI other than as permitted by the contract or as:
column7: A. Required by the BA's board of directors.B. Required by law.C. Requested by the BA's subcontractors.D. Requested by the media.
column14: B. Required by law.
column22: The contract must provide that the BA will not use PHI other than as permitted or required by the contract or as required by law.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contractual Details: Management reviews the mandatory provisions of their Business Associate Agreements (BAAs) to ensure they cover all required "Implementation Specifications."
column4: The BAA may permit the BA to use PHI to carry out the:
column7: A. Marketing efforts of the CE.B. Legal responsibilities of the business associate.C. Fundraising activities of the BA's parent company.D. Sale of PHI for research remuneration.
column14: B. Legal responsibilities of the business associate.
column22: The contract may permit the BA to use PHI if necessary to carry out the legal responsibilities of the business associate.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contractual Details: Management reviews the mandatory provisions of their Business Associate Agreements (BAAs) to ensure they cover all required "Implementation Specifications."
column4: If the BA discloses PHI to a person for its own management purposes, the BA must obtain reasonable assurances that the PHI will be:
column7: A. Encrypted at rest.B. Held confidentially.C. Returned to the CE within 60 days.D. De-identified via the Safe Harbor method.
column14: B. Held confidentially.
column22: The BA must obtain reasonable assurances from the recipient that the PHI will be held confidentially and used only as required by law or for its disclosed purpose.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contractual Details: Management reviews the mandatory provisions of their Business Associate Agreements (BAAs) to ensure they cover all required "Implementation Specifications."
column4: The BAA must require the BA to report to the CE any use or disclosure NOT provided for by the contract, including:
column7: A. All phishing attempts.B. Breaches of unsecured PHI as required by § 164.410.C. Any changes in the BA's workforce.D. Successful login attempts by authorized users.
column14: B. Breaches of unsecured PHI as required by § 164.410.
column22: The contract must require the BA to report any use or disclosure not provided for by the contract, including breaches of unsecured PHI.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contractual Details: Management reviews the mandatory provisions of their Business Associate Agreements (BAAs) to ensure they cover all required "Implementation Specifications."
column4: If a CE and its BA are BOTH governmental entities, they may comply with the BAA standard by entering into a:
column7: A. Verbal handshake agreement.B. Trading Partner Agreement.C. Memorandum of Understanding (MOU).D. Joint Notice of Privacy Practices.
column14: C. Memorandum of Understanding (MOU).
column22: If both are governmental entities, they may comply by entering into an MOU that accomplishes the objectives of the BAA standard.
column42: Privacy requirements to disclose PHI to BAs only under compliant contracts.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Requirements and Complaints: Management reviews the required process for handling complaints regarding privacy and breach notification policies.
column4: The "Complaints" standard requires the CE to provide a process for individuals to make complaints concerning:
column7: A. The CE's clinical diagnosis.B. The CE's compliance with privacy or breach notification policies.C. The CE's billing rates.D. The wait times at the clinic.
column14: B. The CE's compliance with privacy or breach notification policies.
column22: A CE must provide a process for complaints concerning the CE's policies and procedures required by Subparts E and D or its compliance with them.
column42: Requirement to provide a process to receive complaints about privacy/breach compliance.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Requirements and Complaints: Management reviews the required process for handling complaints regarding privacy and breach notification policies.
column4: The CE is REQUIRED to document ALL complaints received and their:
column7: A. Financial impact.B. Disposition, if any.C. Disclosure to the media.D. Associated encryption keys.
column14: B. Disposition, if any.
column22: A CE must document all complaints received and their disposition, if any.
column42: Requirement to provide a process to receive complaints about privacy/breach compliance.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Requirements and Complaints: Management reviews the required process for handling complaints regarding privacy and breach notification policies.
column4: A CE is prohibited from requiring an individual to do what as a condition of receiving treatment or benefits?
column7: A. Sign the Notice of Privacy Practices.B. Waive their rights to complain to the Secretary.C. Provide a unique user identifier.D. Accept the use of a business associate.
column14: B. Waive their rights to complain to the Secretary.
column22: A CE may not require individuals to waive their rights under § 160.306, Subpart E, or Subpart D as a condition of treatment, payment, or benefits.
column42: Prohibition on requiring individuals to waive their right to complain to HHS.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Requirements and Complaints: Management reviews the required process for handling complaints regarding privacy and breach notification policies.
column4: The "Antiretaliation" standard prohibits a CE from taking retaliatory action against an individual for:
column7: A. Requesting an entire medical record.B. Filing a complaint under the HIPAA rules.C. Refusing to provide genetic information.D. Revoking an authorization after action was taken in reliance.
column14: B. Filing a complaint under the HIPAA rules.
column22: A CE may not intimidate or take retaliatory action against any individual for exercising any right or participating in any process provided for by HIPAA, including filing a complaint.
column42: Prohibition on intimidating or retaliatory acts against individuals for exercising HIPAA rights.

column3: Scenario: Administrative Requirements and Complaints: Management reviews the required process for handling complaints regarding privacy and breach notification policies.
column4: The CE must maintain documentation sufficient to meet its "Burden of Proof" under which provision?
column7: A. § 164.506 (TPO).B. § 164.414(b) (Breach Notification).C. § 162.923 (Transactions).D. § 164.508 (Authorizations).
column14: B. § 164.414(b) (Breach Notification).
column22: A CE must maintain documentation sufficient to meet its burden of proof under § 164.414(b).
column42: Burden of proof to show notifications were made or not required.

column3: Scenario: Transition and Compliance Dates: Management is assessing their adherence to the initial and modified HIPAA compliance dates.
column4: A "Small Health Plan" is defined as a health plan with annual receipts of:
column7: A. $1 million or less.B. $5 million or less.C. $10 million or less.D. $50,000 or less.
column14: B. $5 million or less.
column22: Small health plan means a health plan with annual receipts of $5 million or less.
column42: Key definitions, including PHI, covered entity, and business associate.

column3: Scenario: Transition and Compliance Dates: Management is assessing their adherence to the initial and modified HIPAA compliance dates.
column4: The compliance date for most covered entities to initially implement the Privacy Rule (Subpart E) was:
column7: A. April 14, 2001.B. April 14, 2003.C. April 14, 2004.D. April 20, 2005.
column14: B. April 14, 2003.
column22: A covered health care provider, health care clearinghouse, and large health plans were required to comply by April 14, 2003.
column42: Compliance dates for initial implementation of the privacy standards.

column3: Scenario: Transition and Compliance Dates: Management is assessing their adherence to the initial and modified HIPAA compliance dates.
column4: Small Health Plans were granted an additional year to comply with the initial Privacy Rule, with a deadline of:
column7: A. April 14, 2003.B. April 14, 2004.C. April 14, 2005.D. April 20, 2006.
column14: B. April 14, 2004.
column22: Small health plans were required to comply with initial Privacy Rule standards by April 14, 2004.
column42: Compliance dates for initial implementation of the privacy standards.

column3: Scenario: Transition and Compliance Dates: Management is assessing their adherence to the initial and modified HIPAA compliance dates.
column4: The Secretary may adopt a modification to a standard no more frequently than once every:
column7: A. 6 months.B. 12 months.C. 2 years.D. 6 years.
column14: B. 12 months.
column22: The Secretary may adopt a modification to a standard or implementation specification no more frequently than once every 12 months.
column42: Rules regarding the adoption and frequency of modifications to standards.

column3: Scenario: Transition and Compliance Dates: Management is assessing their adherence to the initial and modified HIPAA compliance dates.
column4: For modifications to standards effective AFTER January 25, 2013, CEs/BAs must comply no later than:
column7: A. 60 days from the effective date.B. 180 days from the effective date.C. 1 year from the effective date.D. The end of the calendar year.
column14: B. 180 days from the effective date.
column22: For modified standards effective after January 25, 2013, entities must comply no later than 180 days from the effective date.
column42: Compliance dates for implementation of modified standards.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions and Operating Rules: The billing department is reviewing the technical definitions of "Standard Transactions" to ensure electronic submissions are compliant.
column4: A "Standard Transaction" is defined as a transaction that complies with an applicable standard AND:
column7: A. A patient authorization.B. Associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.C. The Minimum Necessary rule.D. A Business Associate Agreement.
column14: B. Associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column22: A standard transaction complies with an applicable standard and associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column42: Definition of standard transactions and operating rules.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions and Operating Rules: The billing department is reviewing the technical definitions of "Standard Transactions" to ensure electronic submissions are compliant.
column4: "Operating Rules" are defined as the necessary business rules for the electronic exchange of info that are:
column7: A. Defined by the Privacy Rule.B. NOT defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.C. Defined by the trading partner agreement.D. Mandated by the individual.
column14: B. NOT defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.
column22: Operating rules are necessary business rules for electronic exchange not defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.
column42: Definition of operating rules for financial and administrative activities.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions and Operating Rules: The billing department is reviewing the technical definitions of "Standard Transactions" to ensure electronic submissions are compliant.
column4: A "Data Element" is defined under the Administrative Simplification rules as:
column7: A. A complete medical record.B. The smallest named unit of information in a transaction.C. A set of eighteen identifiers.D. An electronic memory card.
column14: B. The smallest named unit of information in a transaction.
column22: Data element means the smallest named unit of information in a transaction.
column42: Key definitions related to transactions and data standards.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions and Operating Rules: The billing department is reviewing the electronic claim layout for institutional claims.
column4: The implementation specifications for the ASC X12N 837 standard for Institutional health care claims are:
column7: A. Optional layouts.B. Incorporated by reference into the regulations.C. Only used for small health plans.D. Only used for dental claims.
column14: B. Incorporated by reference into the regulations.
column22: The implementation specifications for standard transactions like the ASC X12N 837 are incorporated by reference.
column42: Availability of implementation specifications and operating rules.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions and Operating Rules: The billing department is reviewing the electronic claim layout for institutional claims.
column4: A covered entity is prohibited from using any code or data elements that are marked how in the standard's implementation spec?
column7: A. "Optional."B. "Required."C. "Not used."D. "Sensitive."
column14: C. "Not used."
column22: A CE must not use any code or data elements marked "not used" in the standard's implementation specification.
column42: Prohibitions on using non-standard codes or data elements.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Underwriting: A group health plan receives genetic test results for a new applicant. The underwriting team wants to use this data to determine the applicant's premium rate.
column4: Is the health plan permitted to use the genetic information for this purpose?
column7: A. Yes, provided the applicant signs an authorization.B. No, health plans are prohibited from using genetic information for underwriting purposes.C. Yes, if the information is restricted to a limited data set.D. No, unless the information is needed for treatment.
column16: B. No, health plans are prohibited from using genetic information for underwriting purposes.
column21: Notwithstanding other provisions, a health plan (with limited exceptions) shall not use or disclose PHI that is genetic information for underwriting purposes, including premium adjustments.
column46: Prohibition on using or disclosing genetic information for underwriting by most health plans; OCR audits underwriting practices.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Underwriting: A group health plan receives genetic test results for a new applicant. The underwriting team wants to use this data to determine the applicant's premium rate.
column4: According to the HIPAA definition, "Genetic Information" includes information about an individual’s genetic tests and:
column7: A. Their current age.B. Their blood type.C. The manifestation of a disease in family members.D. Their religious affiliation.
column16: C. The manifestation of a disease in family members.
column21: Genetic information includes genetic tests of the individual or family members, and the manifestation of a disease or disorder in family members.
column46: Key definitions, including Genetic Information.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Underwriting: A group health plan receives genetic test results for a new applicant. The underwriting team wants to use this data to determine the applicant's premium rate.
column4: Underwriting purposes include rules for determining eligibility, premium amounts, and:
column7: A. Coordination of treatment with doctors.B. Application of pre-existing condition exclusions.C. Marketing wellness apps to the individual.D. Verifying the individual’s identity.
column16: B. Application of pre-existing condition exclusions.
column21: Underwriting purposes include eligibility rules, premium computation, and the application of any pre-existing condition exclusion.
column46: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Underwriting: A group health plan receives genetic test results for a new applicant. The underwriting team wants to use this data to determine the applicant's premium rate.
column4: "Genetic Information" specifically EXCLUDES which of the following identifiers?
column7: A. DNA analysis.B. Presence of a genetic mutation.C. Sex or age of the individual.D. Family medical history.
column16: C. Sex or age of the individual.
column21: Genetic information excludes information about the sex or age of any individual.
column46: Key definitions, including Genetic Information.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Underwriting: A group health plan receives genetic test results for a new applicant. The underwriting team wants to use this data to determine the applicant's premium rate.
column4: Does "Underwriting purposes" include a determination of medical appropriateness for a requested benefit?
column7: A. Yes, medical appropriateness is part of the rating process.B. No, underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness.C. Only if the cost of the benefit exceeds $5,000.D. Only if a business associate performs the review.
column16: B. No, underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness.
column21: Underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness where an individual seeks a benefit under the plan.
column46: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Denial of Access Review: A clinician determines that granting a patient access to their records is "reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety" of the patient. The patient requests a review of this denial.
column4: This specific ground for denial is classified under HIPAA as a:
column7: A. Unreviewable ground for denial.B. Reviewable ground for denial.C. Violation of the HITECH Act.D. Permitted healthcare operation.
column16: B. Reviewable ground for denial.
column21: A determination that access is reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety of the individual is a reviewable ground for denial.
column46: Conditions for denying access, processes for reviewable and nonreviewable denials, and documentation.

column3: Scenario: Denial of Access Review: A clinician determines that granting a patient access to their records is "reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety" of the patient. The patient requests a review of this denial.
column4: Who must perform the review of the denial of access?
column7: A. The CEO of the organization.B. A licensed health care professional designated as a reviewing official who did not participate in the original decision.C. The Secretary of HHS.D. An independent third-party arbitrator.
column16: B. A licensed health care professional designated as a reviewing official who did not participate in the original decision.
column21: If access is denied on reviewable grounds, the individual has the right to a review by a licensed healthcare professional who did not participate in the original decision.
column46: Requirement to have denials reviewed by a designated official.

column3: Scenario: Denial of Access Review: A clinician determines that granting a patient access to their records is "reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety" of the patient. The patient requests a review of this denial.
column4: When access is denied to one part of a record based on reviewable grounds, the organization must still:
column7: A. Provide an accounting of all researchers who saw that part.B. Give the individual access to any other PHI requested that is not subject to denial.C. Delete that part of the record permanently.D. Report the patient to law enforcement.
column16: B. Give the individual access to any other PHI requested that is not subject to denial.
column21: The covered entity must, to the extent possible, give the individual access to any other PHI requested after excluding the information for which there is a ground to deny access.
column46: Duty to provide access to partial records if only some information is excluded.

column3: Scenario: Denial of Access Review: A clinician determines that granting a patient access to their records is "reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety" of the patient. The patient requests a review of this denial.
column4: If a patient's personal representative requests access, and a professional determines it is reasonably likely to cause "substantial harm" to the patient, this is:
column7: A. An unreviewable ground for denial.B. A reviewable ground for denial.C. A mandatory disclosure requirement.D. A breach of the BAA.
column16: B. A reviewable ground for denial.
column21: Denial of access to a personal representative based on a judgment that access is likely to cause substantial harm to the individual is a reviewable ground.
column46: Conditions for denying access to personal representatives.

column3: Scenario: Denial of Access Review: A clinician determines that granting a patient access to their records is "reasonably likely to endanger the life or physical safety" of the patient. The patient requests a review of this denial.
column4: The written denial must contain the basis for the decision and:
column7: A. A full copy of the clinician’s psychiatric profile.B. A description of how the individual may complain to the CE or the Secretary.C. A waiver of the individual’s right to an accounting.D. The encryption keys for the remaining records.
column16: B. A description of how the individual may complain to the CE or the Secretary.
column21: A written denial must include the basis, review rights (if applicable), and a description of how to file a complaint with the CE or the Secretary.
column46: Required content of written denials.

column3: Scenario: Security Risk Assessment (NIST): An IT Specialist is identifying "Threat Sources" as part of the annual risk assessment for the startup's database.
column4: According to the sources, a "Human" threat source can include which of the following?
column7: A. Earthquakes and landslides.B. Inadvertent data entry or accidental deletions.C. Liquid leaks and environmental pollution.D. Power surges from the local grid.
column16: B. Inadvertent data entry or accidental deletions.
column21: Human threat sources include both unintentional acts (like data entry errors) and deliberate actions.
column46: Taxonomy of threat sources including human, natural, and environmental.

column3: Scenario: Security Risk Assessment (NIST): An IT Specialist is identifying "Threat Sources" as part of the annual risk assessment for the startup's database.
column4: A "Vulnerability" is specifically defined in the NIST guidance as:
column7: A. A circumstance that can have a negative impact on ePHI.B. A flaw or weakness that could be exploited by a threat source.C. The magnitude of harm expected from a loss.D. An intentional act of malicious hacking.
column16: B. A flaw or weakness that could be exploited by a threat source.
column21: A vulnerability is a flaw or weakness in a system, procedures, or internal controls that could be exploited by a threat source.
column46: Definitions of key terms like vulnerability and threat.

column3: Scenario: Security Risk Assessment (NIST): An IT Specialist is identifying "Threat Sources" as part of the annual risk assessment for the startup's database.
column4: When determining "Likelihood" in a risk assessment, the IT specialist is assessing the:
column7: A. Financial cost of a data breach.B. Probability that a threat event will exploit a vulnerability.C. Number of years the entity has been compliant.D. Magnitude of harm to the nation.
column16: B. Probability that a threat event will exploit a vulnerability.
column21: Likelihood refers to the probability that a given threat event is capable of exploiting a given vulnerability to cause harm.
column46: Guidance on determining the likelihood of a threat exploiting a vulnerability.

column3: Scenario: Security Risk Assessment (NIST): An IT Specialist is identifying "Threat Sources" as part of the annual risk assessment for the startup's database.
column4: The "Impact" of a threat event is the magnitude of harm expected to result from the loss of which properties of ePHI?
column7: A. Accuracy, Redundancy, and Speed.B. Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.C. Profitability, Reputation, and Market Share.D. Identity, Verification, and Authorization.
column16: B. Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.
column21: Impact is the magnitude of harm resulting from the loss of confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of ePHI.
column46: Guidance on determining the impact of a threat exploiting a vulnerability.

column3: Scenario: Security Risk Assessment (NIST): An IT Specialist is identifying "Threat Sources" as part of the annual risk assessment for the startup's database.
column4: The final "Risk" rating is typically calculated as a function of which two elements?
column7: A. Budget and Software capabilities.B. Likelihood and Impact.C. Size and Complexity of the entity.D. Employee count and Patient volume.
column16: B. Likelihood and Impact.
column21: Risk refers to the extent to which an entity is threatened, typically a function of likelihood and impact calculations.
column46: Method for determining the level of risk to ePHI.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Management: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to perform data transmission services. The subcontractor discovers a security incident involving the CE's ePHI.
column4: The subcontractor is required to report the security incident to:
column7: A. The Secretary of HHS directly.B. The Covered Entity (CE) only.C. The Business Associate (BA) who hired them.C. The media, if it affects more than 500 people.
column16: C. The Business Associate (BA) who hired them.
column21: Subcontractors must report security incidents and breaches to the business associate that hired them, in the same manner as BAs report to CEs.
column46: Requirements for BAs to ensure subcontractors report incidents.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Management: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to perform data transmission services. The subcontractor discovers a security incident involving the CE's ePHI.
column4: A Business Associate is liable for a Civil Money Penalty (CMP) for a violation based on the act or omission of:
column7: A. Only its own CEO.B. Only its internal IT staff.C. Any agent, including a workforce member or subcontractor, acting within scope.D. Only the Covered Entity.
column16: C. Any agent, including a workforce member or subcontractor, acting within scope.
column21: A business associate is liable for a CMP based on the act or omission of any agent, including a workforce member or subcontractor.
column46: Liability of BAs for acts of their agents and subcontractors.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Management: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to perform data transmission services. The subcontractor discovers a security incident involving the CE's ePHI.
column4: The contract between a BA and its subcontractor must ensure the subcontractor agrees to comply with:
column7: A. Only the marketing restrictions of the CE.B. The applicable requirements of the Security Rule (Subpart C).C. Only the rules regarding dental claims.D. The internal financial audits of the BA.
column16: B. The applicable requirements of the Security Rule (Subpart C).
column21: Contracts must provide that subcontractors will comply with the applicable requirements of Subpart C (Security Standards).
column46: Assurance that subcontractors safeguard ePHI.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Management: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to perform data transmission services. The subcontractor discovers a security incident involving the CE's ePHI.
column4: If a BA discovers that its subcontractor has a "pattern of activity" that violates their contract, the BA must:
column7: A. Report the CE to the Secretary.B. Take reasonable steps to cure the breach, and terminate if unsuccessful.C. Pay the subcontractor's CMP.D. De-identify all data immediately.
column16: B. Take reasonable steps to cure the breach, and terminate if unsuccessful.
column21: A business associate must take reasonable steps to cure a breach by a subcontractor and terminate the arrangement if unsuccessful.
column46: Duty to remediate or terminate subcontractor relationships in case of violations.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Management: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to perform data transmission services. The subcontractor discovers a security incident involving the CE's ePHI.
column4: Are subcontractors of a business associate directly liable for compliance with the HIPAA Security Rule?
column7: A. No, they are only contractually liable to the BA.B. Yes, subcontractors are included in the definition of a business associate and are directly liable.C. Only if the breach affects 500 or more residents.D. Only if the Covered Entity signs the subcontractor's contract.
column16: B. Yes, subcontractors are included in the definition of a business associate and are directly liable.
column21: The definition of business associate includes a subcontractor that creates, receives, maintains, or transmits PHI on behalf of a BA.
column46: Key definitions, including Business Associate and Subcontractor.

column3: Scenario: Audit Log Review: The Security Official at a health clinic is establishing procedures for the "Information System Activity Review" to protect patient data from internal misuse.
column4: Which of the following is an example of a "record of information system activity" that MUST be regularly reviewed?
column7: A. The Notice of Privacy Practices.B. Audit logs, access reports, and security incident tracking reports.C. The organization's quarterly revenue reports.D. Employee vacation schedules.
column16: B. Audit logs, access reports, and security incident tracking reports.
column21: The specification requires regular review of audit logs, access reports, and security incident tracking reports.
column46: Required regular review of system activity involving ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Audit Log Review: The Security Official at a health clinic is establishing procedures for the "Information System Activity Review" to protect patient data from internal misuse.
column4: When reviewing audit logs, the IT team should specifically look for:
column7: A. The name of the software vendor.B. The internet speed during the session.C. Attempted or successful unauthorized access or modification.D. The date of the last risk appetite statement.
column16: C. Attempted or successful unauthorized access or modification.
column21: Reviews are intended to prevent, detect, contain, and correct security violations.
column46: Purpose of regular reviews.

column3: Scenario: Audit Log Review: The Security Official at a health clinic is establishing procedures for the "Information System Activity Review" to protect patient data from internal misuse.
column4: To identify "suspicious activity," the organization should define which of the following in its procedures?
column7: A. The cost of each audit tool.B. Types of activities that require further investigation.C. The religious affiliation of the IT staff.D. The total number of patients in the facility directory.
column16: B. Types of activities that require further investigation.
column21: Audit protocol reviews look for types of activities requiring investigation.
column46: Defining investigation criteria for system activity.

column3: Scenario: Audit Log Review: The Security Official at a health clinic is establishing procedures for the "Information System Activity Review" to protect patient data from internal misuse.
column4: The Information System Activity Review must be performed:
column7: A. Only once every six years.B. Regularly.C. Only after a breach is reported by the media.D. Only when an individual requests an accounting.
column16: B. Regularly.
column21: The required specification mandates that the entity implement procedures to "regularly review" these records.
column46: Frequency of activity reviews.

column3: Scenario: Audit Log Review: The Security Official at a health clinic is establishing procedures for the "Information System Activity Review" to protect patient data from internal misuse.
column4: If an organization lacks the internal staff to review logs manually, they should consider:
column7: A. Ignoring the requirement until an audit occurs.B. Automated tools to assist in monitoring and review.C. De-identifying all data so logs are not needed.D. Asking patients to review their own access logs.
column16: B. Automated tools to assist in monitoring and review.
column21: NIST suggests organizations consider available capabilities to automate reviews.
column46: Use of automation for activity review.

column3: Scenario: Facility Security Walkthrough: A management team is performing a walkthrough to assess "Physical Safeguards" at their data center and clinic.
column4: The "Facility Security Plan" (Addressable) must include policies to safeguard equipment from:
column7: A. Software bugs.B. Unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft.C. Increases in insurance premiums.D. Changes in the local fire code.
column16: B. Unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft.
column21: The Facility Security Plan specification involves policies to safeguard the facility and equipment from unauthorized access, tampering, and theft.
column46: Physical safeguards for facilities and equipment.

column3: Scenario: Facility Security Walkthrough: A management team is performing a walkthrough to assess "Physical Safeguards" at their data center and clinic.
column4: During the walkthrough, the team notes that network wiring is exposed in a public hallway. This violates which physical safeguard principle?
column7: A. Data Backup Plan.B. Protection from natural disasters.C. Ensuring that properly authorized access is allowed while limiting unauthorized physical access.D. De-identification safe harbor.
column16: C. Ensuring that properly authorized access is allowed while limiting unauthorized physical access.
column21: Facility Access Controls requires policies to limit physical access to information systems and the facilities where they are housed.
column46: Limiting physical access to ePHI systems.

column3: Scenario: Facility Security Walkthrough: A management team is performing a walkthrough to assess "Physical Safeguards" at their data center and clinic.
column4: The standard for "Maintenance Records" (Addressable) involves documenting repairs and modifications to:
column7: A. Software source code.B. Physical components of a facility related to security (e.g., hardware, walls, locks).C. The backup server's CPU.D. The medical equipment's calibration.
column16: B. Physical components of a facility related to security (e.g., hardware, walls, locks).
column21: Maintenance records involve documenting repairs and modifications to physical components related to security.
column46: Tracking modifications to physical security components.

column3: Scenario: Facility Security Walkthrough: A management team is performing a walkthrough to assess "Physical Safeguards" at their data center and clinic.
column4: "Access Control and Validation Procedures" (Addressable) specifically requires procedures for:
column7: A. Verifying the patient's religious affiliation.B. Visitor control and access to software for testing.C. Determining the SSN of first-degree relatives.D. Calculating the NPI for a subpart.
column16: B. Visitor control and access to software for testing.
column21: This specification includes procedures for visitor control and control of access to software for testing and revision.
column46: Physical access validation procedures.

column3: Scenario: Facility Security Walkthrough: A management team is performing a walkthrough to assess "Physical Safeguards" at their data center and clinic.
column4: If a facility is shared by a covered HCC and a non-covered component, the entity must ensure:
column7: A. All staff use the same login accounts.B. The HCC protects ePHI from unauthorized access by the other component.C. The non-covered component is exempt from fire codes.D. The facility directory is posted in the elevator.
column16: B. The HCC protects ePHI from unauthorized access by the other component.
column21: Hybrid entities must ensure HCCs protect ePHI from non-covered components as if they were separate legal entities.
column46: Physical safeguard requirements for hybrid entities.

column3: Scenario: Technical Authentication: A startup is choosing between different authentication methods for its remote telehealth platform.
column4: "Authentication" under the HIPAA Security Rule is defined as:
column7: A. The encryption of data during transmission.B. The corroboration that a person is the one claimed.C. The removal of eighteen patient identifiers.D. The signing of a BAA by a subcontractor.
column16: B. The corroboration that a person is the one claimed.
column21: Authentication means the corroboration that a person is the one claimed.
column46: Definition of authentication.

column3: Scenario: Technical Authentication: A startup is choosing between different authentication methods for its remote telehealth platform.
column4: The startup decides to use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). MFA typically utilizes two or more approaches, such as something you know and:
column7: A. Something you have (e.g., a token or smart card).B. Someone you know.C. Something you like.D. Somewhere you want to go.
column16: A. Something you have (e.g., a token or smart card).
column21: Authentication approaches include something you know (password), something you have (token), or something you are (biometric).
column46: Authentication approaches and factors.

column3: Scenario: Technical Authentication: A startup is choosing between different authentication methods for its remote telehealth platform.
column4: "Person or Entity Authentication" is a REQUIRED standard that applies to:
column7: A. Only clinicians.B. Only individuals who have been deceased for 50 years.C. A person or entity seeking access to ePHI.D. Only the Privacy Official.
column16: C. A person or entity seeking access to ePHI.
column21: The standard requires procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed.
column46: Verification that a person or entity seeking ePHI access is the one claimed.

column3: Scenario: Technical Authentication: A startup is choosing between different authentication methods for its remote telehealth platform.
column4: If an organization uses shared/generic accounts for remote access, this is generally:
column7: A. A best practice for speed.B. A violation of the Unique User Identification requirement.C. Permitted if the accounts are encrypted.D. Required for small health plans.
column16: B. A violation of the Unique User Identification requirement.
column21: The entity must assign a unique name and/or number for identifying and tracking user identity.
column46: Requirement to assign unique user IDs.

column3: Scenario: Technical Authentication: A startup is choosing between different authentication methods for its remote telehealth platform.
column4: To support the "Burden of Proof" for an access incident, the authentication procedures should be linked to:
column7: A. The facility floor plan.B. Audit controls that record system activity.C. The startup's marketing materials.D. The patient's religious affiliation.
column16: B. Audit controls that record system activity.
column21: Unique IDs and authentication ensure that system activity can be traced to a specific user to support audit functions.
column46: Use of audit logs to track authenticated user activity.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Retention: An individual files a formal complaint with a clinic's contact office, alleging their PHI was used for marketing without authorization.
column4: The organization is required to document the complaint and its:
column7: A. Financial impact on the clinic.B. Disposition, if any.C. Description in the next media report.D. Associated encryption algorithm.
column16: B. Disposition, if any.
column21: A covered entity must document all complaints received and their disposition, if any.
column46: Requirement to document complaints and dispositions.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Retention: An individual files a formal complaint with a clinic's contact office, alleging their PHI was used for marketing without authorization.
column4: How long must the clinic retain the documentation of this complaint?
column7: A. 1 year.B. 3 years.C. 6 years from the date of its creation.D. 50 years.
column16: C. 6 years from the date of its creation.
column21: Documentation of actions, such as complaint dispositions, must be retained for six years.
column46: Retention period for privacy documentation.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Retention: An individual files a formal complaint with a clinic's contact office, alleging their PHI was used for marketing without authorization.
column4: May the clinic require the individual to waive their right to complain to the Secretary as a condition of receiving treatment?
column7: A. Yes, to protect against frivolous lawsuits.B. No, this is a prohibited waiver of rights.C. Only if the service is paid out-of-pocket.D. Only if the individual is an unemancipated minor.
column16: B. No, this is a prohibited waiver of rights.
column21: A covered entity may not require individuals to waive their rights to complain to the Secretary as a condition of treatment.
column46: Prohibition on requiring waivers of rights.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Retention: An individual files a formal complaint with a clinic's contact office, alleging their PHI was used for marketing without authorization.
column4: If a workforce member assists the individual in filing this complaint, the clinic is prohibited from:
column7: A. Retraining the member.B. Intimidating or taking retaliatory action against them.C. Auditing their system access logs.D. Changing their job description.
column16: B. Intimidating or taking retaliatory action against them.
column21: A covered entity may not intimidate or retaliate against any individual for participating in any process provided for by HIPAA.
column46: Prohibition on retaliatory acts for exercising HIPAA rights.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Retention: An individual files a formal complaint with a clinic's contact office, alleging their PHI was used for marketing without authorization.
column4: The "Privacy Official" and "Contact Person" designations must be documented and:
column7: A. Updated every 30 days.B. Maintained in written or electronic form for six years.C. Published in the Federal Register.D. Kept confidential from the workforce.
column16: B. Maintained in written or electronic form for six years.
column21: Personnel designations must be documented and maintained for a period of six years.
column46: Retention requirements for personnel designations.

column3: Scenario: ALJ Hearing Procedures: A respondent (CE) is challenging a civil money penalty (CMP) in an administrative hearing.
column4: In a hearing, the "Burden of Persuasion" is judged by which standard?
column7: A. Preponderance of the evidence.B. Clear and convincing evidence.C. Beyond a reasonable doubt.C. Reasonable cause.
column16: A. Preponderance of the evidence.
column21: The burden of persuasion in an administrative hearing will be judged by a preponderance of the evidence.
column46: Legal standard for burden of persuasion in HIPAA hearings.

column3: Scenario: ALJ Hearing Procedures: A respondent (CE) is challenging a civil money penalty (CMP) in an administrative hearing.
column4: The Secretary (HHS) has the burden of persuasion regarding issues of:
column7: A. Affirmative defenses.B. Challenges to the penalty amount.C. Liability and the existence of aggravating factors.D. Correcting a violation within 30 days.
column16: C. Liability and the existence of aggravating factors.
column21: The Secretary has the burden of persuasion with respect to issues of liability and aggravating factors.
column46: Secretary's burden of proof in hearings.

column3: Scenario: ALJ Hearing Procedures: A respondent (CE) is challenging a civil money penalty (CMP) in an administrative hearing.
column4: A "statistical sampling study" used by the Secretary to evidence the number of violations constitutes:
column7: A. Hearsay evidence.B. Prima facie evidence.C. Irrefutable proof.D. Privileged information.
column16: B. Prima facie evidence.
column21: A statistical sampling study, if valid, constitutes prima facie evidence of the number of violations and material factors.
column46: Use of statistical sampling in enforcement actions.

column3: Scenario: ALJ Hearing Procedures: A respondent (CE) is challenging a civil money penalty (CMP) in an administrative hearing.
column4: Who has the authority to "affirm, increase, or reduce" the penalties imposed by the Secretary during a hearing?
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).C. The CEO of the CE.D. The media outlet serving the jurisdiction.
column16: B. The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).
column21: The ALJ may affirm, increase, or reduce the penalties imposed by the Secretary.
column46: Authority of the ALJ in penalty challenges.

column3: Scenario: ALJ Hearing Procedures: A respondent (CE) is challenging a civil money penalty (CMP) in an administrative hearing.
column4: After a prima facie case is made via sampling, the burden of "going forward" shifts to the:
column7: A. Secretary.B. Respondent.C. Complainant.D. Board.
column16: B. Respondent.
column21: Once a prima facie case is made, the burden shifts to the respondent to produce evidence to rebut the findings.
column46: Shifting of burden in enforcement hearings.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions (Subpart O): A plan sponsor is sending subscriber enrollment information to a health plan to establish coverage.
column4: This specific transmission is defined under HIPAA as which transaction?
column7: A. Eligibility for a health plan.B. Enrollment and disenrollment in a health plan.C. Coordination of benefits.D. Referral certification.
column16: B. Enrollment and disenrollment in a health plan.
column21: This transaction is the transmission of subscriber enrollment info from the sponsor to a plan to establish or terminate coverage.
column46: Definition of enrollment/disenrollment transaction.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions (Subpart O): A plan sponsor is sending subscriber enrollment information to a health plan to establish coverage.
column4: A "Standard Transaction" MUST comply with an applicable standard and:
column7: A. A patient's verbal consent.B. Associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.C. The CE's internal marketing guidelines.D. A signed BAA with the clinic.
column16: B. Associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column21: A standard transaction complies with an applicable standard and associated operating rules adopted under Part 162.
column46: Definition of standard transactions and operating rules.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions (Subpart O): A plan sponsor is sending subscriber enrollment information to a health plan to establish coverage.
column4: "Operating Rules" are defined as business rules for electronic exchange that are:
column7: A. Defined by the Privacy Rule.B. NOT defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.C. Approved by the individual in the NPP.D. Defined solely by the billing software vendor.
column16: B. NOT defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.
column21: Operating rules are business rules for electronic exchange NOT defined by a standard or its implementation specifications.
column46: Definition of operating rules.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions (Subpart O): A plan sponsor is sending subscriber enrollment information to a health plan to establish coverage.
column4: If a covered entity uses a Business Associate (BA) to conduct a transaction, the entity must:
column7: A. Share all ePHI with the BA without encryption.B. Require the BA and its subcontractors to comply with all applicable Part 162 requirements.C. Only use the BA for dental claims.D. Waive the NPI requirement for that transaction.
column16: B. Require the BA and its subcontractors to comply with all applicable Part 162 requirements.
column21: If using a BA for transactions, the CE must require the BA (and its agents/subcontractors) to comply with Part 162 requirements.
column46: Responsibility for BA compliance in transactions.

column3: Scenario: Standard Transactions (Subpart O): A plan sponsor is sending subscriber enrollment information to a health plan to establish coverage.
column4: A health plan is prohibited from rejection a standard transaction because it contains:
column7: A. Valid medical code sets.B. Data elements not needed or used by the plan.C. Encrypted PHI.D. A correct National Provider Identifier.
column16: B. Data elements not needed or used by the plan.
column21: A health plan may not reject a standard transaction because it contains data elements not needed or used by the plan.
column46: Prohibitions on rejecting standard transactions.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Wellness Programs: A large health plan offers a "Wellness Discount" to enrollees who complete a health risk assessment. The assessment asks for the "manifestation of a disease or disorder" in the individual’s family members to determine the discount amount.
column4: Is the health plan permitted to use this family medical history to determine a premium discount?
column7: A. Yes, because wellness programs are exempt from underwriting rules.B. No, using genetic information for premium differentials is a prohibited underwriting purpose.C. Yes, if the individual provides a signed HIPAA authorization.D. Only if the health plan is an issuer of a long-term care policy.
column14: B. No, using genetic information for premium differentials is a prohibited underwriting purpose.
column20: Underwriting purposes include the computation of premium or contribution amounts, including premium differential mechanisms in return for activities like completing a health risk assessment. Genetic information includes the manifestation of disease in family members.
column44: Prohibition on using or disclosing genetic information for underwriting by most health plans; OCR audits underwriting practices.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Wellness Programs: A large health plan offers a "Wellness Discount" to enrollees who complete a health risk assessment. The assessment asks for the "manifestation of a disease or disorder" in the individual’s family members to determine the discount amount.
column4: According to the sources, the term "Genetic Information" specifically includes information about which of the following?
column7: A. The individual’s current age.B. The individual’s sex.C. A fetus carried by a family member who is a pregnant woman.D. The individual’s blood pressure readings.
column14: C. A fetus carried by a family member who is a pregnant woman.
column20: Genetic information concerning an individual or family member includes the genetic information of a fetus carried by the individual or family member who is a pregnant woman.
column44: Key definitions, including Genetic Information.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Wellness Programs: A large health plan offers a "Wellness Discount" to enrollees who complete a health risk assessment. The assessment asks for the "manifestation of a disease or disorder" in the individual’s family members to determine the discount amount.
column4: The ban on using genetic information for underwriting applies to all health plans EXCEPT:
column7: A. Small health plans.B. Health care clearinghouses.C. Issuers of a long-term care policy.D. Group health plans with fewer than 50 participants.
column14: C. Issuers of a long-term care policy.
column20: The prohibition on the use of genetic information for underwriting purposes excludes issuers of long-term care policies.
column44: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Wellness Programs: A large health plan offers a "Wellness Discount" to enrollees who complete a health risk assessment. The assessment asks for the "manifestation of a disease or disorder" in the individual’s family members to determine the discount amount.
column4: Which of the following is NOT considered a "genetic test" under the HIPAA definition?
column7: A. DNA analysis.B. Chromosomal analysis.C. Analysis of proteins directly related to a manifested disease.D. RNA analysis.
column14: C. Analysis of proteins directly related to a manifested disease.
column20: Genetic test does not include an analysis of proteins or metabolites that is directly related to a manifested disease, disorder, or pathological condition.
column44: Key definitions, including Genetic Information.

column3: Scenario: Genetic Info and Wellness Programs: A large health plan offers a "Wellness Discount" to enrollees who complete a health risk assessment. The assessment asks for the "manifestation of a disease or disorder" in the individual’s family members to determine the discount amount.
column4: If a health plan uses genetic information to determine "medical appropriateness" for a benefit rather than a premium rate, is this considered an "underwriting purpose"?
column7: A. Yes, all medical reviews are underwriting.B. No, underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness.C. Only if the review is performed by a Business Associate.D. Only if the benefit is for a pre-existing condition.
column14: B. No, underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness.
column20: Underwriting purposes does not include determinations of medical appropriateness where an individual seeks a benefit under the plan.
column44: Limits on using PHI received for underwriting, rating, or similar purposes.

column3: Scenario: Privacy of Decedents: A researcher requests access to the medical records of a patient who passed away at the clinic in 1970. The Privacy Official must determine if the records are still protected under HIPAA.
column4: For how many years following the death of an individual must a Covered Entity comply with the Privacy Rule regarding that individual's PHI?
column7: A. 6 years.B. 10 years.C. 50 years.D. Perpetually.
column14: C. 50 years.
column20: A covered entity must comply with the requirements of this subpart with respect to the protected health information of a deceased individual for a period of 50 years following the death.
column44: Obligation to protect PHI of deceased individuals for 50 years.

column3: Scenario: Privacy of Decedents: A researcher requests access to the medical records of a patient who passed away at the clinic in 1970. The Privacy Official must determine if the records are still protected under HIPAA.
column4: If the patient in this scenario passed away more than 50 years ago, is the information still considered "Protected Health Information"?
column7: A. Yes, but it is no longer subject to the Security Rule.B. No, PHI excludes individually identifiable health information regarding a person deceased for more than 50 years.C. Yes, it remains PHI until all 18 identifiers are removed.D. Only if the next of kin is still alive.
column14: B. No, PHI excludes individually identifiable health information regarding a person deceased for more than 50 years.
column20: The definition of PHI explicitly excludes information regarding a person who has been deceased for more than 50 years.
column44: Key definitions, including PHI.

column3: Scenario: Privacy of Decedents: A researcher requests access to the medical records of a patient who passed away at the clinic in 1970. The Privacy Official must determine if the records are still protected under HIPAA.
column4: If the patient had been deceased for only 20 years, the provider could disclose PHI to an involved family member unless:
column7: A. The family member is not the executor.B. Doing so is inconsistent with any prior expressed preference of the individual known to the CE.C. The PHI is in electronic format.D. The disclosure is for healthcare operations.
column14: B. Doing so is inconsistent with any prior expressed preference of the individual known to the CE.
column20: A CE may disclose PHI relevant to a person's involvement in a decedent's care unless doing so is inconsistent with any prior expressed preference of the individual known to the CE.
column44: Permitted and required uses and disclosures of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Privacy of Decedents: A researcher requests access to the medical records of a patient who passed away at the clinic in 1970. The Privacy Official must determine if the records are still protected under HIPAA.
column4: When a personal representative (executor) requests a decedent’s records, the provider must treat them as the individual with respect to PHI that is:
column7: A. Created within 6 years of death.B. Relevant to such personal representation.C. Only related to billing.D. Approved by the clinician.
column14: B. Relevant to such personal representation.
column20: A CE must treat a person as a personal representative with respect to PHI relevant to such personal representation.
column44: Requirement to recognize personal representatives for decedents.

column3: Scenario: Privacy of Decedents: A researcher requests access to the medical records of a patient who passed away at the clinic in 1970. The Privacy Official must determine if the records are still protected under HIPAA.
column4: If a provider knows an individual is deceased, they must send a required breach notification to:
column7: A. The Secretary of HHS only.B. The next of kin or personal representative of the individual.C. The prominent media outlets in the state.D. The individual's last known home address.
column14: B. The next of kin or personal representative of the individual.
column20: If the CE knows the individual is deceased, written notification must be sent to either the next of kin or personal representative of the individual.
column44: Obligation to notify next of kin for deceased individuals.

column3: Scenario: Personal Reps and Safety: A father requests the medical records of his 14-year-old son. The clinician has a reasonable belief that the son has been subjected to domestic violence by the father.
column4: According to the implementation specifications for "Abuse, neglect, [and] endangerment," the clinician:
column7: A. Must still provide the records because of parental rights.B. May elect not to treat the father as the personal representative if it is not in the best interest of the child.C. Must report the clinician to the Secretary.D. Must wait for a court order to deny access.
column14: B. May elect not to treat the father as the personal representative if it is not in the best interest of the child.
column20: A CE may elect not to treat a person as a personal representative if they believe the individual may be subjected to abuse or endangerment by that person and determine it's not in the individual's best interest.
column44: Exceptions to recognizing personal representatives for abuse/neglect/endangerment.

column3: Scenario: Personal Reps and Safety: A father requests the medical records of his 14-year-old son. The clinician has a reasonable belief that the son has been subjected to domestic violence by the father.
column4: If the clinician decides NOT to treat the father as the personal representative based on professional judgment, this decision:
column7: A. Overrides State law to the contrary.B. Is subject to mandatory review by the Security Official.C. Must be reported to the media.D. Is invalid if the son is an emancipated minor.
column14: A. Overrides State law to the contrary.
column20: This election may be made notwithstanding a State law or any requirement of this paragraph to the contrary.
column44: Recognition of personal representatives and safety exceptions.

column3: Scenario: Personal Reps and Safety: A father requests the medical records of his 14-year-old son. The clinician has a reasonable belief that the son has been subjected to domestic violence by the father.
column4: When a clinician makes a disclosure about a victim of abuse to a government authority, they must promptly inform the individual EXCEPT if:
column7: A. The individual is an adult.B. The clinician believes informing the person would place them at risk of serious harm.C. The disclosure is required by law.D. The individual is incapacitated.
column14: B. The clinician believes informing the person would place them at risk of serious harm.
column20: Prompt notice is required unless the CE believes informing the individual would place the individual at risk of serious harm.
column38: Uses and disclosures for which authorization/opportunity to object is not required
column44: Disclosures about victims of abuse/neglect.

column3: Scenario: Personal Reps and Safety: A father requests the medical records of his 14-year-old son. The clinician has a reasonable belief that the son has been subjected to domestic violence by the father.
column4: If an unemancipated minor consents to a service and no other consent is required by law, the minor has the authority to:
column7: A. Waive the 50-year decedent rule.B. Act as an individual and prevent parental access to those specific records.C. Revoke the organization's NPI.D. Conduct their own risk analysis.
column14: B. Act as an individual and prevent parental access to those specific records.
column20: A minor has the authority to act as an individual if they consent to a service where no other consent is required by law and have not requested a personal representative.
column44: Individual rights of unemancipated minors.

column3: Scenario: Personal Reps and Safety: A father requests the medical records of his 14-year-old son. The clinician has a reasonable belief that the son has been subjected to domestic violence by the father.
column4: In the absence of a specific state law regarding parental access to a minor's PHI, the decision to grant or deny access to the parent must be made by:
column7: A. The Privacy Official.B. A licensed health care professional in the exercise of professional judgment.C. The child's legal counsel.D. The CEO of the health plan.
column14: B. A licensed health care professional in the exercise of professional judgment.
column20: Where there is no applicable access provision under law, a CE may provide or deny access to a parent provided the decision is made by a licensed professional in the exercise of professional judgment.
column44: Recognition of personal representatives for minors.

column3: Scenario: BA Pattern of Practice: A Covered Entity (CE) discovers that its Business Associate (BA) is consistently failing to encrypt laptops, which is a material breach of their contract. The CE attempts to work with the BA to remediate, but the BA refuses to change its practices.
column4: Under the "Business associate contracts" standard, the CE MUST:
column7: A. Ignore the violation as long as no breach occurs.B. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.C. Pay the BA's Civil Money Penalties.D. De-identify all data and continue the contract.
column14: B. Terminate the contract or arrangement, if feasible.
column20: If a CE knows of a pattern of violation and remediation steps are unsuccessful, the CE must terminate the contract if feasible.
column44: Duty to remediate or terminate BA relationships in case of violations.

column3: Scenario: BA Pattern of Practice: A Covered Entity (CE) discovers that its Business Associate (BA) is consistently failing to encrypt laptops, which is a material breach of their contract. The CE attempts to work with the BA to remediate, but the BA refuses to change its practices.
column4: If a Business Associate (BA) discovers a similar pattern of violation by its own subcontractor, the BA has:
column7: A. No liability, as the subcontractor is separate.B. The same obligation as a CE to take steps to cure or terminate.C. An obligation to notify the media within 30 days.D. A requirement to report the CE to the Secretary.
column14: B. The same obligation as a CE to take steps to cure or terminate.
column20: A business associate is not in compliance if it knows of a pattern of violation by a subcontractor and fails to take reasonable steps to cure or terminate.
column44: Downstream obligations for BAs managing subcontractors.

column3: Scenario: BA Pattern of Practice: A Covered Entity (CE) discovers that its Business Associate (BA) is consistently failing to encrypt laptops, which is a material breach of their contract. The CE attempts to work with the BA to remediate, but the BA refuses to change its practices.
column4: The contract between a CE and BA must require the BA to make its internal practices, books, and records available to:
column7: A. The individual patient upon request.B. The Secretary (HHS) for determining compliance.C. The BA's subcontractors.D. The media serving the jurisdiction.
column14: B. The Secretary (HHS) for determining compliance.
column20: The BAA must require the BA to make internal practices, books, and records available to the Secretary for purposes of determining compliance.
column44: Privacy requirements for BA contracts.

column3: Scenario: BA Pattern of Practice: A Covered Entity (CE) discovers that its Business Associate (BA) is consistently failing to encrypt laptops, which is a material breach of their contract. The CE attempts to work with the BA to remediate, but the BA refuses to change its practices.
column4: If the BA discloses PHI to a third party for management purposes, the BA must obtain reasonable assurances that the info will be used only as required by law or for the purpose disclosed, AND:
column7: A. The recipient will pay a cost-based fee.B. The person notifies the BA of any breaches of confidentiality.C. The recipient has an NPI.D. The recipient provides a written risk analysis.
column14: B. The person notifies the BA of any breaches of confidentiality.
column20: The BA must obtain assurances that the recipient will notify the BA of any instances in which the confidentiality of the information has been breached.
column44: BA management and administration disclosure rules.

column3: Scenario: BA Pattern of Practice: A Covered Entity (CE) discovers that its Business Associate (BA) is consistently failing to encrypt laptops, which is a material breach of their contract. The CE attempts to work with the BA to remediate, but the BA refuses to change its practices.
column4: The "Agency" rule states that a CE is liable for a civil money penalty for a violation based on the act or omission of:
column7: A. Only the CEO.B. Any agent, including a workforce member or BA, acting within the scope of agency.C. Only on-site contractors.D. Only the Security Official.
column14: B. Any agent, including a workforce member or BA, acting within the scope of agency.
column20: A covered entity is liable for the acts of any agent, including workforce members and business associates, acting within the scope of agency.
column44: Liability for acts of agents and business associates.

column3: Scenario: Clearinghouse Isolation: A health tech company operates a "Health Care Clearinghouse" as one of its divisions. The company's main division, which is not a covered entity, wants to access clearinghouse data for product development.
column4: Under "Information Access Management," the clearinghouse MUST:
column7: A. Share all data for health care operations.B. Implement policies that protect clearinghouse ePHI from unauthorized access by the larger organization.C. De-identify the data using Safe Harbor only.D. Document the larger organization as a personal representative.
column14: B. Implement policies that protect clearinghouse ePHI from unauthorized access by the larger organization.
column20: If a clearinghouse is part of a larger organization, it must implement policies to protect its ePHI from unauthorized access by that larger organization.
column44: Requirement to isolate clearinghouse functions within a larger organization.

column3: Scenario: Clearinghouse Isolation: A health tech company operates a "Health Care Clearinghouse" as one of its divisions. The company's main division, which is not a covered entity, wants to access clearinghouse data for product development.
column4: The larger organization's access to the clearinghouse's ePHI must be restricted to only those persons:
column7: A. With an equitable interest of 5% or more.B. Who have been granted access rights as specified in § 164.308(a)(4).C. Who are licensed clinicians.D. Who have signed the Notice of Privacy Practices.
column14: B. Who have been granted access rights as specified in § 164.308(a)(4).
column20: Access Control standard requires policies to allow access only to those who have been granted access rights under the Information Access Management standard.
column44: Limit access to ePHI to authorized users/programs.

column3: Scenario: Clearinghouse Isolation: A health tech company operates a "Health Care Clearinghouse" as one of its divisions. The company's main division, which is not a covered entity, wants to access clearinghouse data for product development.
column4: If a workforce member performs duties for BOTH the clearinghouse and the larger non-covered component, they:
column7: A. Are exempt from the Privacy Rule.B. Must not use or disclose PHI created for the clearinghouse in a way prohibited by Subpart E.C. Are considered a "Plan Sponsor."D. Must only follow the non-covered component's internal ethics code.
column14: B. Must not use or disclose PHI created for the clearinghouse in a way prohibited by Subpart E.
column20: Hybrid entity workforce members performing dual roles must not use or disclose PHI created for the HCC in a way prohibited by the Privacy Rule.
column44: Use and disclosure restrictions for hybrid entity workforce.

column3: Scenario: Clearinghouse Isolation: A health tech company operates a "Health Care Clearinghouse" as one of its divisions. The company's main division, which is not a covered entity, wants to access clearinghouse data for product development.
column4: To ensure proper isolation, NIST suggests that the clearinghouse:
column7: A. Encrypt all databases with a single master key.B. Establish a separate network or subsystem for the clearinghouse function.C. Share the same facility security plan with the larger company.D. Allow only the Security Official to access the clearinghouse.
column14: B. Establish a separate network or subsystem for the clearinghouse function.
column20: NIST suggests establishing a separate network or subsystem for the healthcare clearinghouse if reasonable and appropriate to ensure isolation.
column44: Guidance on isolating clearinghouse functions.

column3: Scenario: Clearinghouse Isolation: A health tech company operates a "Health Care Clearinghouse" as one of its divisions. The company's main division, which is not a covered entity, wants to access clearinghouse data for product development.
column4: "Covered functions" refers specifically to the performance of activities that make an entity a:
column7: A. Hybrid Entity.B. Health plan, health care provider, or health care clearinghouse.C. Plan sponsor or employer.D. Business associate or subcontractor.
column14: B. Health plan, health care provider, or health care clearinghouse.
column20: Covered functions means those functions the performance of which makes the entity a health plan, health care provider, or health care clearinghouse.
column44: Key definitions, including Covered Functions.

column3: Scenario: Training and Login Monitoring: The IT department is implementing a "Log-in Monitoring" procedure as part of its security awareness program. They want to ensure staff understand the purpose and reporting steps.
column4: "Log-in Monitoring" is classified as which type of implementation specification?
column7: A. Required Administrative Safeguard.B. Addressable Administrative Safeguard.C. Required Technical Safeguard.D. Addressable Physical Safeguard.
column14: B. Addressable Administrative Safeguard.
column20: Log-in monitoring is an addressable implementation specification under the Security Awareness and Training standard.
column44: Procedures for monitoring log-in attempts and reporting discrepancies.

column3: Scenario: Training and Login Monitoring: The IT department is implementing a "Log-in Monitoring" procedure as part of its security awareness program. They want to ensure staff understand the purpose and reporting steps.
column4: According to the HHS Audit Protocol, the "Log-in Monitoring" procedures should define:
column7: A. The cost of the monitoring software.B. How to identify an inappropriate or attempted log-in.C. The NPI for the IT staff.D. The encryption algorithm for passwords.
