column14: B. How to identify an inappropriate or attempted log-in.
column20: Audit elements include identifying how log-in monitoring is conducted and how to identify inappropriate or attempted log-ins.
column44: Procedures for monitoring log-in attempts and reporting discrepancies.

column3: Scenario: Training and Login Monitoring: The IT department is implementing a "Log-in Monitoring" procedure as part of its security awareness program. They want to ensure staff understand the purpose and reporting steps.
column4: Procedures for creating, changing, and safeguarding passwords are part of which standard?
column7: A. Access Control.B. Audit Controls.C. Security Awareness and Training.D. Workforce Security.
column14: C. Security Awareness and Training.
column20: Password Management is an addressable implementation specification under Security Awareness and Training.
column44: Security awareness program: reminders, malicious software protection, login monitoring, password management.

column3: Scenario: Training and Login Monitoring: The IT department is implementing a "Log-in Monitoring" procedure as part of its security awareness program. They want to ensure staff understand the purpose and reporting steps.
column4: NIST recommends that a security awareness program include training on the "importance of the timely application of system patches" to address:
column7: A. Transmission Security.B. Protection from Malicious Software.C. Facility Access Controls.D. Device and Media Controls.
column14: B. Protection from Malicious Software.
column20: Patching is crucial for protecting against malicious software and exploitation of vulnerabilities.
column44: Procedures for guarding against, detecting, and reporting malicious software.

column3: Scenario: Training and Login Monitoring: The IT department is implementing a "Log-in Monitoring" procedure as part of its security awareness program. They want to ensure staff understand the purpose and reporting steps.
column4: If an organization determines that a "Password Management" specification is not reasonable, it must implement an equivalent alternative, such as:
column7: A. Biometric authentication.B. Eliminating all passwords.C. Changing the notice of privacy practices.D. Increasing the number of business associates.
column14: A. Biometric authentication.
column20: NIST mentions biometric authentication as a password-less option that could address risk.
column44: Authentication approaches and factors.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: As part of contingency planning, the Security Official is reviewing which applications and data sets are most essential for business operations following a major outage.
column4: The "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" is a(n):
column7: A. Required Administrative safeguard.B. Addressable Administrative safeguard.C. Required Physical safeguard.D. Addressable Technical safeguard.
column14: B. Addressable Administrative safeguard.
column20: Applications and Data Criticality Analysis is an addressable implementation specification under the Contingency Plan standard.
column44: Assessing relative criticality of applications and data for contingency planning.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: As part of contingency planning, the Security Official is reviewing which applications and data sets are most essential for business operations following a major outage.
column4: The objective of this analysis is to prioritize restoration efforts for applications based on:
column7: A. The cost of the software license.B. Importance to business needs or patient care.C. The number of IT staff required.D. The date the data was last audited.
column14: B. Importance to business needs or patient care.
column20: Critically levels are assessed based on importance to business needs or patient care to prioritize backup and recovery.
column44: Assessing relative criticality of applications and data for contingency planning.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: As part of contingency planning, the Security Official is reviewing which applications and data sets are most essential for business operations following a major outage.
column4: According to the HHS Audit Protocol, this analysis should support which other plan components?
column7: A. Sanction Policy and Training.B. Data Backup, Disaster Recovery, and Emergency Mode Operations.C. Facility Access and Workstation Security.D. Encryption and Transmission Security.
column14: B. Data Backup, Disaster Recovery, and Emergency Mode Operations.
column20: The analysis assesses criticality in support of other contingency plan components.
column44: Assessing relative criticality of applications and data for contingency planning.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: As part of contingency planning, the Security Official is reviewing which applications and data sets are most essential for business operations following a major outage.
column4: NIST recommends that a "Business Impact Analysis" (BIA) be used to:
column7: A. Calculate Civil Money Penalties.B. Evaluate and monitor the criticality of organizational assets, including ePHI.C. Determine if a minor is emancipated.D. Identify the perpetrator of a security incident.
column14: B. Evaluate and monitor the criticality of organizational assets, including ePHI.
column20: A BIA can help evaluate, record, and monitor asset criticality and inform risk tolerance levels.
column44: Use of BIA in risk assessment and contingency planning.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: As part of contingency planning, the Security Official is reviewing which applications and data sets are most essential for business operations following a major outage.
column4: The required specification to establish (and implement as needed) procedures to RESTORE any loss of data is the:
column7: A. Data Backup Plan.B. Disaster Recovery Plan.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Accountability Specification.
column14: B. Disaster Recovery Plan.
column20: Disaster Recovery Plan requires establishing and implementing procedures to restore any loss of data.
column44: Procedures to restore any loss of data.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance Records: A maintenance worker replaces a broken lock on the server room door. The Security Official must ensure this repair is documented correctly under the Physical Safeguards.
column4: The requirement to document repairs and modifications to the physical components of a facility related to security is the standard for:
column7: A. Facility Security Plan.B. Maintenance Records.C. Access Control and Validation.D. Workstation Security.
column14: B. Maintenance Records.
column20: Maintenance Records (Addressable) requires policies to document repairs and modifications to physical components related to security.
column44: Tracking modifications to physical security components.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance Records: A maintenance worker replaces a broken lock on the server room door. The Security Official must ensure this repair is documented correctly under the Physical Safeguards.
column4: Examples of components that require maintenance records include hardware, walls, doors, and:
column7: A. Encryption keys.B. Audit logs.C. Locks.D. Personnel files.
column14: C. Locks.
column20: The standard explicitly lists hardware, walls, doors, and locks as examples of physical components related to security.
column44: Tracking modifications to physical security components.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance Records: A maintenance worker replaces a broken lock on the server room door. The Security Official must ensure this repair is documented correctly under the Physical Safeguards.
column4: "Facility Security Plan" (Addressable) specifically requires policies to safeguard equipment from:
column7: A. Software malware.B. Unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft.C. Incorrect medical coding.D. Expiration of BAAs.
column14: B. Unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft.
column20: The Facility Security Plan specification involves policies to safeguard the facility and equipment from unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft.
column44: Physical safeguards to safeguard facilities and equipment.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance Records: A maintenance worker replaces a broken lock on the server room door. The Security Official must ensure this repair is documented correctly under the Physical Safeguards.
column4: Physical safeguards are policies and procedures to protect systems and buildings from unauthorized intrusion and which other hazards?
column7: A. Marketing solicitations.B. Natural and environmental hazards.C. Workforce whistleblowers.D. Non-standard transactions.
column14: B. Natural and environmental hazards.
column20: Physical safeguards protect systems and facilities from natural and environmental hazards and unauthorized intrusion.
column44: Definition of Physical Safeguards.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance Records: A maintenance worker replaces a broken lock on the server room door. The Security Official must ensure this repair is documented correctly under the Physical Safeguards.
column4: Access Control and Validation Procedures (Addressable) must include procedures for which of the following?
column7: A. De-identification of PHI.B. Visitor control.C. Multi-factor authentication.D. Unique User Identification.
column14: B. Visitor control.
column20: This specification includes procedures for visitor control and control of access to software for testing and revision.
column44: Physical safeguards for facilities, including visitor control.

column3: Scenario: Technical Integrity and Hashing: The IT team implements a cryptographic hashing process to verify that ePHI transmitted between two facilities has not been modified in transit.
column4: This process addresses which addressable implementation specification under the "Integrity" standard?
column7: A. Encryption and Decryption.B. Integrity Controls.C. Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI.D. Automatic Logoff.
column14: C. Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI.
column20: Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI (addressable) requires mechanisms to corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
column44: Policies and mechanisms to protect and authenticate ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical Integrity and Hashing: The IT team implements a cryptographic hashing process to verify that ePHI transmitted between two facilities has not been modified in transit.
column4: The requirement to protect ePHI from "improper alteration or destruction" is the core definition of which standard?
column7: A. Confidentiality.B. Availability.C. Integrity.D. Authentication.
column14: C. Integrity.
column20: Integrity is the property that data or information have not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner.
column44: Definition of Integrity.

column3: Scenario: Technical Integrity and Hashing: The IT team implements a cryptographic hashing process to verify that ePHI transmitted between two facilities has not been modified in transit.
column4: Which Technical Safeguard standard requires guarding against unauthorized access to ePHI that is BEING TRANSMITTED over a network?
column7: A. Access Control.B. Audit Controls.C. Integrity.D. Transmission Security.
column14: D. Transmission Security.
column20: Transmission Security requires technical measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI being transmitted over an electronic communications network.
column44: Measures to guard ePHI in motion.

column3: Scenario: Technical Integrity and Hashing: The IT team implements a cryptographic hashing process to verify that ePHI transmitted between two facilities has not been modified in transit.
column4: "Integrity Controls" (Addressable) under Transmission Security specifically ensures that transmitted ePHI is not:
column7: A. Encrypted without a key.B. Improperly modified without detection.C. Shared with a Business Associate.D. Stored for more than 6 years.
column14: B. Improperly modified without detection.
column20: Integrity Controls require measures to ensure that electronically transmitted ePHI is not improperly modified without detection until disposed of.
column44: Integrity controls for transmitted ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Technical Integrity and Hashing: The IT team implements a cryptographic hashing process to verify that ePHI transmitted between two facilities has not been modified in transit.
column4: NIST defines "Encryption" as an algorithmic process to transform data into a form in which there is:
column7: A. Zero probability of assigning meaning.B. A low probability of assigning meaning without the use of a key.C. No patient identifiers remaining.D. Only binary code.
column14: B. A low probability of assigning meaning without the use of a key.
column20: Encryption is an algorithmic process to transform data to a form with a low probability of meaning without a key.
column44: Definition of Encryption.

column3: Scenario: Documentation Availability: An OCR auditor asks the Security Official to demonstrate that policies and procedures are available to the employees who actually perform the security tasks.
column4: The required specification "Availability" under the Documentation standard mandates making documentation available to:
column7: A. The public upon request.B. Those persons responsible for implementing the procedures.C. Only the Privacy and Security Officials.D. All individual patients.
column14: B. Those persons responsible for implementing the procedures.
column20: Availability (Required) mandates making documentation available to those persons responsible for implementing the procedures to which the documentation pertains.
column44: Making security documentation available to responsible staff.

column3: Scenario: Documentation Availability: An OCR auditor asks the Security Official to demonstrate that policies and procedures are available to the employees who actually perform the security tasks.
column4: How long must an organization retain the written or electronic records of its HIPAA policies and actions?
column7: A. 3 years.B. 6 years from creation or last effect.C. 10 years.D. 50 years after the organization closes.
column14: B. 6 years from creation or last effect.
column20: A covered entity must retain required documentation for six years from the date of its creation or the date when it last was in effect, whichever is later.
column44: Retention period for security records.

column3: Scenario: Documentation Availability: An OCR auditor asks the Security Official to demonstrate that policies and procedures are available to the employees who actually perform the security tasks.
column4: The required "Updates" specification mandates that the organization MUST review documentation periodically and update it in response to:
column7: A. Changes in annual revenue.B. Environmental or operational changes affecting the security of ePHI.C. Requests from the media.D. Changes in the organization's NPI.
column14: B. Environmental or operational changes affecting the security of ePHI.
column20: Updates (Required) requires reviewing documentation periodically and updating as needed in response to environmental or operational changes affecting ePHI security.
column44: Periodic review and updating of security documentation.

column3: Scenario: Documentation Availability: An OCR auditor asks the Security Official to demonstrate that policies and procedures are available to the employees who actually perform the security tasks.
column4: If a Covered Entity changes a privacy practice, it is bound by the practices in its PREVIOUS notice with respect to PHI created while that notice was in effect UNLESS it:
column7: A. Paid a correction fee to HHS.B. Reserved the right to change its practices in the notice.C. De-identified the previous records.D. Sanctioned the Privacy Official.
column14: B. Reserved the right to change its practices in the notice.
column20: A CE is bound by the practices in the notice in effect unless it has reserved the right to change the terms of its notice and make the new provisions effective for all PHI.
column44: Rules for changing privacy practices and notice updates.

column3: Scenario: Documentation Availability: An OCR auditor asks the Security Official to demonstrate that policies and procedures are available to the employees who actually perform the security tasks.
column4: "Reasonable diligence" is defined as the business care and prudence expected from:
column7: A. A licensed healthcare professional.B. A person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.C. The Secretary of HHS.D. A Business Associate.
column14: B. A person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.
column20: Reasonable diligence means the business care and prudence expected from a person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.
column44: Key definitions related to compliance and enforcement.

column3: Scenario: Audit Readiness: An organization is selected for an OCR audit. The auditor requests documentation that is not currently available for the requested period.
column4: According to the general instructions of the Audit Protocol, what must the entity provide if the requested implementation documentation is unavailable?
column9: A. A promise to create the documents within 30 days.B. Instances from equivalent previous time periods to complete the sample.C. A waiver signed by the Security Official.D. Documentation from a business associate instead.
column16: B. Instances from equivalent previous time periods to complete the sample.
column19: If the requested number of documentations is not available, the entity must provide instances from equivalent previous time periods or a statement that no documentation is available.
column45: Requirements for entities to provide specified documents and statements regarding documentation availability.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement Definitions: Management is reviewing the organization's compliance posture to avoid "Civil Money Penalties" (CMPs). They are defining the level of care expected.
column4: "Reasonable diligence" is defined under HIPAA as the business care and prudence expected from:
column9: A. A licensed healthcare professional.B. A person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.C. The Secretary of HHS.D. A Business Associate only.
column16: B. A person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.
column19: Reasonable diligence means the business care and prudence expected from a person seeking to satisfy a legal requirement under similar circumstances.
column45: Key definitions related to compliance and enforcement.

column3: Scenario: Enforcement Definitions: Management is reviewing the organization's compliance posture to avoid "Civil Money Penalties" (CMPs). They are defining the level of care expected.
column4: Which term refers to a "conscious, intentional failure or reckless indifference" to the obligation to comply with a HIPAA provision?
column9: A. Reasonable cause.B. Willful neglect.C. Affirmative defense.D. Corrective action.
column16: B. Willful neglect.
column19: Willful neglect means conscious, intentional failure or reckless indifference to the obligation to comply with the administrative simplification provision violated.
column45: Key definitions related to compliance and enforcement.

column3: Scenario: ACE Liability: A health system comprises three legally separate covered entities that have designated themselves as an "Affiliated Covered Entity" (ACE).
column4: A member of an ACE is jointly and severally liable for a CMP for a violation of the ACE unless it is established that:
column9: A. The violation was unintentional.B. Another member of the ACE was responsible for the violation.C. The CE has fewer than 50 employees.D. The CE corrected the violation within 60 days.
column16: B. Another member of the ACE was responsible for the violation.
column19: A member of an ACE is jointly and severally liable for a CMP unless it is established that another member was responsible.
column45: Liability of affiliated covered entities.

column3: Scenario: Regulatory Changes: The compliance team is monitoring the Federal Register for HIPAA modifications.
column4: The Secretary may adopt a modification to a HIPAA standard or implementation specification no more frequently than once every:
column9: A. 6 months.B. 12 months.C. 2 years.D. 5 years.
column16: B. 12 months.
column19: Except for initial adoptions, the Secretary may adopt a modification to a standard no more frequently than once every 12 months.
column45: Rules regarding the adoption and frequency of modifications.

column3: Scenario: Preemption of State Law: A startup operates in a state with its own medical privacy laws. They need to determine which law takes precedence.
column4: A standard adopted under HIPAA preempts a "contrary" provision of State law UNLESS the State law:
column9: A. Is less expensive to implement.B. Relates to privacy and is "more stringent" than the HIPAA Privacy Rule.C. Was enacted before 1996.D. Is preferred by the organization's legal counsel.
column16: B. Relates to privacy and is "more stringent" than the HIPAA Privacy Rule.
column19: HIPAA preempts contrary state law unless the state law relates to privacy and is more stringent than the federal standard.
column45: Rules for when State law is preserved over HIPAA.

column3: Scenario: Preemption of State Law: A startup operates in a state with its own medical privacy laws. They need to determine which law takes precedence.
column4: A State law is considered "more stringent" if it provides the individual with:
column9: A. More rapid access to their records.B. Greater rights of amendment.C. More detailed information in an accounting of disclosures.D. All of the above.
column16: D. All of the above.
column19: More stringent criteria include greater rights of access/amendment, more information to the individual, or more detailed/longer retention for accountings.
column45: Definition of "more stringent" state law.

column3: Scenario: Compliance Investigations: An OCR investigator determines that "exigent circumstances" exist during an investigation into a massive data breach.
column4: If the Secretary determines that exigent circumstances exist (e.g., records may be destroyed), the entity MUST permit access to its facilities and records:
column9: A. Within 24 hours of notice.B. At any time and without notice.C. Only after a court order is served.D. Only during daylight hours.
column16: B. At any time and without notice.
column19: If exigent circumstances exist, the entity must permit access by the Secretary at any time and without notice.
column39: Responsibilities of covered entities and business associates
column45: Access requirements for investigations.

column3: Scenario: Investigational Subpoenas: The Secretary issues a subpoena to a business associate to require the production of documents during a compliance review.
column4: If a subpoena is addressed to an "entity" (rather than a person), the entity MUST:
column9: A. Designate one or more natural persons to testify on its behalf.B. Refuse to respond until the CE is notified.C. De-identify all documents before production.D. Pay a fee to the Department of Justice.
column16: A. Designate one or more natural persons to testify on its behalf.
column19: When a subpoena is addressed to an entity, the entity must designate natural persons to testify as to matters known/available to the entity.
column45: Requirements for responding to subpoenas.

column3: Scenario: Discovery in ALJ Hearings: A respondent (CE) is in discovery during an administrative hearing regarding a HIPAA penalty.
column4: In an ALJ proceeding, which party has the burden of showing that "discovery should be allowed"?
column9: A. The Secretary.B. The party seeking discovery.C. The Administrative Law Judge.D. The individual affected by the breach.
column16: B. The party seeking discovery.
column19: The burden of showing that discovery should be allowed is on the party seeking discovery.
column45: Rules for discovery and burden of proof in hearings.

column3: Scenario: Statistical Sampling Evidence: During a hearing, the Secretary introduces a "statistical sampling study" to prove the number of violations.
column4: If based on appropriate sampling and valid methods, such a study constitutes:
column9: A. Hearsay evidence.B. Prima facie evidence of the number of violations.C. Irrefutable proof of liability.D. Privileged information.
column16: B. Prima facie evidence of the number of violations.
column19: A valid statistical sampling study constitutes prima facie evidence of the number of violations and material factors.
column45: Use of statistical sampling in enforcement actions.

column3: Scenario: Evidence in ALJ Hearings: A respondent attempts to exclude evidence that was not previously exchanged 15 days before the hearing.
column4: The ALJ is generally NOT bound by which of the following in an administrative hearing?
column9: A. The HIPAA Security Rule.B. The Federal Rules of Evidence.C. The Preponderance of Evidence standard.D. The Administrative Procedure Act.
column16: B. The Federal Rules of Evidence.
column19: Except as provided in Subpart E, the ALJ is not bound by the Federal Rules of Evidence but may apply them where appropriate.
column45: Admissibility of evidence in ALJ hearings.

column3: Scenario: Provider Identifiers (NPI): A billing department is reviewing the technical structure of their National Provider Identifier (NPI).
column4: The NPI is a 10-position numeric identifier that specifically includes which feature in the 10th position?
column9: A. A letter indicating the provider's specialty.B. A check digit.C. The provider's state code.D. A sequence number for subparts.
column16: B. A check digit.
column19: The NPI is a 10-position numeric identifier with a check digit in the 10th position.
column45: Technical specifications for the NPI.

column3: Scenario: National Provider System (NPS): A medical organization is dissolving. The NPS must update the status of the associated NPIs.
column4: The National Provider System (NPS) will "deactivate" an NPI upon receipt of information concerning the:
column9: A. Rebranding of the organization.B. Dissolution of the organization or death of the individual provider.C. Failure to pay annual HIPAA dues.D. Adoption of a new EHR system.
column16: B. Dissolution of the organization or death of the individual provider.
column19: The NPS deactivates NPIs for dissolution of an organization, death of an individual, or other justifying circumstances.
column45: Maintenance of the National Provider System.

column3: Scenario: Health Plan Identifiers (HPID): A business associate (BA) is conducting standard transactions on behalf of a covered entity.
column4: If a CE uses a BA for standard transactions, the CE MUST require the BA to use what to identify a health plan (if that plan has one)?
column9: A. The plan's EIN.B. The plan's HPID.C. The plan's NPI.D. The plan's tax identification number.
column16: B. The plan's HPID.
column19: If a CE uses one or more BAs to conduct transactions, it must require the BA to use an HPID to identify a health plan that has an HPID.
column45: Use of HPID by business associates.

column3: Scenario: Trading Partner Agreements: A hospital and a health plan are negotiating a "Trading Partner Agreement" for electronic data exchange.
column4: A covered entity is PROHIBITED from entering into a trading partner agreement that would:
column9: A. Specify the time for data transmission.B. Add any data elements or segments to the maximum defined data set.C. Require encryption for all data.D. Limit the number of claims per batch.
column16: B. Add any data elements or segments to the maximum defined data set.
column19: A CE must not enter into an agreement that adds data elements or segments to the maximum defined data set.
column45: Prohibitions on modifying standard transaction elements.

column3: Scenario: Code Sets: A clinic is updating its billing software to ensure medical data code sets (like CPT-4 or ICD-10) are used correctly.
column4: When conducting a standard transaction, the clinic must use medical code sets that are valid at the time:
column9: A. The claim is adjudicated.B. The health care is furnished.C. The transaction is initiated.D. The insurance premium is paid.
column16: B. The health care is furnished.
column19: Covered entities must use medical data code sets that are valid at the time the health care is furnished.
column45: Requirement to use valid medical code sets.

column3: Scenario: Pharmacy Transactions: A retail pharmacy is submitting an electronic claim for a prescription drug.
column4: The standard for "Retail pharmacy drug claims" is established by which organization?
column9: A. The American Medical Association (AMA).B. The National Council for Prescription Drug Programs (NCPDP).C. The Centers for Disease Control (CDC).D. The Department of Veterans Affairs.
column16: B. The National Council for Prescription Drug Programs (NCPDP).
column19: The standards for retail pharmacy drug claims are established by the NCPDP (e.g., Telecommunication Standard).
column45: Standards for retail pharmacy drug transactions.

column3: Scenario: Electronic Funds Transfers (EFT): A health plan is initiating an electronic funds transfer to a provider for claims payment.
column4: The instruction from a health plan to its financial institution to make an EFT payment is defined as:
column9: A. Stage 1 payment initiation.B. Remittance Advice.C. Coordination of benefits.D. Enrollment transaction.
column16: A. Stage 1 payment initiation.
column19: Stage 1 payment initiation is the health plan's instruction to its financial institution to make a claims payment using EFT.
column45: Definition of payment initiation in EFT transactions.

column3: Scenario: BA Subcontractor Security: A business associate (BA) hires a subcontractor to maintain its cloud server.
column4: The contract between the BA and its subcontractor must require the subcontractor to comply with which HIPAA subpart?
column9: A. Subpart A (General).B. Subpart C (Security).C. Subpart E (Privacy) only.D. None, as they are not a BA.
column16: B. Subpart C (Security).
column19: The contract must provide that the subcontractor agrees to comply with the applicable requirements of Subpart C (Security Standards).
column45: Requirement for subcontractors to safeguard ePHI.

column3: Scenario: Sale of PHI: An organization is considering sharing PHI with a researcher in exchange for a fee.
column4: The "Sale of protected health information" EXCLUDES a disclosure for public health purposes provided the only remuneration is:
column9: A. $1,000 flat fee.B. A reasonable cost-based fee to cover preparation and transmission.C. A percentage of the research grants.D. Free software for the clinic.
column16: B. A reasonable cost-based fee to cover preparation and transmission.
column19: Sale of PHI does not include disclosures for public health or research where the remuneration is a reasonable cost-based fee.
column45: Exceptions to the prohibition on the sale of PHI.

column3: Scenario: Conditioning Authorizations: A provider is conducting a clinical trial and wants to ensure participants sign a HIPAA authorization.
column4: A covered health care provider MAY condition the provision of research-related treatment on:
column9: A. The payment of an entry fee.B. Provision of an authorization for the use or disclosure of PHI for such research.C. The waiver of the right to an accounting.D. The individual's religious affiliation.
column16: B. Provision of an authorization for the use or disclosure of PHI for such research.
column19: A covered health care provider may condition research-related treatment on the provision of an authorization for that research.
column45: Exceptions for research-related treatment conditioning.

column3: Scenario: Disclosure of Psychotherapy Notes: A mental health professional's notes are being requested in a legal action.
column4: A covered entity MAY use or disclose psychotherapy notes WITHOUT authorization for which of the following?
column9: A. Use by the originator for treatment.B. Use by the CE to defend itself in a legal action brought by the individual.C. Use for training programs for mental health students.D. All of the above.
column16: D. All of the above.
column19: Authorization is not required for the originator's use for treatment, the CE's training programs, or the CE's legal defense.
column45: Specific exceptions for psychotherapy notes.

column3: Scenario: Marketing Communication: A clinic wants to send a promotional mailing to its patients about a new health app.
column4: An authorization is NOT required for marketing if the communication is in the form of:
column9: A. An email with a pharmaceutical logo.B. A promotional gift of nominal value provided by the covered entity.C. A text message sponsored by a third party.D. A letter recommending a specific brand of medication for remuneration.
column16: B. A promotional gift of nominal value provided by the covered entity.
column19: Authorization is not required for face-to-face communications or promotional gifts of nominal value.
column45: Exceptions to the marketing authorization requirement.

column3: Scenario: Electronic Privacy Notice: A patient agrees to receive the Notice of Privacy Practices (NPP) via email rather than in paper form.
column4: An individual who agrees to receive an electronic notice:
column9: A. Waives their right to a paper copy forever.B. Retains the right to obtain a paper copy from the CE upon request.C. Must pay a fee for any paper copy requested later.D. Can only revoke the agreement in writing via certified mail.
column16: B. Retains the right to obtain a paper copy from the CE upon request.
column19: The individual who is the recipient of an electronic notice retains the right to obtain a paper copy upon request.
column45: Rights of individuals receiving electronic notices.

column3: Scenario: Right of Access Formats: Mr. Brown requests an electronic copy of his medical records, which the provider maintains in an older legacy system.
column4: If the PHI is maintained electronically but NOT in the specific form/format requested, the provider must furnish it in:
column9: A. A readable electronic form/format as agreed to by the CE and individual.B. Hard copy only.C. Any format the provider chooses.D. A summary only.
column16: A. A readable electronic form/format as agreed to by the CE and individual.
column19: If the requested electronic format is not readily producible, the CE must provide it in a readable electronic form/format as agreed.
column45: Form of access for electronic records.

column3: Scenario: Unreviewable Denial of Access: A provider denies a patient's request to access their records.
column4: Which of the following is an "unreviewable" ground for denying access?
column9: A. Granting access is likely to endanger the life of the individual.B. The PHI was obtained from someone other than a health care provider under a promise of confidentiality.C. The PHI makes reference to another person.C. The individual is a minor.
column16: B. The PHI was obtained from someone other than a health care provider under a promise of confidentiality.
column19: Denials based on promises of confidentiality where access would reveal the source are unreviewable.
column45: Circumstances for unreviewable denials.

column3: Scenario: Suspending Accounting of Disclosures: A law enforcement official tells a clinic that providing a patient with an accounting of disclosures would impede a criminal investigation.
column4: If the law enforcement statement is made ORALLY, the clinic must temporarily suspend the right to an accounting for no longer than:
column9: A. 7 days.B. 30 days from the date of the oral statement.C. 60 days.D. Until the end of the year.
column16: B. 30 days from the date of the oral statement.
column19: An oral suspension request from law enforcement is limited to 30 days unless a written statement is submitted.
column45: Rules for law enforcement suspension of accounting rights.

column3: Scenario: Privacy Training Frequency: The organization updates its policy regarding "Genetic Information" to reflect the HITECH Omnibus rule.
column4: The organization must provide training to workforce members whose functions are affected by a material change in policies:
column9: A. By the next annual review.B. Within a reasonable period after the change becomes effective.C. Only if the workforce member requests it.D. Only if a breach occurs.
column16: B. Within a reasonable period after the change becomes effective.
column19: Training must be provided within a reasonable period of time after a material change in policies becomes effective.
column45: Frequency of updated training for material changes.

column3: Scenario: NIST Threat Sources: An IT team is classifying threats for their annual risk assessment according to NIST SP 800-30 taxonomy.
column4: According to the NIST taxonomy, "Erroneous actions taken by individuals in the course of executing everyday responsibilities" are:
column9: A. Adversarial threat sources.B. Accidental threat sources.C. Structural threat sources.D. Environmental threat sources.
column16: B. Accidental threat sources.
column19: NIST classifies erroneous actions by users as accidental threat sources.
column45: Taxonomy of threat sources.

column3: Scenario: Adversarial Threat Events: The organization identifies a risk where a competitor might gather information about their business processes via open sources.
column4: In the NIST taxonomy of adversarial threat events, "Gathering information using open-source discovery" is an example of which tactic?
column9: A. Deliver/Insert/Install.B. Perform reconnaissance and gather information.C. Coordinate a campaign.D. Exploit and compromise.
column16: B. Perform reconnaissance and gather information.
column19: Open-source discovery is classified under the "Perform reconnaissance and gather information" tactic.
column45: Representative adversarial threat events.

column3: Scenario: Spear Phishing Targets: A hacker sends an email specifically targeted at the CEO to steal their credentials.
column4: This specific type of attack, characterized as "phishing targeted at high-value targets (e.g., senior leaders)," is:
column9: A. Distributed denial-of-service.B. Spear phishing.C. Session hijacking.D. Brute force.
column16: B. Spear phishing.
column19: NIST defines spear phishing as attacks targeted at high-value targets like senior leaders or executives.
column45: Definition of spear phishing.

column3: Scenario: Network Traffic Modification: An adversary intercepts a data session and makes the two systems believe they are communicating directly while the adversary controls the entire communication.
column4: This adversarial threat event is defined by NIST as:
column9: A. Wireless jamming.B. Network traffic modification (machine-in-the-middle).C. Simple denial-of-service.D. Data scavenging.
column16: B. Network traffic modification (machine-in-the-middle).
column19: This describes an externally-based network traffic modification or "machine-in-the-middle" attack.
column45: Definition of machine-in-the-middle attacks.

column3: Scenario: Non-Adversarial Spills: A privileged user inadvertently sends a sensitive file to a unauthorized email recipient, and the system is taken offline for mitigation.
column4: This non-adversarial threat event is defined as:
column9: A. Resource depletion.B. Spilling sensitive information.C. Communications contention.D. Pervasive disk error.
column16: B. Spilling sensitive information.
column19: A "spill" occurs when an authorized user erroneously contaminates a device/network by sending info to someone not authorized to handle it.
column45: Definition of non-adversarial threat events.

column3: Scenario: Environmental Failure: A hurricane of organization-defined strength makes a primary facility inoperable.
column4: According to the NIST examples of non-adversarial threat events, a hurricane is classified as which type of source?
column9: A. Human accidental.B. Environmental.C. Structural failure.D. Adversarial.
column16: B. Environmental.
column19: NIST classifies hurricanes and earthquakes as environmental threat events/sources.
column45: Classification of environmental threat events.

column3: Scenario: Information Access Permissions: A system administrator is assigning "least privilege" access to a new billing clerk.
column4: The organization should implement policies to ensure that the workforce operates at privilege levels:
column9: A. No higher than necessary to accomplish required job duties.B. As high as possible to ensure no delays in care.C. That allow viewing of any psychiatric notes for all staff.D. Determined solely by the software vendor's default settings.
column16: A. No higher than necessary to accomplish required job duties.
column19: Least privilege involves ensuring the workforce operates at privilege levels no higher than necessary.
column45: Enforcement of least privilege in access management.

column3: Scenario: Security Awareness Channels: A clinic uses newsletters and posters to keep staff informed about new ransomware threats.
column4: These periodic security updates are the definition of which addressable specification?
column9: A. Protection from Malicious Software.B. Security Reminders.C. Log-in Monitoring.D. Password Management.
column16: B. Security Reminders.
column19: Security Reminders are periodic security updates provided to the workforce.
column45: Requirement for periodic security updates.

column3: Scenario: Incident Response Analysis: After a data breach is contained, the IT team conducts a "Post-Incident Analysis."
column4: The primary goal of this analysis should be to:
column9: A. Identify which employee to terminate.B. Improve security controls and incorporate lessons learned into updates.C. Calculate the exact Civil Money Penalty.D. Publish the results to the media.
column16: B. Improve security controls and incorporate lessons learned into updates.
column19: Post-incident analysis should be used to improve controls and reassess risk.
column45: Incorporating post-incident findings into security revisions.

column3: Scenario: Contingency Plan Modes: A clinic is operating in "Emergency Mode" due to a massive flood that destroyed local power lines.
column4: According to NIST, "Emergency Mode" operation should involve only those:
column9: A. Billing functions that ensure profitability.B. Critical business processes that must occur to protect the security of ePHI.C. Marketing campaigns that were already scheduled.D. External audit responses.
column16: B. Critical business processes that must occur to protect the security of ePHI.
column19: Emergency mode involves only those critical processes that must occur during and after a crisis to protect ePHI.
column45: Definition and implementation of emergency mode operations.

column3: Scenario: Periodic Security Evaluation: The Privacy Official suggests a way to track the organization's security progress over time.
column4: NIST recommends that evaluations capture specific which of the following to assist in tracking progress?
column9: A. Names of all whistleblowers.B. Evaluation metrics and/or measurements.C. The organizational chart of the health plan sponsor.D. The date of the individual's birth.
column16: B. Evaluation metrics and/or measurements.
column19: Metrics and measurements can assist in tracking progress over time during periodic evaluations.
column45: Developing standards and measurements for evaluations.

column3: Scenario: Business Associate Contract Monitoring: Management wants to ensure their BAs are actually protecting ePHI as promised.
column4: NIST suggests establishing criteria for what regarding the business associate contract?
column9: A. The remuneration percentage.B. Measuring contract performance.C. The number of employees in the BA's workforce.D. The BA's marketing budget.
column16: B. Measuring contract performance.
column19: Organizations should establish criteria for measuring contract performance and ensuring security requirements are met.
column45: Establishing a process for measuring contract performance.

column3: Scenario: Physical Security Measures: A clinic is relocating its central server to a more secure room.
column4: NIST suggests that, if reasonable and appropriate, non-public areas should have:
column9: A. Large windows for public transparency.B. Locks and cameras.C. A posted directory of all patients.D. Shared passwords for all maintenance staff.
column16: B. Locks and cameras.
column19: NIST suggests using locks and cameras for non-public areas containing ePHI.
column45: Typical physical security measures for non-public areas.

column3: Scenario: Workstation Use and Surroundings: A nurse uses a tablet computer to access patient charts in a busy waiting area.
column4: The "Workstation Use" standard requires policies to specify "physical attributes of the surroundings" to specifically:
column9: A. Improve internet speed.B. Prevent unauthorized persons from viewing sensitive information.C. Ensure the workstation is within reach of the Security Official.D. Match the organization's color scheme.
column16: B. Prevent unauthorized persons from viewing sensitive information.
column19: Workstation use policies should limit the ability of unauthorized persons to view sensitive info.
column45: Analyzing surroundings to prevent unauthorized viewing.

column3: Scenario: Mobile Workstation Security: Clinicians carry laptops from room to room to document care.
column4: Which of the following is a physical safeguard specifically suggested by NIST for mobile environments?
column9: A. Automatic data backups every 3 years.B. Use of physical privacy screens.C. De-identifying all data before documention.D. Allowing only clergy to touch the device.
column16: B. Use of physical privacy screens.
column19: NIST suggests physical privacy screens and anti-theft devices for workstations in mobile environments.
column45: Physical safeguards for mobile workstations.

column3: Scenario: Media Sanitization: The IT department is disposing of a stack of old hard drives.
column4: Before disposal, the hard drives should be "sanitized" according to which standard (specifically mentioned in the sources)?
column9: A. The HIPAA Privacy Rule.B. NIST SP 800-88.C. The HITECH Act.D. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
column16: B. NIST SP 800-88.
column19: NIST specifically references its own SP 800-88 for media sanitization before disposal.
column45: Sanitization of media in accordance with NIST guidance.

column3: Scenario: Modern Access Control: A health tech startup is implementing "Zero Trust" architecture for its cloud environment.
column4: NIST suggests that "Zero Trust Architecture" focuses defenses on:
column9: A. The network perimeter firewall only.B. Users, assets, and resources rather than static network boundaries.C. The organization's physical lobby.D. The presence of business associate agreements.
column16: B. Users, assets, and resources rather than static network boundaries.
column19: Zero Trust moves defenses away from static perimeters to focus on users, assets, and resources.
column45: Use of Zero Trust principles in access control.

column3: Scenario: Workstation Access Control: A physician leaves her computer unattended to attend to a patient emergency.
column4: The technical procedure to terminate an electronic session after a predetermined time of inactivity is:
column9: A. Unique user identification.B. Automatic logoff.C. Integrity control.D. Emergency access procedure.
column16: B. Automatic logoff.
column19: Automatic logoff implements procedures to terminate a session after a predetermined period of inactivity.
column45: Implementation of automatic logoff features.

column3: Scenario: Transmission Integrity: The IT team is configuring a system to send ePHI to a remote specialty clinic.
column4: "Integrity Controls" under Transmission Security specifically require security measures to:
column9: A. Encrypt the data using AES-256.B. Ensure ePHI is not improperly modified without detection.C. Limit the disclosure to first-degree relatives.D. Maintain the data for 50 years after death.
column16: B. Ensure ePHI is not improperly modified without detection.
column19: Integrity controls (Addressable) ensure transmitted ePHI is not improperly modified without detection.
column45: Measures to ensure transmitted data integrity.

column3: Scenario: Authentication Factors: The organization is requiring staff to use their fingerprint to access the pharmaceutical storage system.
column4: According to the NIST guidance, a fingerprint is which approach to authentication?
column9: A. Something you know.B. Something you have.C. Something you are (biometric identification).D. Something you like.
column16: C. Something you are (biometric identification).
column19: Biometric identification, such as a fingerprint, is classified as the "something you are" approach.
column45: Approach types for authentication.

column3: Scenario: Secure Email Transmissions: The Security Official wants to protect ePHI that leaves the organization via email.
column4: NIST suggests that organizations consider using which of the following for email leaving the organization?
column9: A. Standard non-encrypted SMTP.B. Automated confidentiality statements and encryption.C. No subject lines.D. Only de-identified data.
column16: B. Automated confidentiality statements and encryption.
column19: NIST suggests considering automated confidentiality statements and encryption for external email.
column45: Use of automated confidentiality statements and encryption for email.

column3: Scenario: Rebutting the Presumption of Breach: A hospital employee accidentally sends a spreadsheet containing PHI for 50 patients to the wrong internal department. The recipient immediately notifies the sender and deletes the email without opening the attachment.
column4: Under the Breach Notification Rule, an impermissible use or disclosure is presumed to be a breach unless the entity demonstrates:
column7: A. No financial loss occurred.B. A low probability that the PHI has been compromised.C. The employee was properly trained.D. The Secretary grants a waiver.
column15: B. A low probability that the PHI has been compromised.
column18: An acquisition, access, use, or disclosure of PHI in a non-permitted manner is presumed to be a breach unless the entity demonstrates a low probability that the PHI has been compromised.
column43: Required four-factor risk assessment to determine probability that PHI has been compromised.

column3: Scenario: Rebutting the Presumption of Breach: A hospital employee accidentally sends a spreadsheet containing PHI for 50 patients to the wrong internal department. The recipient immediately notifies the sender and deletes the email without opening the attachment.
column4: Which of the following is one of the four REQUIRED factors to consider in a breach risk assessment?
column7: A. The annual revenue of the covered entity.B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.C. The length of time since the last risk analysis.D. The presence of a Business Associate Agreement.
column15: B. Whether the PHI was actually acquired or viewed.
column18: The risk assessment must consider: (i) nature/extent of PHI, (ii) unauthorised person, (iii) whether PHI was actually acquired or viewed, and (iv) the extent of mitigation.
column43: Factor-based assessment of breach probability.

column3: Scenario: Rebutting the Presumption of Breach: A hospital employee accidentally sends a spreadsheet containing PHI for 50 patients to the wrong internal department. The recipient immediately notifies the sender and deletes the email without opening the attachment.
column4: If the entity determines there is a low probability of compromise, they must maintain documentation of the assessment for:
column7: A. 1 year.B. 3 years.C. 6 years.D. 10 years.
column15: C. 6 years.
column18: Regulated entities must maintain documentation required by the HIPAA Rules for six years from creation or when last in effect.
column43: Application of documentation requirements to breach notification activities.

column3: Scenario: Rebutting the Presumption of Breach: A hospital employee accidentally sends a spreadsheet containing PHI for 50 patients to the wrong internal department. The recipient immediately notifies the sender and deletes the email without opening the attachment.
column4: The factor "Nature and extent of the PHI involved" in a risk assessment specifically includes looking at:
column7: A. The cost of the records.B. Types of identifiers and the likelihood of re-identification.C. The server's IP address.D. The employee's previous sanction history.
column15: B. Types of identifiers and the likelihood of re-identification.
column18: The nature and extent of the PHI includes the types of identifiers and the likelihood of re-identification.
column43: Analyzing the data involved to determine risk.

column3: Scenario: Rebutting the Presumption of Breach: A hospital employee accidentally sends a spreadsheet containing PHI for 50 patients to the wrong internal department. The recipient immediately notifies the sender and deletes the email without opening the attachment.
column4: If the risk assessment determines that the PHI WAS compromised, notification to the individuals must be provided:
column7: A. Within 30 days of the incident.B. Within 60 calendar days after discovery of the breach.C. Only if the breach affects 500+ residents.D. After the media has been notified.
column15: B. Within 60 calendar days after discovery of the breach.
column18: Notification must be provided without unreasonable delay and in no case later than 60 calendar days after discovery.
column43: Requirement to provide notice without unreasonable delay.

column3: Scenario: Access Format Requests: A patient, Ms. Green, requests a copy of her medical records. She specifically asks for them in a specific digital format (e.g., an Excel file) that the hospital’s EHR system cannot produce.
column4: According to the Right of Access standard, if the PHI is not readily producible in the format requested, the entity must provide it in:
column7: A. Hard copy only.B. A readable electronic form and format as agreed to by the entity and individual.C. Any format the entity finds convenient.D. A summary only.
column15: B. A readable electronic form and format as agreed to by the entity and individual.
column18: If the requested electronic format is not readily producible, the entity must provide it in a readable electronic format as agreed upon.
column43: Individual right to obtain copies in requested form/format.

column3: Scenario: Access Format Requests: A patient, Ms. Green, requests a copy of her medical records. She specifically asks for them in a specific digital format (e.g., an Excel file) that the hospital’s EHR system cannot produce.
column4: Can the hospital provide Ms. Green with a SUMMARY of her records instead of the full copy?
column7: A. Yes, at the hospital's discretion.B. No, patients always have a right to the full record.C. Yes, if the individual agrees in advance to the summary and the associated fees.D. Only if the original records were destroyed.
column15: C. Yes, if the individual agrees in advance to the summary and the associated fees.
column18: A covered entity may provide a summary if the individual agrees in advance to the summary and the fees.
column43: Conditions for providing summaries or explanations.

column3: Scenario: Access Format Requests: A patient, Ms. Green, requests a copy of her medical records. She specifically asks for them in a specific digital format (e.g., an Excel file) that the hospital’s EHR system cannot produce.
column4: When calculating the "reasonable, cost-based fee" for providing the copy, the hospital may include the cost of:
column7: A. Labor for reviewing the records for accuracy.B. Labor for copying the PHI (paper or electronic).C. Administrative overhead for the privacy office.D. The cost of the EHR software license.
column15: B. Labor for copying the PHI (paper or electronic).
column18: Fees are limited to labor for copying, supplies for creating the copy/media, postage, and preparing a summary if agreed.
column43: Fee limitations for providing access.

column3: Scenario: Access Format Requests: A patient, Ms. Green, requests a copy of her medical records. She specifically asks for them in a specific digital format (e.g., an Excel file) that the hospital’s EHR system cannot produce.
column4: If the hospital denies access to a portion of the records (e.g., psychotherapy notes), what is their responsibility regarding the remaining records?
column7: A. Deny the entire request.B. Give the individual access to any other PHI requested after excluding the denied portion.C. Delete the denied portion and send the rest without explanation.D. Report the request to law enforcement.
column15: B. Give the individual access to any other PHI requested after excluding the denied portion.
column18: The entity must, to the extent possible, give the individual access to any other PHI requested after excluding the information for which there is a ground to deny access.
column43: Duty to make non-excluded information accessible.

column3: Scenario: Access Format Requests: A patient, Ms. Green, requests a copy of her medical records. She specifically asks for them in a specific digital format (e.g., an Excel file) that the hospital’s EHR system cannot produce.
column4: A written denial of access must contain a description of how the individual may complain to the CE or the:
column7: A. Better Business Bureau.B. Secretary of HHS.C. Local police department.D. Individual's insurance provider.
column15: B. Secretary of HHS.
column18: Denials must include a description of how to complain to the CE or the Secretary.
column43: Required elements of a written denial.

column3: Scenario: Amendment Disagreements: A patient requests an amendment to his record, which the clinic denies because the information is accurate. The patient then submits a "Statement of Disagreement."
column4: Upon receiving the Statement of Disagreement, the covered entity:
column7: A. Must delete the original record.B. May prepare a written rebuttal and must provide the individual a copy.C. Must report the patient to the Secretary.D. Is not required to take further action.
column15: B. May prepare a written rebuttal and must provide the individual a copy.
column18: The entity may prepare a rebuttal and, if so, must provide a copy to the individual.
column43: Handling disagreements and rebuttals.

column3: Scenario: Amendment Disagreements: A patient requests an amendment to his record, which the clinic denies because the information is accurate. The patient then submits a "Statement of Disagreement."
column4: For all FUTURE disclosures of the record in question, the covered entity MUST:
column7: A. Include only the original record.B. Include the statement of disagreement and the rebuttal (or accurate summaries).C. Redact the disputed portion entirely.D. Charge a higher fee for the disclosure.
column15: B. Include the statement of disagreement and the rebuttal (or accurate summaries).
column18: The entity must include the material appended (disagreement, rebuttal, etc.) or an accurate summary with subsequent disclosures.
column43: Requirements for future disclosures of disputed records.

column3: Scenario: Amendment Disagreements: A patient requests an amendment to his record, which the clinic denies because the information is accurate. The patient then submits a "Statement of Disagreement."
column4: If a covered entity is informed by another covered entity of an amendment to an individual’s PHI, they must:
column7: A. Ignore it unless the patient requests it directly.B. Amend the PHI in their own designated record sets.C. Notify the Secretary of the change.D. Verify the change with the patient's employer.
column15: B. Amend the PHI in their own designated record sets.
column18: An entity informed by another of an amendment must amend the PHI in its own records.
column43: Actions on notices of amendment from other entities.

column3: Scenario: Amendment Disagreements: A patient requests an amendment to his record, which the clinic denies because the information is accurate. The patient then submits a "Statement of Disagreement."
column4: A covered entity must document the titles of the persons or offices responsible for processing amendment requests and retain this for:
column7: A. 2 years.B. 6 years.C. 10 years.D. 50 years.
column15: B. 6 years.
column18: Entities must document titles for amendment processing and retain documentation for six years.
column43: Documentation and retention of amendment procedures.

column3: Scenario: Amendment Disagreements: A patient requests an amendment to his record, which the clinic denies because the information is accurate. The patient then submits a "Statement of Disagreement."
column4: An amendment request may be denied if the record was NOT created by the covered entity, EXCEPT if:
column7: A. The patient pays a fee for the review.B. The individual provides a reasonable basis to believe the originator is no longer available.C. The clinician agrees the information is wrong.D. The record is more than 6 years old.
column15: B. The individual provides a reasonable basis to believe the originator is no longer available.
column18: A CE may deny if they didn't create the PHI unless the individual provides a basis to believe the originator is no longer available.
column43: Grounds for denying amendment requests.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: A patient requests a list of all disclosures of his health data. The clinic must identify which disclosures must be included.
column4: Which of the following is an EXCEPTION where a disclosure does NOT need to be included in the accounting?
column7: A. Disclosures for public health activities.B. Disclosures to the individual of PHI about them.C. Disclosures to a coroner or medical examiner.D. Disclosures required by law.
column15: B. Disclosures to the individual of PHI about them.
column18: Disclosures to individuals of PHI about them are excluded from the accounting requirement.
column43: List of excluded disclosures from the accounting.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: A patient requests a list of all disclosures of his health data. The clinic must identify which disclosures must be included.
column4: Disclosures made for which purpose are also EXCLUDED from the accounting requirement?
column7: A. Research where a waiver was approved.B. National security or intelligence purposes.C. Victims of abuse or neglect.D. Oversight of the healthcare system.
column15: B. National security or intelligence purposes.
column18: Disclosures for national security or intelligence purposes are excluded from the accounting.
column43: Exclusions for national security disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: A patient requests a list of all disclosures of his health data. The clinic must identify which disclosures must be included.
column4: If an entity provides an accounting for research disclosures involving 50+ individuals, they must provide the name of the protocol and:
column7: A. A list of every patient's social security number.B. A statement that the PHI of the individual may or may not have been disclosed for that protocol.C. The exact date of every single data pull.D. A copy of the signed patient authorisation.
column15: B. A statement that the PHI of the individual may or may not have been disclosed for that protocol.
column18: For large research disclosures, the accounting must state the PHI may or may not have been disclosed for that protocol.
column43: Simplified accounting for large research disclosures.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: A patient requests a list of all disclosures of his health data. The clinic must identify which disclosures must be included.
column4: The covered entity must provide the first accounting in any 12-month period:
column7: A. For a $50 fee.B. Without charge.C. Only if the patient has a valid reason.D. Within 15 days.
column15: B. Without charge.
column18: The first accounting in any 12-month period is provided without charge.
column43: Fee rules for subsequent accounting requests.

column3: Scenario: Accounting of Disclosures: A patient requests a list of all disclosures of his health data. The clinic must identify which disclosures must be included.
column4: An individual may request an accounting of disclosures for a period of time:
column7: A. No less than 1 year.B. Less than six years from the date of the request.C. Exactly 50 years after death.D. Determined by the Secretary.
column15: B. Less than six years from the date of the request.
column18: An individual may request an accounting for a period of time less than six years.
column43: Individual right to define the accounting timeframe.

column3: Scenario: Risk Appetite and Strategy: Startup leadership is defining its "Risk Appetite" as part of a new enterprise risk management strategy to comply with the Security Rule.
column4: According to NIST SP 800-66r2, "Risk Appetite" is declared at:
column7: A. The IT Department level.B. The individual user level.C. The enterprise (highest) level of the organisation.D. The business associate's level.
column15: C. The enterprise (highest) level of the organisation.
column18: Risk appetite is declared at the enterprise level and provides a guidepost to risk acceptance for senior leaders.
column43: Strategic risk concepts for senior leadership.

column3: Scenario: Risk Appetite and Strategy: Startup leadership is defining its "Risk Appetite" as part of a new enterprise risk management strategy to comply with the Security Rule.
column4: "Risk Tolerance" differs from risk appetite because it represents:
column7: A. The total cost of security software.B. The specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite.C. The number of breaches per year.D. The length of a workstation session.
column15: B. The specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the risk appetite.
column18: Risk tolerance represents the specific level of performance risk deemed acceptable within the appetite.
column43: Definitions of risk appetite and risk tolerance.

column3: Scenario: Risk Appetite and Strategy: Startup leadership is defining its "Risk Appetite" as part of a new enterprise risk management strategy to comply with the Security Rule.
column4: NIST states that "risk appetite" and "risk tolerance" together represent:
column7: A. Technical safeguards.B. Risk limits that assist in managing risk to ePHI.C. Administrative simplification code sets.D. Unreviewable grounds for denial.
column15: B. Risk limits that assist in managing risk to ePHI.
column18: Together, these statements represent risk limits that assist entities in managing risk.
column43: Strategic risk limits in managing ePHI security.

column3: Scenario: Risk Appetite and Strategy: Startup leadership is defining its "Risk Appetite" as part of a new enterprise risk management strategy to comply with the Security Rule.
column4: If an unacceptable level of risk to ePHI cannot be adequately treated in a cost-effective manner, NIST suggests the risk should be:
column7: A. Accepted anyway to save money.B. Avoided, potentially by redesigning systems or processes.C. Ignored until an audit occurs.D. Disclosed in the Notice of Privacy Practices.
column15: B. Avoided, potentially by redesigning systems or processes.
column18: If risk cannot be treated cost-effectively, it should be avoided, which may require redesigning processes.
column43: Handling unacceptable risk through system redesign.

column3: Scenario: Risk Appetite and Strategy: Startup leadership is defining its "Risk Appetite" as part of a new enterprise risk management strategy to comply with the Security Rule.
column4: The decision factors management must use when selecting security measures (Flexibility of Approach) include:
column7: A. Size, complexity, and capabilities of the entity.B. Costs of security measures.C. Technical infrastructure.D. All of the above.
column15: D. All of the above.
column18: Decisions on measures must consider size, complexity, infrastructure, costs, and probability/criticality of risks.
column43: Factors in deciding appropriate security measures.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents (NIST): An IT team is responding to a "Security Incident" and must determine which actions are required under the Response and Reporting implementation specification.
column4: A "Security Incident" includes attempted or successful unauthorised access, use, or:
column7: A. Any failure of a software patch.B. Interference with system operations in an information system.C. Use of a personal mobile device for work.D. A patient complaint about billing.
column15: B. Interference with system operations in an information system.
column18: A security incident means attempted/successful unauthorised access, use, disclosure, modification, or destruction of info or interference with system operations.
column43: Definition of security incident.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents (NIST): An IT team is responding to a "Security Incident" and must determine which actions are required under the Response and Reporting implementation specification.
column4: The "Response and Reporting" specification (Required) mandates that the entity must:
column7: A. Terminate the employee responsible.B. Document security incidents and their outcomes.C. Notify the Secretary within 24 hours.D. Pay a fine to the individual.
column15: B. Document security incidents and their outcomes.
column18: Response and Reporting requires identifying/responding to incidents, mitigating harm, and documenting outcomes.
column43: Identifying, responding to, and documenting incidents.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents (NIST): An IT team is responding to a "Security Incident" and must determine which actions are required under the Response and Reporting implementation specification.
column4: NIST suggests that incident response programs should cover:
column7: A. Only the data center.B. All parts of the organisation in which ePHI is created, stored, processed, or transmitted.C. Only business associates.D. Only servers containing 500+ records.
column15: B. All parts of the organisation in which ePHI is created, stored, processed, or transmitted.
column18: Incident response should cover all parts of the organisation where ePHI is created, stored, processed, or transmitted.
column43: Scope of incident response programs.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents (NIST): An IT team is responding to a "Security Incident" and must determine which actions are required under the Response and Reporting implementation specification.
column4: Following an incident, NIST recommends a "Post-Incident Analysis" to:
column7: A. Improve security controls and incorporate lessons learned.B. Calculate civil money penalties.C. Determine marketing opportunities.D. Update the list of NPIs.
column15: A. Improve security controls and incorporate lessons learned.
column18: Post-incident analysis should be used to improve controls and incorporate lessons learned into updates.
column43: Using incident findings for security improvements.

column3: Scenario: Security Incidents (NIST): An IT team is responding to a "Security Incident" and must determine which actions are required under the Response and Reporting implementation specification.
column4: If an incident involves an "Inadvertent disclosure by an authorised person to another authorised person" at the same CE, it is:
column7: A. A major breach requiring media notice.B. Excluded from the definition of a breach.C. A criminal violation of HIPAA.D. A ground for unreviewable denial.
column15: B. Excluded from the definition of a breach.
column18: Breach excludes inadvertent disclosure by an authorised person to another authorised person at the same entity/BA/OHCA.
column43: Regulatory exceptions to the definition of breach.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: The Security Official is evaluating the "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" addressable specification to support contingency planning.
column4: The goal of this analysis is to assess the relative criticality of specific applications and data:
column7: A. To determine software licensing costs.B. In support of other contingency plan components.C. To decide which employees to retain.D. To assign NPI numbers to subparts.
column15: B. In support of other contingency plan components.
column18: This analysis assesses relative criticality in support of other plan components (like backup and recovery).
column43: Assessing relative criticality of ePHI systems.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: The Security Official is evaluating the "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" addressable specification to support contingency planning.
column4: Criticality levels should be assessed based on importance to:
column7: A. Annual revenue.B. Business needs or patient care.C. The Security Official's preferences.D. Future de-identification efforts.
column15: B. Business needs or patient care.
column18: Critically levels are assessed based on importance to business needs or patient care.
column43: Performance criteria for data criticality analysis.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: The Security Official is evaluating the "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" addressable specification to support contingency planning.
column4: NIST suggests using a "Business Impact Analysis" (BIA) to:
column7: A. Calculate Civil Money Penalties.B. Evaluate, record, and monitor the criticality of organizational assets.C. Track the movements of hardware devices.D. Verify the religious affiliation of clergy.
column15: B. Evaluate, record, and monitor the criticality of organizational assets.
column18: A BIA helps evaluate, record, and monitor asset criticality and informs risk tolerance.
column43: Use of BIA in security strategy.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: The Security Official is evaluating the "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" addressable specification to support contingency planning.
column4: Which standard requires establishing procedures to ENABLE continuation of critical business processes in an emergency?
column7: A. Data Backup Plan.B. Disaster Recovery Plan.C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.D. Sanction Policy.
column15: C. Emergency Mode Operation Plan.
column18: This required plan involves procedures to enable continuation of critical processes to protect ePHI security in emergency mode.
column43: Continuation of critical processes during emergencies.

column3: Scenario: Data Criticality Analysis: The Security Official is evaluating the "Applications and Data Criticality Analysis" addressable specification to support contingency planning.
column4: The Data Backup Plan standard (Required) mandates creating and maintaining:
column7: A. Paper copies of all charts.B. Retrievable exact copies of electronic PHI.C. Summaries of all patient histories.D. Off-site cloud archives for 50 years.
column15: B. Retrievable exact copies of electronic PHI.
column18: Data Backup Plan requires procedures to create/maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI.
column43: Requirement for exact data copies.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Clearance: The HR department is implementing the "Workforce Clearance Procedure" addressable specification for new clinical hires.
column4: This procedure is designed to determine that the access of a workforce member to ePHI is:
column7: A. Profitable for the organization.B. Appropriate.C. Perpetual.D. Approved by the patient.
column15: B. Appropriate.
column18: Workforce Clearance Procedure implements procedures to determine that a workforce member's access to ePHI is appropriate.
column43: Procedures to ensure appropriate access.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Clearance: The HR department is implementing the "Workforce Clearance Procedure" addressable specification for new clinical hires.
column4: NIST recommends that "Least Privilege" involves ensuring workforce members operate at privilege levels:
column7: A. High enough to access all records.B. No higher than necessary to accomplish required job duties.C. Determined by the individual employee.D. That allow viewing of psychotherapy notes.
column15: B. No higher than necessary to accomplish required job duties.
column18: Least privilege means ensuring workforce operates at privilege levels no higher than necessary.
column43: Enforcement of least privilege in access management.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Clearance: The HR department is implementing the "Workforce Clearance Procedure" addressable specification for new clinical hires.
column4: Termination procedures (Addressable) specifically include recovery of access control devices and:
column7: A. Retraining the employee.B. Deactivation of information system access.C. Updating the Notice of Privacy Practices.D. Providing a copy of the exit interview to HHS.
column15: B. Deactivation of information system access.
column18: Termination procedures include deactivating accounts and recovering devices.
column43: Procedures for ending access when employment ends.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Clearance: The HR department is implementing the "Workforce Clearance Procedure" addressable specification for new clinical hires.
column4: "Workforce members" includes entity employees, students, volunteers, and:
column7: A. All medical examiners.B. On-site contractors.C. Plan sponsors.D. Health insurance issuers.
column15: B. On-site contractors.
column18: Workforce means employees, volunteers, trainees, and others under the direct control of the CE, including on-site contractors.
column43: Key definitions, including workforce.

column3: Scenario: Workforce Clearance: The HR department is implementing the "Workforce Clearance Procedure" addressable specification for new clinical hires.
column4: The standard for "Authorization and/or Supervision" (Addressable) applies to workforce members who:
column7: A. Only work from home.B. Work with ePHI or in locations where it might be accessed.C. Are victims of a crime.D. Conduct de-identification.
column15: B. Work with ePHI or in locations where it might be accessed.
column18: This specification applies to those who work with ePHI or in locations where it might be accessed.
column43: Supervision of workforce in sensitive locations.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance: A facility manager replaces the biometric scanner on the main server room door. The Security Official must ensure this is documented properly.
column4: The requirement to document repairs and modifications to the physical components of a facility related to security is:
column7: A. Facility Security Plan.B. Maintenance Records.C. Contingency Operations.D. Audit Controls.
column15: B. Maintenance Records.
column18: Maintenance Records (Addressable) requires policies to document repairs/modifications to physical components related to security.
column43: Tracking modifications to security hardware.
