column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance: A facility manager replaces the biometric scanner on the main server room door. The Security Official must ensure this is documented properly.
column4: Examples of physical components requiring maintenance records include hardware, walls, doors, and:
column7: A. Passwords.B. Locks.C. Training logs.D. Cloud servers.
column15: B. Locks.
column18: The standard explicitly lists hardware, walls, doors, and locks as examples.
column43: Examples of facility security components.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance: A facility manager replaces the biometric scanner on the main server room door. The Security Official must ensure this is documented properly.
column4: Which standard requires policies to limit physical access to systems while ENSURING properly authorised access is allowed?
column7: A. Workstation Security.B. Facility Access Controls.C. Workforce Security.D. Transmission Security.
column15: B. Facility Access Controls.
column18: Facility Access Controls require limiting physical access while ensuring properly authorised access.
column43: Physical safeguards for facility systems.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance: A facility manager replaces the biometric scanner on the main server room door. The Security Official must ensure this is documented properly.
column4: "Facility" is defined as the physical premises and:
column7: A. The internal network only.B. The interior and exterior of a building(s).C. All remote home offices.D. The cloud provider's data center.
column15: B. The interior and exterior of a building(s).
column18: Facility means the physical premises and the interior and exterior of a building(s).
column43: Definition of facility.

column3: Scenario: Facility Maintenance: A facility manager replaces the biometric scanner on the main server room door. The Security Official must ensure this is documented properly.
column4: The "Facility Security Plan" (Addressable) involves policies to safeguard the facility and equipment from:
column7: A. Improper medical coding.B. Unauthorised physical access, tampering, and theft.C. System failure.D. Natural disasters only.
column15: B. Unauthorised physical access, tampering, and theft.
column18: This specification involves safeguarding equipment from unauthorised physical access, tampering, and theft.
column43: Physical safeguards for hardware and facilities.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Sanctions: An individual files a formal complaint regarding a clinic’s privacy practices. Management discovers a clinical employee intentionally ignored a policy.
column4: The organization is required to document all complaints received and their:
column7: A. Cost to the organization.B. Disposition, if any.C. Identification in the media.D. Related NPI.
column15: B. Disposition, if any.
column18: A CE must document all complaints received and their disposition.
column43: Requirement to document and resolve complaints.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Sanctions: An individual files a formal complaint regarding a clinic’s privacy practices. Management discovers a clinical employee intentionally ignored a policy.
column4: The requirement to apply appropriate sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with policies is a:
column7: A. Addressable implementation specification.B. Required implementation specification.C. Mandatory technical safeguard.D. Whistleblower protection.
column15: B. Required implementation specification.
column18: The Sanction Policy is a required implementation specification under the Security Management Process.
column43: Requirement to apply sanctions for non-compliance.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Sanctions: An individual files a formal complaint regarding a clinic’s privacy practices. Management discovers a clinical employee intentionally ignored a policy.
column4: The organization is PROHIBITED from taking retaliatory action against an individual for:
column7: A. Requesting a summary health record.B. Filing a complaint under the HIPAA Rules.C. Failing to pay out-of-pocket.D. Opting into fundraising communications.
column15: B. Filing a complaint under the HIPAA Rules.
column18: A CE may not intimidate or take retaliatory action against an individual for exercising a right or filing a complaint.
column43: Prohibition on retaliatory acts for exercising HIPAA rights.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Sanctions: An individual files a formal complaint regarding a clinic’s privacy practices. Management discovers a clinical employee intentionally ignored a policy.
column4: "Mitigation" (Standard) requires the entity to mitigate harmful effects of a violation committed by:
column7: A. Only the CE workforce.B. Either the covered entity or its business associate.C. Only third-party hackers.D. Only senior management.
column15: B. Either the covered entity or its business associate.
column18: The entity must mitigate harmful effects of a violation by the entity or its business associate.
column43: Obligation to mitigate known harmful effects of PHI misuse.

column3: Scenario: Complaints and Sanctions: An individual files a formal complaint regarding a clinic’s privacy practices. Management discovers a clinical employee intentionally ignored a policy.
column4: Does the sanction standard apply to a workforce member who acts as a "whistleblower" under § 164.502(j)?
column7: A. Yes, rules apply to everyone.B. No, the sanction standard does not apply to whistleblowers or crime victims.C. Only if the whistleblower is an on-site contractor.D. Only if the whistleblower notifies the media first.
column15: B. No, the sanction standard does not apply to whistleblowers or crime victims.
column18: The sanction standard does not apply to actions that meet the whistleblower or crime victim conditions.
column43: Exceptions to the sanction policy requirement.
